A baubling vessel was he captain of, For shallow draught and bulk unprizable, With which such scathful grapple did he make With the most noble bottom of our fleet, That very envy and the tongue of loss Cried fame and honor on him.—What’s the matter?
A beast, no more.

A better instance, I say.

A gallant curtal-axe upon my thigh, A boar-spear in my hand, and in my heart Lie there what hidden woman’s fear there will, We’ll have a swashing and a martial outside— As many other mannish cowards have That do outface it with their semblances.

Also King Lewis the Tenth, Who was sole heir to the usurper Capet, Could not keep quiet in his conscience, Wearing the crown of France, till satisfied That fair Queen Isabel, his grandmother, Was lineal of the Lady Ermengare, Daughter to Charles the foresaid duke of Lorraine, By the which marriage the line of Charles the Great Was reunited to the crown of France.

An eagle, madam, Hath not so green, so quick, so fair an eye As Paris hath.
An Englishman?
An evil soul producing holy witness Is like a villain with a smiling cheek, A goodly apple rotten at the heart.
An he should, it were an alms to hang him.
An he speak any thing against me, I’ll take him down, an he were lustier than he is, and twenty such Jacks.
An honest man he is, and hates the slime That sticks on filthy deeds.
An honest mind and plain, he must speak truth.
An honest tale speeds best being plainly told.
An I do not— Come, let’s see the event.
An I had been a man of any occupation, if I would not have taken him at a word, I would I might go to hell among the rogues.
An I may hide my face, let me play Thisbe too!
An I might live to see thee married once, I have my wish.
An I were so apt to quarrel as thou art, any man should buy the fee simple of my life for an hour and a quarter.
An if he be not fought withal, my lord, Let us not live in France.
An if he hear thee, thou wilt anger him.
An if I be, sir, is it any offense?
An if I could, what should I get therefore?
An if the wind blow any way from shore, I will not harbor in this town tonight.
An if they live, I hope I need not fear.
An if thou couldst, thou couldst not make him live.
An if you plead as well for them As I can say “nay” to thee for myself, No doubt we bring it to a happy issue.
An if your wife be not a madwoman, And know how well I have deserved the ring, She would not hold out enemy forever For giving it to me.
An interlude!
An inviting eye, and yet methinks right modest.
An it had not fallen flat-long.
An now tell me, how doth your cousin?
An oath of mickle might, and fury shall abate.
An oath, an oath, I have an oath in heaven.
An old Italian fox is not so kind, my boy.

An please your Worship, Brakenbury, You may partake of anything we say.

An there be any matter of weight chances, call up me.
An they be not, let them hang themselves in their own straps.
An they will take it, so.

And then the justice, In fair round belly with good capon lined, With eyes severe and beard of formal cut, Full of wise saws and modern instances; And so he plays his part.
And then the moon, like to a silver bow New bent in heaven, shall behold the night Of our solemnities.
And then, as we have ta'en the sacrament, We will unite the white rose and the red.
And then, I hope, thou wilt be satisfied.

And then?
And thence from Athens turn away our eyes To seek new friends and stranger companies.

And therefore, good Grumio, the news.
And therefore, I pray thee, news.

And thereof came it that the man was mad.

And thou, all-shaking thunder, Smite flat the thick rotundity o' th' world, Crack nature’s molds, all germens spill at once That make ingrateful man!

And though we lay these honors on this man To ease ourselves of divers slanderous loads, He shall but bear them as the ass bears gold, To groan and sweat under the business, Either led or driven, as we point the way.

And time is at his period.

And when she went away now, “Let this fellow be looked to.” “Fellow!” Not “Malvolio,” nor after my degree, but “fellow.” Why, everything adheres together, that no dram of a scruple, no scruple of a scruple, no obstacle, no incredulous or unsafe circumstance—what can be said?

Being holiday, the beggar’s shop is shut.
Being so frustrate, tell him, he mocks The pauses that he makes.

Besides—I ha' not since put up my sword— Against the Capitol I met a lion, Who glared upon me and went surly by, Without annoying me.
Besides, Antonio certified the Duke They were not with Bassanio in his ship.
Besides, he brings his destiny with him.
Besides, his cote, his flocks, and bounds of feed Are now on sale, and at our sheepcote now, By reason of his absence, there is nothing That you will feed on.
Besides, I have some business in the town.
Besides, I like you not.
Besides, in mercy, The constable desires thee thou wilt mind Thy followers of repentance, that their souls May make a peaceful and a sweet retire From off these fields where, wretches, their poor bodies Must lie and fester.
Besides, it should appear that if he had The present money to discharge the Jew, He would not take it.
Besides, old Gremio is heark'ning still, And happily we might be interrupted.
Besides, our hands are hard.
Besides, she uses me with a more exalted respect than anyone else that follows her.
Besides, the king’s name is a tower of strength Which they upon the adverse party want.
Besides, the knave is handsome, young, and hath all those requisites in him that folly and green minds look after.
Besides, their writers say, King Pepin, which deposèd Childeric, Did, as heir general, being descended Of Blithild, which was daughter to King Clothair, Make claim and title to the crown of France.
Besides, there is no king, be his cause never so spotless, if it come to the arbitrament of swords, can try it out with all unspotted soldiers.
Besides, they all are fresh.
Besides, they are our outward consciences And preachers to us all, admonishing That we should dress us fairly for our end.
Besides, they have burned and carried away all that was in the king’s tent, wherefore the king, most worthily, hath caused every soldier to cut his prisoner’s throat.
Besides, you grow dishonest.
Bespeak him a fortnight before.—I will have the heart of him if he forfeit, for were he out of Venice I can make what merchandise I will.—Go, go, Tubal, and meet me at our synagogue.
Best of comfort, And ever welcome to us.
Best safety lies in fear.
Best you safed the bringer Out of the host.
Bestow it at your pleasure, and believe Caesar’s no merchant, to make prize with you Of things that merchants sold.
Betrayed I am.
Better be with the dead, Whom we, to gain our peace, have sent to peace, Than on the torture of the mind to lie In restless ecstasy.
Better cheer may you have, but not with better heart.
Better I were distract— So should my thoughts be severed from my griefs, And woes by wrong imaginations lose The knowledge of themselves.
Better it were they all came by his father, Or by the father there were none at all, For emulation who shall now be nearest Will touch us all too near if God prevent not.
Better Macbeth Than such an one to reign.
Better once than never, for never too late.
Better thou Hadst not been born than not t' have pleased me better.
Bettering thy loss makes the bad causer worse.

Bid him set on his powers betimes before, And we will follow.
Bid him therefore consider of his ransom, which must proportion the losses we have borne, the subjects we have lost, the disgrace we have digested, which, in weight to reanswer, his pettiness would bow under.

Bid me tear the bond.
Bid that welcome Which comes to punish us, and we punish it, Seeming to bear it lightly.

Bid them all fly.

Boatswain!
Bondage is hoarse, and may not speak aloud, Else would I tear the cave where Echo lies, And make her airy tongue more hoarse than mine, With repetition of “My Romeo!” It is my soul that calls upon my name.

Borachio.
Borrow Cupid’s wings And soar with them above a common bound.

Both which, Master Constable— You have.

Boundless intemperance In nature is a tyranny.

Boy!

Brief let me be.
Brief, I recovered him, bound up his wound, And after some small space, being strong at heart,

Briefly, sir.
Briefness and fortune, work!— Brother, a word.
Bring a corollary, Rather than want a spirit.
Bring forth men-children only, For thy undaunted mettle should compose Nothing but males.
Bring her to try wi' th' main course.
Bring him away.
Bring him before us.
Bring him silently.
Bring him through the bands.
Bring him with triumph home unto his house!
Bring him, dead or living, Within this twelvemonth or turn thou no more To seek a living in our territory.
Bring it hither to me in the orchard.
Bring it to that, The gold I give thee will I melt and pour Down thy ill-uttering throat.

Brutus” will start a spirit as soon as “Caesar.” Now in the names of all the gods at once, Upon what meat doth this our Caesar feed That he is grown so great?

But if the cause be not good, the king himself hath a heavy reckoning to make, when all those legs and arms and heads, chopped off in a battle, shall join together at the latter day, and cry all, “We died at such a place,” some swearing, some crying for a surgeon, some upon their wives left poor behind them, some upon the debts they owe, some upon their children rawly left.
But if these— As I am sure they do—bear fire enough To kindle cowards and to steel with valor The melting spirits of women, then, countrymen, What need we any spur but our own cause To prick us to redress?

But upon the fairest boughs, Or at every sentence end, Will I “Rosalinda” write, Teaching all that read to know The quintessence of every sprite Heaven would in little show.

But we are spirits of another sort.

But well and free, If thou so yield him, there is gold, and here My bluest veins to kiss—a hand that kings Have lipped, and trembled kissing.

But were I Brutus, And Brutus Antony, there were an Antony Would ruffle up your spirits and put a tongue In every wound of Caesar that should move The stones of Rome to rise and mutiny.

But when we in our viciousness grow hard— Oh, misery on ’t!—the wise gods seel our eyes, In our own filth drop our clear judgments, make us Adore our errors, laugh at ’s while we strut To our confusion.

By heaven, that should be my handkerchief!

By Him that raised me to this careful height From that contented hap which I enjoyed, I never did incense his majesty Against the duke of Clarence, but have been An earnest advocate to plead for him.

By Jove that thunders!
By Jove, I am not covetous for gold Nor care I who doth feed upon my cost; It yearns me not if men my garments wear; Such outward things dwell not in my desires.
By Jupiter, I swear “No.” By Juno, I swear “Ay.”    They durst not do ’t.
By Jupiter, This shall not be revoked.
By Jupiter, Were I the wearer of Antonio’s beard, I would not shave ’t today.

By this light, a most perfidious and drunken monster.
By this marriage, All little jealousies, which now seem great, And all great fears, which now import their dangers, Would then be nothing.
By this scimitar That slew the Sophy and a Persian prince That won three fields of Sultan Solyman, I would o'erstare the sternest eyes that look, Outbrave the heart most daring on the earth, Pluck the young sucking cubs from the she-bear, Yea, mock the lion when he roars for prey, To win the lady.

Captain Jamy is a marvelous falorous gentleman, that is certain, and of great expedition and knowledge in th' aunchient wars, upon my particular knowledge of his directions.
Captain Macmorris, I beseech you now, will you voutsafe me, look you, a few disputations with you as partly touching or concerning the disciplines of the war, the Roman wars?
Captain Macmorris, I think, look you, under your correction, there is not many of your nation—  Of my nation?
Captain Macmorris, when there is more better opportunity to be required, look you, I will be so bold as to tell you I know the disciplines of war, and there is an end.
Captain, I thee beseech to do me favors.

Conscience,” say I, “you counsel well.” “Fiend,” say I, “you counsel well.” To be ruled by my conscience I should stay with the Jew my master, who, God bless the mark, is a kind of devil.

Death of one person can be paid but once, And that she has discharged.
Death of thy soul!
Death, in guerdon of her wrongs, Gives her fame which never dies.

Each new morn New widows howl, new orphans cry, new sorrows Strike heaven on the face, that it resounds As if it felt with Scotland and yelled out Like syllable of dolor.

Either be patient and entreat me fair, Or with the clamorous report of war Thus will I drown your exclamations.

Either my eyesight fails, or thou look’st pale.

Either thou, Macbeth, Or else my sword with an unbattered edge I sheathe again undeeded.

First, as you know, my house within the city Is richly furnishèd with plate and gold, Basins and ewers to lave her dainty hands; My hangings all of Tyrian tapestry, In ivory coffers I have stuffed my crowns, In cypress chests my arras counterpoints, Costly apparel, tents, and canopies, Fine linen, Turkey cushions bossed with pearl, Valance of Venice gold in needlework, Pewter and brass, and all things that belong To house or housekeeping.

First, if all obstacles were cut away And that my path were even to the crown As the ripe revenue and due of birth, Yet so much is my poverty of spirit, So mighty and so many my defects, That I would rather hide me from my greatness, Being a bark to brook no mighty sea, Than in my greatness covet to be hid And in the vapor of my glory smothered.

Five hundred poor I have in yearly pay, Who twice a day their withered hands hold up Toward heaven to pardon blood.
Five shillings to one on ’t, with any man that knows the statutes, he may stay him—marry, not without the Prince be willing, for indeed the watch ought to offend no man, and it is an offense to stay a man against his will.
Five summers have I spent in farthest Greece, Roaming clean through the bounds of Asia, And, coasting homeward, came to Ephesus, Hopeless to find, yet loath to leave unsought Or that or any place that harbors men.
Five-and-twenty, sir.

For any good That I myself have done unto myself?

For both, my lord.
For Brutus, as you know, was Caesar’s angel.
For Brutus' sake, I am beholding to you.
For but a month ago I went from hence, And then ’twas fresh in murmur—as, you know, What great ones do the less will prattle of— That he did seek the love of fair Olivia.
For by the way I’ll sort occasion, As index to the story we late talked of, To part the queen’s proud kindred from the prince.
For certain she is dead, and by strange manner.
For certain, sir, he is not.
For certainly thou art so near the gulf Thou needs must be englutted.
For charitable prayers Shards, flints and pebbles should be thrown on her.
For Christian shame, put by this barbarous brawl.
For divers unknown reasons, I beseech you, Grant me this boon.
For do but stand upon the foaming shore, The chidden billow seems to pelt the clouds, The wind-shaked surge, with high and monstrous mane, Seems to cast water on the burning bear, And quench the guards of th' ever-fixèd pole.
For doting, not for loving, pupil mine.
For Edward, for my brother, for his sake.
For England his approaches makes as fierce As waters to the sucking of a gulf.
For even out of that will I cause these of Cyprus to mutiny, whose qualification shall come into no true taste again but by the displanting of Cassio.
For every minute is expectancy Of more arrivance.
For Falstaff, he is dead, and we must earn therefore.
For first was he contract to Lady Lucy— Your mother lives a witness to that vow— And afterward by substitute betrothed To Bona, sister to the king of France.
For gazing on your beams, fair sun, being by.
For God’s love, let me hear.

For God’s sake, take a house.
For half thy wealth, it is Antonio’s.
For Hamlet and the trifling of his favor, Hold it a fashion and a toy in blood, A violet in the youth of primy nature, Forward, not permanent, sweet, not lasting, The perfume and suppliance of a minute.
For he is, sure, i' th' island.
For he loves to hear That unicorns may be betrayed with trees, And bears with glasses, elephants with holes, Lions with toils, and men with flatterers.
For he partly begs To be desired to give.
For hear me, Hero, wooing, wedding, and repenting is as a Scotch jig, a measure, and a cinquepace.
For heaven’s sake, help me!
For him, I think not on him.
For himself to mar,” quoth he?
For his bounty, There was no winter in ’t, an autumn ’twas That grew the more by reaping.
For his thoughts, Would they were blanks, rather than fill’d with me.
For his valor cannot carry his discretion, and the fox carries the goose.
For I am almost ready to dissolve, Hearing of this.
For I am he am born to tame you, Kate, And bring you from a wild Kate to a Kate Conformable as other household Kates.
For I am sick when I do look on thee.
For I am sure mine nails Are stronger than mine eyes.
For I am sure, Though you can guess what temperance should be, You know not what it is.
For I am Trinculo—be not afeard—thy good friend Trinculo.
For I can give his humor the true bent, And I will bring him to the Capitol.
For I had then laid wormwood to my dug, Sitting in the sun under the dovehouse wall.
For I have neither wit nor words nor worth, Action nor utterance nor the power of speech, To stir men’s blood.
For I have seen more years, I’m sure, than ye.
For I mine own gained knowledge should profane If I would time expend with such a snipe But for my sport and profit.
For I ne'er saw true beauty till this night.
For I tell you, father, I am as peremptory as she proud-minded; And where two raging fires meet together, They do consume the thing that feeds their fury.
For I will make him tell the tale anew Where, how, how oft, how long ago, and when He hath, and is again to cope your wife.
For if such actions may have passage free, Bond-slaves and pagans shall our statesmen be.
For if the Jew do cut but deep enough, I’ll pay it presently with all my heart.
For if the sun breed maggots in a dead dog, being a good kissing carrion— Have you a daughter?
For if thou dost intend Never so little show of love to her, Thou shalt aby it.
For in all the play There is not one word apt, one player fitted.
For indeed, who would set his wit to so foolish a bird?
For it is a figure in rhetoric that drink, being poured out of a cup into a glass, by filling the one doth empty the other.
For Juliet’s sake, for her sake, rise and stand.
For lead?
For learn this, Silius: Better to leave undone than by our deed Acquire too high a fame when him we serve’s away.
For Lord Hamlet, Believe so much in him that he is young, And with a larger tether may he walk Than may be given you.
For love I followed him.
For love of God, forbear him.
For many miles about There’s scarce a bush.
For me, I’ll not be gone till I please myself.
For me, that I may surely keep mine oath, I will be married to a wealthy widow, Ere three days pass, which hath as long loved me As I have loved this proud disdainful haggard.
For me, the gold of France did not seduce, Although I did admit it as a motive The sooner to effect what I intended; But God be thankèd for prevention, Which I in sufferance heartily will rejoice, Beseeching God and you to pardon me.
For me, three thousand ducats.
For me, with sorrow I embrace my fortune.
For Michael Cassio, I dare be sworn, I think, that he is honest.
For mine own good, All causes shall give way.
For mine own part, I shall be glad to learn of noble men.
For mine own part, no offence to the general nor any man of quality, I hope to be saved.
For Monsieur Malvolio, let me alone with him.
For murder, though it have no tongue, will speak With most miraculous organ.
For my brother, I think he holds you well, and in dearness of heart hath holp to effect your ensuing marriage—surely suit ill spent and labor ill bestowed.
For my dinner.
For my Lord Lackbeard there, he and I shall meet, and till then peace be with him.
For my part, I am so attired in wonder I know not what to say.
For my part, I am sorry it is turned to a drinking.
For my part, I care not.
For my part, I had rather bear with you than bear you.
For my part, I have walked about the streets, Submitting me unto the perilous night, And, thus unbracèd, Casca, as you see, Have bared my bosom to the thunder-stone.
For my part, the sea cannot drown me.
For my uncle is King of Denmark, and those that would make mouths at him while my father lived give twenty, forty, fifty, a hundred ducats apiece for his picture in little.
For naught so vile that on the earth doth live But to the earth some special good doth give.
For no kind of traffic Would I admit.
For not alone The death of Fulvia, with more urgent touches, Do strongly speak to us, but the letters too Of many our contriving friends in Rome Petition us at home.
For Oberon is passing fell and wrath Because that she, as her attendant hath A lovely boy stolen from an Indian king.
For often, with a solemn earnestness— More than indeed belonged to such a trifle— He begged of me to steal it.
For once upon a raw and gusty day, The troubled Tiber chafing with her shores, Caesar said to me, “Darest thou, Cassius, now Leap in with me into this angry flood And swim to yonder point?” Upon the word, Accoutred as I was, I plungèd in And bade him follow.
For one thing she did They would not take her life.
For our bad neighbor makes us early stirrers, Which is both healthful and good husbandry.
For our losses, his exchequer is too poor; for th' effusion of our blood, the muster of his kingdom too faint a number; and for our disgrace, his own person, kneeling at our feet but a weak and worthless satisfaction.
For Pyramus is a sweet-faced man, a proper man as one shall see in a summer’s day, a most lovely, gentlemanlike man.

For she his hairy temples then had rounded With a coronet of fresh and fragrant flowers, And that same dew, which sometime on the buds Was wont to swell like round and orient pearls, Stood now within the pretty flowerets' eyes Like tears that did their own disgrace bewail.

For the heavens, he shows me where the bachelors sit, and there live we as merry as the day is long.

For when mine hours Were nice and lucky, men did ransom lives Of me for jests; but now I’ll set my teeth And send to darkness all that stop me.

For who would bear the whips and scorns of time, Th' oppressor’s wrong, the proud man’s contumely, The pangs of despised love, the law’s delay, The insolence of office, and the spurns That patient merit of th' unworthy takes, When he himself might his quietus make With a bare bodkin?
For whose sake did I that ill deed?
For with throwing thus my head,  Dogs leap the hatch, and all are fled.

For, as I am a soldier, A name that in my thoughts becomes me best, If I begin the batt'ry once again, I will not leave the half-achieved Harfleur Till in her ashes she lie burièd.
For, as it is a heartbreaking to see a handsome man loose-wived, so it is a deadly sorrow to behold a foul knave uncuckolded.

For, of my heart, those charms, thine eyes, are blotted.

Friends, part!” and, swifter than his tongue, His agile arm beats down their fatal points, And ’twixt them rushes—underneath whose arm An envious thrust from Tybalt hit the life Of stout Mercutio, and then Tybalt fled.

From both, my lord.
From forth the fatal loins of these two foes A pair of star-crossed lovers take their life, Whose misadventured piteous overthrows Doth with their death bury their parents' strife.
From France there comes a power Into this scattered kingdom, who already, Wise in our negligence, have secret feet In some of our best ports and are at point To show their open banner.

Grandam, one night as we did sit at supper, My uncle Rivers talked how I did grow More than my brother: “Ay,” quoth my uncle Gloucester, “Small herbs have grace; great weeds do grow apace.” And since, methinks I would not grow so fast Because sweet flowers are slow and weeds make haste.
Grandam, this would have been a biting jest.

Had all his hairs been lives My great revenge had stomach for them all.
Had he a hand to write this, a heart and brain to breed it in?

Had he his hurts before?
Had I a glass, I would.
Had I as many mouths as Hydra, such an answer would stop them all.
Had I as many sons as I have hairs, I would not wish them to a fairer death.
Had I been any god of power, I would Have sunk the sea within the earth or ere It should the good ship so have swallowed and The fraughting souls within her.
Had I before known this young man his son, I should have given him tears unto entreaties Ere he should thus have ventured.
Had I but died an hour before this chance, I had lived a blessèd time, for from this instant There’s nothing serious in mortality.
Had I great Juno’s power, The strong-winged Mercury should fetch thee up And set thee by Jove’s side.
Had I not Four or five women once that tended me?
Had I plantation of this isle, my lord— He’d sow ’t with nettle seed.
Had I your tongues and eyes, I’d use them so That heaven’s vault should crack.
Had it th' ability of life to thank you.
Had my lips that power, Thus would I wear them out.
Had not that been as proper?
Had our general Been what he knew himself, it had gone well.
Had she affections and warm youthful blood, She would be as swift in motion as a ball.
Had she been true, If heaven would make me such another world Of one entire and perfect chrysolite, I’d not have sold her for it.
Had we done so at first, we had droven them home With clouts about their heads.
Had we fought, I doubt we should have been too young for them.
Had you been as wise as bold, Young in limbs, in judgment old, Your answer had not been inscrolled.
Had you not been their father, these white flakes Did challenge pity of them.
Had you not come upon your cue, my lord, William Lord Hastings had pronounced your part— I mean your voice for crowning of the king.
Had you rather Caesar were living and die all slaves, than that Caesar were dead, to live all free men?
Had you such leisure in the time of death To gaze upon the secrets of the deep?
Hadst thou done so, The kings that have revolted, and the soldier That has this morning left thee, would have still Followed thy heels.
Hadst thou no poison mixed, no sharp-ground knife, No sudden mean of death, though ne'er so mean, But “banishèd” to kill me?—“Banishèd”!

Haply in private.
Haply some poison yet doth hang on them, To make me die with a restorative.
Haply the seas and countries different With variable objects shall expel This something-settled matter in his heart, Whereon his brains still beating puts him thus From fashion of himself.
Haply when I shall wed That lord whose hand must take my plight shall carry Half my love with him, half my care and duty.
Haply your eye shall light upon some toy You have desire to purchase, and your store, I think, is not for idle markets, sir.
Happier than this— She is not bred so dull but she can learn.

Hastings and Edward’s children, Grey and Rivers, Holy King Henry and thy fair son Edward, Vaughan, and all that have miscarrièd By underhand, corrupted, foul injustice, If that your moody, discontented souls Do through the clouds behold this present hour, Even for revenge mock my destruction.— This is All Souls' Day, fellow, is it not?

Hath it not, boy?
Hath Leonato any son, my lord?
Hath not a Jew eyes?
Hath not a Jew hands, organs, dimensions, senses, affections, passions?
Hath not else his eye Stray’d his affection in unlawful love, A sin prevailing much in youthful men Who give their eyes the liberty of gazing?
Hath put himself from rest, And must needs taste his folly.
Hath Romeo slain himself?
Hath she forgot already that brave prince, Edward, her lord, whom I some three months since Stabbed in my angry mood at Tewkesbury?
Hath she forsook so many noble matches, Her father and her country, and her friends, To be called “whore”?
Hath she made her affection known to Benedick?
Hath the fellow any wit that told you this?
Hath there been such a time—I would fain know that— That I have positively said, “'Tis so,” When it proved otherwise?

Have an eye to Cinna.
Have at the very eye of that proverb with “A pox of the devil.”  You are the better at proverbs, by how much “A fool’s bolt is soon shot.”  You have shot over.

Have at you now!
Have at you with a proverb: shall I set in my staff?
Have by some surgeon, Shylock, on your charge, To stop his wounds lest he do bleed to death.

Have done, have done.
Have I caught thee?
Have I in conquest stretched mine arm so far To be afraid to tell graybeards the truth?
Have I not heard great ordnance in the field, And heaven’s artillery thunder in the skies?
Have I not heard the sea, puffed up with winds, Rage like an angry boar chafèd with sweat?
Have I not reason, beldams as you are?
Have I the aspic in my lips?
Have I thought long to see this morning’s face, And doth it give me such a sight as this?

Have I, my lord?
Have mercy, Jesu!—Soft, I did but dream.
Have mind upon your health, tempt me no further.
Have more than thou showest, Speak less than thou knowest, Lend less than thou owest, Ride more than thou goest, Learn more than thou trowest, Set less than thou throwest, Leave thy drink and thy whore And keep in-a-door, And thou shalt have more Than two tens to a score.
Have not saints lips, and holy palmers too?

Have you importuned him by any means?
Have you no modesty, no maiden shame, No touch of bashfulness?
Have you no more to say?
Have you no more to say?
Have you no wit, manners, nor honesty but to gabble like tinkers at this time of night?
Have you not hurt your head?
Have you not read, Roderigo, Of some such thing?
Have you not set Lysander, as in scorn, To follow me and praise my eyes and face?
Have you not set mine honor at the stake, And baited it with all the unmuzzled thoughts That tyrannous heart can think?
Have you not spoken 'gainst the Duke of Cornwall aught?
Have you sent to Bottom’s house?
Have you that holy feeling in your souls To counsel me to make my peace with God, And art you yet to your own souls so blind That thou will war with God by murd'ring me?
Have you that I sent you for?
Have you the chain about you?
Have you the lion’s part written?
Have you writ down that they are none?
Having once this juice, I’ll watch Titania when she is asleep And drop the liquor of it in her eyes.
Hazard for lead?
He always loved our sister most, and with what poor judgment he hath now cast her off appears too grossly.
He and Lepidus are at Caesar’s house.
He attendeth here hard by To know your answer whether you’ll admit him.
He attends here in the forest on the duke your father.
He bears him like a portly gentleman, And, to say truth, Verona brags of him To be a virtuous and well-governed youth.
He bears The third part of the world, man.
He bears too great a mind.
He begins at curfew and walks till the first cock.
He bounds from the earth, as if his entrails were hairs, le cheval volant, the Pegasus, qui a les narines de feu.
He breathes, my lord.
He brings great news.
He brings me liberty.
He brings you figs.
He brushes his hat o' mornings.
He calls me “boy” and chides as he had power To beat me out of Egypt.
He calls to horse, but will I know not whither.
He calls us back.
He came to me, and I delivered it.
He came too late.
He can report, As seemeth by his plight, of the revolt The newest state.
He cannot be heard of.
He cannot be such a monster— Nor is not, sure.
He cannot by the duello avoid it.
He cannot flatter, he.
He cannot like her long.
He cannot live, I hope, and must not die Till George be packed with post-horse up to heaven.
He cannot prevail with me.
He cannot speak, my lord.
He comes to kill my heart.
He comes upon a wish.
He comes, my lord.
He could not have ’scaped sixpence a day.
He cries for you, and vows, if he can take you, To scorch your face and to disfigure you.
He dares not come there for the candle.
He did appoint so.
He did ask favor.
He did bespeak a chain for me but had it not.
He did bewray his practice, and received This hurt you see striving to apprehend him.
He did command me to call timely on him.
He did comply, sir, with his dug before he sucked it.
He did in some sort, indeed, handle women, but then he was rheumatic, and talked of the Whore of Babylon.
He did me kindness, sir, drew on my side, But in conclusion put strange speech upon me.
He did not call, he’s busy in the paper.
He did receive his letters and is coming.
He did, and from my finger snatched that ring.
He did, from first to last.
He did, my gracious lord, begin that place, Which, since, succeeding ages have re-edified.
He died As one that had been studied in his death To throw away the dearest thing he owed As ’twere a careless trifle.
He dies that strikes again.
He dies!
He does hear me, And that he does I weep.
He does make our fire, Fetch in our wood, and serves in offices That profit us.—What, ho!
He does smile his face into more lines than is in the new map with the augmentation of the Indies.
He does well to commend it himself.
He does.
He doth entreat your Grace, my noble lord, To visit him tomorrow or next day.
He doth indeed show some sparks that are like wit.
He doth nothing but frown, as who should say, “An you will not have me, choose.” He hears merry tales and smiles not.
He doth, for he did bid Antonius Send word to you he would be there tomorrow.
He dreams.
He faints!—My lord, my lord!
He fears, my lord, you mean no good to him.
He fell down in the marketplace, and foamed at mouth, and was speechless.
He finished indeed his mortal act That day that made my sister thirteen years.
He followed you.
He forbids it, Being free from vainness and self-glorious pride, Giving full trophy, signal, and ostent Quite from himself, to God.
He gives you upon his knees a thousand thanks, and he esteems himself happy that he hath fall'n into the hands of one, as he thinks, the most brave, valorous, and thrice- worthy seigneur of England.
He goes before me and still dares me on.
He goes forth gallantly.
He grows worse and worse.
He had a fever when he was in Spain, And when the fit was on him, I did mark How he did shake.
He had a kind of taste.—Well, my conscience says, “Launcelot, budge not.” “Budge!” says the fiend.
He had a thousand noses, Horns whelked and waved like the enragèd sea.
He had none.
He had one yesterday.
He had, my lord, and when he ran in here, These people saw the chain about his neck.
He has a little galled me, I confess.
He has almost supped.
He has been yonder i' the sun practising behavior to his own shadow this half hour.
He has brave utensils—for so he calls them— Which when he has a house, he’ll deck withal.
He has broke my head across and has given Sir Toby a bloody coxcomb too.
He has deserved it, were it carbuncled Like holy Phoebus’ car.
He has heard that word of some great man and now applies it to a fool.
He has killed me, mother.
He has my dying voice.
He has no children.
He has no more directions in the true disciplines of the wars, look you, of the Roman disciplines, than is a puppy dog.
He hath a heart as sound as a bell, and his tongue is the clapper, for what his heart thinks, his tongue speaks.
He hath an argosy bound to Tripolis, another to the Indies.
He hath an uncle here in Messina will be very much glad of it.
He hath assembled Bocchus, the King of Libya; Archelaus, Of Cappadocia; Philadelphos, King Of Paphlagonia; the Thracian king, Adallas; King Manchus of Arabia; King of Pont; Herod of Jewry; Mithridates, King Of Comagen; Polemon and Amyntas, The Kings of Mede and Lycaonia, With a more larger list of scepters.
He hath been a courtier, he swears.
He hath been in unusual pleasure, and Sent forth great largess to your offices.
He hath been most notoriously abused.
He hath been out nine years, and away he shall again.
He hath brought many captives home to Rome Whose ransoms did the general coffers fill.
He hath commission from thy wife and me To hang Cordelia in the prison and To lay the blame upon her own despair, That she fordid herself.
He hath confessed.
He hath disgraced me and hindered me half a million, laughed at my losses, mocked at my gains, scorned my nation, thwarted my bargains, cooled my friends, heated mine enemies—and what’s his reason?
He hath done good service, lady, in these wars.
He hath every month a new sworn brother.
He hath fought today As if a god, in hate of mankind, had Destroyed in such a shape.
He hath given his empire Up to a whore; who now are levying The kings o’ th’ earth for war.
He hath honored me of late, and I have bought Golden opinions from all sorts of people, Which would be worn now in their newest gloss, Not cast aside so soon.
He hath known you but three days, and already you are no stranger.
He hath left them you And to your heirs forever—common pleasures, To walk abroad and recreate yourselves.
He hath lost his fellows And strays about to find 'em.
He hath made me a Christian.
He hath neither Latin, French, nor Italian, and you will come into the court and swear that I have a poor pennyworth in the English.
He hath no daughters, sir.
He hath no friends but who are friends for fear.
He hath not told his thought to the king?
He hath not told us of the captain yet.
He hath not touched you yet.
He hath refused it in the open court.
He hath rid his prologue like a rough colt.
He hath slept long.
He hath some meaning in his mad attire.
He hath the falling sickness.
He hath the jewel of my life in hold, His youngest daughter, beautiful Bianca, And her withholds from me and other more, Suitors to her and rivals in my love, Supposing it a thing impossible, For those defects I have before rehearsed, That ever Katherina will be wooed.
He hath twice or thrice cut Cupid’s bow-string, and the little hangman dare not shoot at him.
He hath, my lord, but be you well assured No more than he’ll unswear.
He hath, my lord, of late made many tenders Of his affection to me.
He hath, my lord.
He hath.
He himself Calls her a nonpareil.
He holds me well.
He is a craven and a villain else, an ’t please your Majesty, in my conscience.
He is a dreamer.
He is a gentleman of a good house, and for his ransom he will give you two hundred crowns.
He is a god and knows What is most right.
He is a good one, and his worthiness Does challenge much respect.—Come, Desdemona, Once more, well met at Cyprus.
He is a proper man’s picture, but alas, who can converse with a dumb show?
He is a sailmaker in Bergamo.
He is a sick man that would speak with you.
He is a very proper man.
He is about the house.
He is addressed.
He is afeard to come.
He is all the mother’s, from the top to toe.
He is already named and gone to Scone To be invested.
He is arrived.
He is as disproportioned in his manners As in his shape.— Take with you your companions.
He is as full of valor as of kindness, Princely in both.
He is as horribly conceited of him, and pants and looks pale, as if a bear were at his heels.
He is at hand, and Pindarus is come To do you salutation from his master.
He is attended with a desperate train.
He is called Aunchient Pistol.
He is coming.
He is composed and framed of treachery, And fled he is upon this villainy.
He is descried.
He is drowned Whom thus we stray to find, and the sea mocks Our frustrate search on land.
He is drunk now.
He is enamored on Hero.
He is hid at Lawrence' cell.
He is in earnest.
He is in heaven, where thou shalt never come.
He is indeed a horse, and all other jades you may call beasts.
He is justly served.
He is knight, dubbed with unhatched rapier and on carpet consideration, but he is a devil in private brawl.
He is married?
He is most in the company of the right noble Claudio.
He is much changed.
He is my dear friend, an please you.
He is my prisoner, and you shall not have him.
He is my prisoner.
He is no less than a stuffed man.
He is not doubted.—A word, Lucillius.
He is not here, so please your lordship, that should sing it.
He is not here.
He is not lolling on a lewd love bed, But on his knees at meditation; Not dallying with a brace of courtesans, But meditating with two deep divines; Not sleeping, to engross his idle body, But praying, to enrich his watchful soul.
He is not the flower of courtesy, but, I’ll warrant him, as gentle as a lamb.
He is not very tall—yet for his years he’s tall.
He is not yet arrived.
He is now as valiant as Hercules that only tells a lie and swears it.
He is now in some commerce with my lady and will by and by depart.
He is of a very melancholy disposition.
He is of note.
He is or ta'en or slain.
He is ready at the door.
He is returned.
He is sad and civil And suits well for a servant with my fortunes.
He is simply the most active gentleman of France.
He is slain.
He is sure possessed, madam.
He is the brooch indeed And gem of all the nation.
He is the general challenger.
He is the only man of Italy, Always excepted my dear Claudio.
He is then a giant to an ape; but then is an ape a doctor to such a man.
He is too disputable for my company.
He is unqualitied with very shame.
He is very busy about it.
He is very near by this.
He is very well-favored, and he speaks very shrewishly.
He is welcome hither.
He is welcome too.
He is well paid that is well satisfied.
He is wise, And, on my life, hath stol'n him home to bed.
He is, indeed, sir, the most skillful, bloody, and fatal opposite that you could possibly have found in any part of Illyria.
He is, my lord, and safe in Leicester town, Whither, if it please you, we may now withdraw us.
He is.
He kills her in her own humor.
He knows I know him well.
He knows me as the blind man knows the cuckoo— By the bad voice.
He knows not the stop.
He knows not what he says, and vain it is That we present us to him.
He knows not yet of his honorable fortune.
He knows that you embrace not Antony As you did love, but as you feared him.
He lays it on.
He leads himself.
He left behind him myself and a sister, both born in an hour.
He left this ring behind him, Would I or not.
He lies not like the living.
He lies to th' heart.
He lies tonight within seven leagues of Rome.
He lives that loves thee better than he could.
He longs not for the dawning as we do.
He longs to eat the English.
He longs to see your head.
He looks gentler than he did.
He loves me well, and I have given him reasons.
He made you for a highway to my bed, But I, a maid, die maiden-widowèd.
He married but his occasion here.
He may command me as my sovereign, But you have power in me as in a kinsman.
He may recover yet.
He may show what outward courage he will, but I believe, as cold a night as ’tis, he could wish himself in Thames up to the neck; and so I would he were, and I by him, at all adventures, so we were quit here.
He may win, And what is music then?
He meant he did me none; the more my spite.
He might have chid me so, for, in good faith, I am a child to chiding.
He misses not much.
He named Sebastian.
He needs as many, sir, as Caesar has, Or needs not us.
He needs not.
He never did harm that I heard of.
He no more shall see my face.
He only in a general honest thought And common good to all, made one of them.
He only lived but till he was a man, The which no sooner had his prowess confirmed In the unshrinking station where he fought, But like a man he died.
He passes some humors and careers.
He plies the duke at morning and at night, And doth impeach the freedom of the state If they deny him justice.
He prays you to save his life.
He raised the house with loud and coward cries.
He ran this way and leapt this orchard wall.
He received them Of him that brought them.
He replied, “Thou unpossessing bastard!
He said mine eyes were black and my hair black And, now I am remembered, scorned at me.
He said once the devil would have him about women.
He said the truth.
He saves my labor by his own approach.
He says for Brutus' sake He finds himself beholding to us all.
He says he’ll come.
He says his name is Master Fer.
He says his name’s Poor Tom.
He says so, Tranio?
He says so.
He says they can do nothing in this kind.
He says, my lord, your daughter is not well.
He seeks my life.
He seems to have a foreknowledge of that too, and therefore comes to speak with you.
He sees thee not.
He sends to know if your pleasure hold to play with Laertes, or that you will take longer time.
He sent me word if I said his beard was not cut well, he was in the mind it was.
He shall do this, or else I do recant The pardon that I late pronouncèd here.
He shall enlarge him.
He shall have merely justice and his bond.
He shall have nothing but the penalty.
He shall in time be ready.
He shall kill two of us, and men indeed, But that’s no matter.
He shall live a man forbid.
He shall not go to prison.
He shall not live.
He shall pay for him that hath him, and that soundly.
He shall see none to fear.
He shall spurn fate, scorn death, and bear His hopes 'bove wisdom, grace, and fear.
He shall stay my leisure.
He shall taste of my bottle.
He shall tell them so.
He shall think, by the letters that thou wilt drop, that they come from my niece, and that she’s in love with him.
He should, for that, commit your godfathers.
He sings at grave- making.
He smiled and said “The better for our purpose.” He was in the right, and so indeed it is.
He sought my life, But lately, very late.
He speaks home, madam.
He speaks not true.
He speaks nothing but madman.
He speaks to me.—I am your master, Dromio.
He speaks well.
He started one poor heart of mine in thee.
He stays upon your will.
He supped at my house, but I therefore shake not.
He sups tonight with a harlotry, and thither will I go to him.
He swore he would never marry, and yet now, in despite of his heart, he eats his meat without grudging.
He takes on him to understand so much, and therefore comes to speak with you.
He taught me how to know a man in love, in which cage of rushes I am sure you are not prisoner.
He tells me flatly there is no mercy for me in heaven because I am a Jew’s daughter, and he says you are no good member of the commonwealth, for in converting Jews to Christians you raise the price of pork.
He tells me, my dear Gertrude, he hath found The head and source of all your son’s distemper.
He that commends me to mine own content Commends me to the thing I cannot get.
He that conceals him, death.
He that has a house to put ’s head in has a good headpiece.
He that has the two fair daughters—is ’t he you mean?
He that is giddy thinks the world turns round.
He that is giddy thinks the world turns round”— I pray you, tell me what you meant by that.
He that is robbed, not wanting what is stol'n, Let him not know’t, and he’s not robbed at all.
He that keeps nor crust nor crumb,  Weary of all, shall want some.
He that knows better how to tame a shrew, Now let him speak; ’tis charity to show.
He that parts us shall bring a brand from heaven And fire us hence like foxes.
He that plays the king shall be welcome.
He that shall see this day, and live old age, Will yearly on the vigil feast his neighbors And say, “Tomorrow is Saint Crispian.” Then will he strip his sleeve and show his scars, And say, “These wounds I had on Crispin’s day.”
He that stirs next to carve for his own rage Holds his soul light, he dies upon his motion.
He that sweetest rose will find Must find love’s prick, and Rosalind.
He that will think to live till he be old, Give me some help!
He therefore sends you, meeter for your spirit, This tun of treasure, and, in lieu of this, Desires you let the dukedoms that you claim Hear no more of you.
He thinks he still is at his instrument.
He thinks, being twenty times of better fortune, He is twenty men to one.
He threw his eye aside— And mark what object did present itself: Under an old oak, whose boughs were mossed with age And high top bald with dry antiquity, A wretched, ragged man, o'ergrown with hair, Lay sleeping on his back.
He uses his folly like a stalking-horse, and under the presentation of that he shoots his wit.
He was a bachelor then.
He was a goodly king.
He was a man.
He was but a fool that brought My answer back.
He was disposed to mirth, but on the sudden A Roman thought hath struck him.—Enobarbus!
He was furnished like a hunter.
He was my friend, faithful and just to me.
He was not born to shame.
He was not merry, Which seemed to tell them his remembrance lay In Egypt with his joy, but between both.
He was not sad, for he would shine on those That make their looks by his.
He was not three leagues off when I left him.
He was quick mettle when he went to school.
He was the wretched’st thing when he was young, So long a-growing and so leisurely, That if this rule were true, he should be gracious.
He was wont to call me usurer; let him look to his bond.
He was wont to lend money for a Christian courtesy; let him look to his bond.
He waxes desperate with imagination.
He were a brave monster indeed, if they were set in his tail.
He were an excellent man that were made just in the midway between him and Benedick.
He were no lion were not Romans hinds.
he whom next thyself Of all the world I loved and to him put The manage of my state, as at that time Through all the signories it was the first, And Prospero the prime duke, being so reputed In dignity, and for the liberal arts Without a parallel.
He will bear you easily and reins well.
He will come straight.
He will do all in all as Hastings doth.
He will find it comes from a clodpole.
He will keep that good name still.
He will not fight with me, Domitius?
He will not know what all but he do know.
He will not say so.
He will to his Egyptian dish again.
He will, an if he live to be a man.
He wonders to what end you have assembled Such troops of citizens to come to him, His grace not being warned thereof before.
He wore his beaver up.
He would be crowned.
He would have deserved it.
He would make but a sport of it and torment the poor lady worse.
He would not have spoke such a word.
He would not take the crown.
He would not?
He, for his father’s sake, so loves the prince That he will not be won to aught against him.
He, he, ’tis he.
He, of all the men that ever my foolish eyes looked upon, was the best deserving a fair lady.
He, sir, that must marry this woman.
He, sir.
He, that Caliban Whom now I keep in service.
He, upon some action, Is now in durance at Malvolio’s suit, A gentleman and follower of my lady’s.
He, when he hears of her, cannot refrain From the excess of laughter.
He, woman.
He.
He’ll be hanged yet, though every drop of water swear against it and gape at widest to glut him.
He’ll but break a comparison or two on me, which, peradventure not marked or not laughed at, strikes him into melancholy, and then there’s a partridge wing saved, for the fool will eat no supper that night.
He’ll fright you up, i' faith.
He’ll make a proper man.
He’ll make your Paris Louvre shake for it, Were it the mistress court of mighty Europe.
He’ll never yield to that.
He’ll say ’twas done cowardly, when he wakes.
He’ll speak with you, will you or no.
He’ll watch the horologe a double set If drink rock not his cradle.
He’s a conspirator.
He’s a coward and a coistrel that will not drink to my niece till his brains turn o' th' toe like a parish top.
He’s a friend of the Duke Alençon’s.
He’s a good fellow, I can tell you that.
He’s a traitor.
He’s a very fool and a prodigal.
He’s almost slain, and Roderigo dead.
He’s as good at anything and yet a fool.
He’s as tall a man as any ’s in Illyria.
He’s bound unto Octavia.
He’s coming hither—now, i' th' night, i' th' haste, And Regan with him.
He’s coming, madam; but in very strange manner.
He’s coming, madam.
He’s dead and rotten.
He’s dead.
He’s fat, and scant of breath.— Here, Hamlet, take my napkin, rub thy brows.
He’s fortified against any denial.
He’s friends with Caesar, In state of health, thou say’st, and, thou say’st, free.
He’s gone, but his wife’s killed.
He’s gone.
He’s in Arthur’s bosom, if ever man went to Arthur’s bosom.
He’s in his fit now and does not talk after the wisest.
He’s in yellow stockings.
He’s married to Octavia.
He’s married, madam.
He’s married.
He’s no standard.
He’s not thy kinsman.
He’s now in Florence.
He’s of the color of the nutmeg.
He’s safe for these three hours.
He’s speaking now, Or murmuring “Where’s my serpent of old Nile?” For so he calls me.
He’s that he is.
He’s worth more sorrow, And that I’ll spend for him.
He’s worth no more.
Hear a little further And then I’ll bring thee to the present business Which now ’s upon ’s, without the which this story Were most impertinent.
Hear Antony.
Hear his speech but say thou nought.
Hear it apart.
Hear it not, Duncan, for it is a knell That summons thee to heaven or to hell.
Hear me a word, For I shall never speak to thee again.
Hear me for my cause, and be silent that you may hear.
Hear me with patience.
Hear me yet, good Shylock.
Hear me, Beatrice— Talk with a man out at a window!
Hear me, for I will speak.
Hear me, good brother— Under your pardon.
Hear me, good friends—
Hear me, good madam.
Hear me, hear me what I say: he that strikes the first stroke, I’ll run him up to the hilts, as I am a soldier.
Hear me, my lord.
Hear me, Queen: The strong necessity of time commands Our services awhile, but my full heart Remains in use with you.
Hear me, recreant!
Hear me, you wrangling pirates, that fall out In sharing that which you have pilled from me!
Hear my excuse.
Hear my soul speak.
Hear the ambassadors.
Hear the noble Antony.
Hear the shrill whistle, which doth order give To sounds confused.

Hear you the news abroad?

Hear you, sir?
Hear, Nature, hear, dear goddess, hear!
Heard you of nothing strange about the streets?
Heard you this, Gonzalo?
Heart, once be stronger than thy continent.
Hearts, tongues, figures, scribes, bards, poets, cannot Think, speak, cast, write, sing, number—hoo!— His love to Antony.
Hearty thanks.
Heaven and earth!
Heaven and thy thoughts are witness that thou art.
Heaven and yourself Had part in this fair maid.
Heaven doth truly know it.
Heaven keep the monster from Othello’s mind!
Heaven knows what she has known.
Heaven make thee free of it.
Heaven me such uses send, Not to pick bad from bad, but by bad mend!
Heaven preserve you!
Heaven rest them now.
Heaven truly knows that thou art false as hell.
Heaven would that she these gifts should have And I to live and die her slave.
Heavenly powers, restore him!
Heavens keep him from these beasts!
Heavens make our presence and our practices Pleasant and helpful to him!
Heavens shield Lysander if they mean a fray!
Heavens thank you for ’t!
Heavens, I am the best of them that speak this speech, Were I but where ’tis spoken.
Heigh-ho.
Helen, it is not so.
Helen, to you our minds we will unfold.
Helena, adieu.
Help me hence, ho!
Help me into some house, Benvolio, Or I shall faint.
Help me, help me!
Help me, my women!
Help to bear this away where my hogshead of wine is, or I’ll turn you out of my kingdom.

Help, help, help!

Help, ho!
Help!
Hem them away.
Hence “banishèd” is banished from the world, And world’s exile is death.
Hence his ambition growing— Dost thou hear?
Hence will I to my ghostly friar’s close cell, His help to crave and my dear hap to tell.
Hence with your little ones.
Hence, and avoid my sight!— So be my grave my peace as here I give Her father’s heart from her.—Call France.
Hence, and stand aloof.
Hence, away!
Hence, be gone, away!
Hence, get thee gone, and follow me no more.
Hence, horrible shadow!
Hence, horrible villain, or I’ll spurn thine eyes Like balls before me!
Hence, Lest that th' infection of his fortune take Like hold on thee.
Hence, make your best of it.
Hence, Mardian, And bring me how he takes my death.
Hence, prating peasant!
Hence, saucy eunuch!
Hence!
Hence!
Hence!
Hence!
Hence.
Hence.
Henceforth I never will be Romeo.
Henceforth I’ll bear Affliction till it do cry out itself, “Enough, enough,” and die.
Henceforward do your messages yourself.
Henry the Sixth, in infant bands crowned king Of France and England, did this king succeed, Whose state so many had the managing That they lost France and made his England bleed, Which oft our stage hath shown.
Her blood is settled, and her joints are stiff.
Her blush is guiltiness, not modesty.
Her body sleeps in Capels' monument, And her immortal part with angels lives.
Her dotage now I do begin to pity.
Her eye discourses.
Her eye in heaven Would through the airy region stream so bright That birds would sing and think it were not night.
Her eyes are fierce, but thine Do comfort and not burn.
Her fallow leas The darnel, hemlock, and rank fumitory Doth root upon, while that the coulter rusts That should deracinate such savagery.
Her father is Baptista Minola, An affable and courteous gentleman.
Her father loved me, oft invited me, Still questioned me the story of my life From year to year, the battles, sieges, fortunes, That I have passed.
Her father’s brother Would be her lord?
Her hair, what color?
Her head’s declined, and death will seize her but Your comfort makes the rescue.
Her hedges, even-pleached, Like prisoners wildly overgrown with hair, Put forth disordered twigs.
Her husband, knave.
Her husband, sirrah?
Her length of sickness, with what else more serious Importeth thee to know, this bears.
Her lord is come.
Her love to both Would each to other and all loves to both Draw after her.
Her mother hath many times told me so.
Her name is Katherina Minola, Renowned in Padua for her scolding tongue.
Her name is Margery, indeed.
Her name is Portia, nothing undervalued To Cato’s daughter, Brutus' Portia.
Her name, that was as fresh As Dian’s visage, is now begrimed and black As mine own face.
Her only fault, and that is faults enough, Is that she is intolerable curst, And shrewd and froward, so beyond all measure That, were my state far worser than it is, I would not wed her for a mine of gold.
Her vestal livery is but sick and green, And none but fools do wear it.
Her vine, the merry cheerer of the heart, Unprunèd, dies.
Her waspish-headed son has broke his arrows, Swears he will shoot no more, but play with sparrows And be a boy right out.
Her worth being mounted on the wind, Through all the world bears Rosalind.
Herald, save thou thy labor.

Here lay Duncan, His silver skin laced with his golden blood, And his gashed stabs looked like a breach in nature For ruin’s wasteful entrance; there, the murderers, Steeped in the colors of their trade, their daggers Unmannerly breeched with gore.
Here let them lie Till famine and the ague eat them up.
Here lie I down and measure out my grave.
Here lies the county slain, And Juliet bleeding, warm and newly dead, Who here hath lain these two days buried.— Go, tell the Prince.

Here lies your way.
Here love, thou seest how diligent I am, To dress thy meat myself and bring it thee.

Hereafter, in a better world than this, I shall desire more love and knowledge of you.

Hero itself can blot out Hero’s virtue.
Hero that is dead!
Hero thinks surely she will die, for she says she will die if he love her not, and she will die ere she make her love known, and she will die if he woo her rather than she will bate one breath of her accustomed crossness.
Hers you are.
Hey, Mountain, hey!
Hid’st thou that forehead with a golden crown Where should be branded, if that right were right, The slaughter of the prince that owed that crown And the dire death of my poor sons and brothers?

Him and his worth and our great need of him You have right well conceited.
Himself in person there?
Himself.
His absence, sir, Lays blame upon his promise.
His affections do not that way tend.
His answer was, the people were not used To be spoke to but by the recorder.
His backward voice is to utter foul speeches and to detract.
His bark is stoutly timbered and his pilot Of very expert and approved allowance Therefore my hopes, not surfeited to death, Stand in bold cure.
His beard was grizzled, no?
His better doth not breathe upon the earth.
His breeding, sir, hath been at my charge.
His captain’s heart, Which in the scuffles of great fights hath burst The buckles on his breast, reneges all temper And is become the bellows and the fan To cool a gypsy’s lust.
His ceremonies laid by, in his nakedness he appears but a man, and though his affections are higher mounted than ours, yet when they stoop, they stoop with the like wing.
His company must do his minions grace, Whilst I at home starve for a merry look.
His counsel now might do me golden service.
His countenance likes me not.
His coward lips did from their color fly, And that same eye whose bend doth awe the world Did lose his luster.
His daughter and I will be king and queen—save our graces!—and Trinculo and thyself shall be viceroys.—Dost thou like the plot, Trinculo?
His daughter is to be brought by you to the supper.
His daughters seek his death.
His death’s upon him, but not dead.
His discretion, I am sure, cannot carry his valor, for the goose carries not the fox.
His dishonesty appears in leaving his friend here in necessity and denying him.
His employment between his lord and my niece confirms no less.
His excellence did earn it, ere he had it.
His eyes are humbler than they used to be.
His eyes are red as fire with weeping.
His eyes were green as leeks.
His eyes were set at eight i' the morning.
His father was called Philip of Macedon, as I take it.
His father, though I say ’t, is an honest exceeding poor man and, God be thanked, well to live.
His fault concludes but what the law should end, The life of Tybalt.
His fault is much, and the good king his master Will check him for ’t.
His flight was madness.
His folly, Helena, is no fault of mine.
His forward voice now is to speak well of his friend.
His glory not extenuated wherein he was worthy, nor his offenses enforced for which he suffered death.
His grace hath made the match, and all grace say “Amen” to it.
His grace looks cheerfully and smooth this morning.
His grace speaks cheerfully.
His highness is not well.
His Honor and myself are at the one, And at the other is my good friend Catesby, Where nothing can proceed that toucheth us Whereof I shall not have intelligence.
His horse is slain, and all on foot he fights, Seeking for Richmond in the throat of death.
His hour is almost past.
His indignation derives itself out of a very competent injury.
His knights grow riotous, and himself upbraids us On every trifle.
His lecture will be done ere you have tuned.
His leg is but so-so—and yet ’tis well.
His letter there Will show you his estate.
His life I gave him and did thereto add My love, without retention or restraint, All his in dedication.
His life was gentle, and the elements So mixed in him that Nature might stand up And say to all the world, “This was a man.” According to his virtue let us use him, With all respect and rites of burial.
His majesty, Tend'ring my person’s safety, hath appointed This conduct to convey me to the Tower.
His name is Balthazar.
His name, my lord, is Tyrrel.
His name!
His name’s Cinna.
His neigh is like the bidding of a monarch, and his countenance enforces homage.
His nurse?
His own unkindness That stripped her from his benediction turned her To foreign casualties, gave her dear rights To his dog-hearted daughters.
His passport shall be made, And crowns for convoy put into his purse.
His present and your pains we thank you for.
His reared arm Crested the world.
His reason well I know.
His roguish madness Allows itself to any thing.
His royal grace, Whom God preserve better than you would wish, Cannot be quiet scarce a breathing while But you must trouble him with lewd complaints.
His soldiership Is twice the other twain.
His son is elder, sir.
His son is thirty.
His son was but a ward two years ago.
His speech was like a tangled chain.
His spirits hear me And yet I needs must curse.
His taints and honors Waged equal with him.
His very genius hath taken the infection of the device, man.
His very opinion in the letter!
His wits are gone.
His word is more than the miraculous harp.
His word might bear my wealth at any time.
His words were, “Farewell, mistress.” Nothing else.

How malicious is my fortune, that I must repent to be just!
How many cowards whose hearts are all as false As stairs of sand wear yet upon their chins The beards of Hercules and frowning Mars, Who, inward searched, have livers white as milk, And these assume but valor’s excrement To render them redoubted.
How many fond fools serve mad jealousy!
How many gentlemen have you lost in this action?
How many goodly creatures are there here!
How many months Do you desire?
How many then should cover that stand bare!
How many things by season seasoned are To their right praise and true perfection!
How many times shall Caesar bleed in sport, That now on Pompey’s basis lies along No worthier than the dust!
How many, as you guess?

How silver-sweet sound lovers' tongues by night, Like softest music to attending ears!
How smooth and even they do bear themselves, As if allegiance in their bosoms sat Crownèd with faith and constant loyalty.
How sound is she asleep!
How sweet is love itself possessed When but love’s shadows are so rich in joy!
How sweet the moonlight sleeps upon this bank!

How that might change his nature, there’s the question.
How the moon sleeps with Endymion And would not be awaked.

how, I pray?
How, in one house, Should many people under two commands Hold amity?

Hugh Capet also, who usurped the crown Of Charles the duke of Lorraine, sole heir male Of the true line and stock of Charles the Great, To find his title with some shows of truth, Though in pure truth it was corrupt and naught, Conveyed himself as th' heir to th' Lady Lingare, Daughter to Charlemagne, who was the son To Lewis the Emperor, and Lewis the son Of Charles the Great.

I am all the daughters of my father’s house, And all the brothers too—and yet I know not.
I am alone the villain of the earth, And feel I am so most.

I am an ass, indeed; you may prove it by my long ears.—I have served him from the hour of my nativity to this instant, and have nothing at his hands for my service but blows.

I called thee then “vain flourish of my fortune.” I called thee then poor shadow, “painted queen,” The presentation of but what I was, The flattering index of a direful pageant, One heaved a-high, to be hurled down below, A mother only mocked with two fair babes, A dream of what thou wast, a garish flag To be the aim of every dangerous shot, A sign of dignity, a breath, a bubble, A queen in jest, only to fill the scene.

I do love nothing in the world so well as you.
I do never use it.
I do not bid the thunder-bearer shoot, Nor tell tales of thee to high-judging Jove.
I do not bid thee call.
I do not desire he should answer for me, and yet I determine to fight lustily for him.
I do not find that thou deal’st justly with me.
I do not know dat.
I do not know One of my sex, no woman’s face remember— Save, from my glass, mine own.
I do not know what “poetical” is.
I do not know you so good a man as myself.
I do not know, my lord, what I should think.
I do not know.
I do not like her name.
I do not like the office.
I do not like the Tower, of any place.— Did Julius Caesar build that place, my lord?
I do not like thy look, I promise thee.
I do not like your faults.
I do not now fool myself, to let imagination jade me, for every reason excites to this, that my lady loves me.
I do not see them bleed.
I do not set my life in a pin’s fee, And for my soul—what can it do to that, Being a thing immortal as itself?
I do not think ’t.
I do not think it good.
I do not think so.
I do not think there is any such woman.
I do not think thou canst, for then thou wast not Out three years old.
I do not understand.
I do not well know, my lord.
I do not well understand that.
I do not, sir.
I do not, till you practice them on me.
I do now let loose my opinion, hold it no longer: this is no fish, but an islander that hath lately suffered by a thunderbolt.
I do obey thee till I give thee bail.
I do remember in this shepherd boy Some lively touches of my daughter’s favor.
I do remember me, Henry the Sixth Did prophesy that Richmond should be king, When Richmond was a little peevish boy.
I do remember now.
I do remember well where I should be, And there I am.
I do remember.
I do repent me that I put it to you.
I do repent The tedious minutes I with her have spent.
I do require them of you, so to use them As we shall find their merits and our safety May equally determine.
I do serve you in this business.
I do so, I confess it.
I do suffer love indeed, for I love thee against my will.
I do suspect I have done some offense That seems disgracious in the city’s eye, And that you come to reprehend my ignorance.
I do the wrong, and first begin to brawl.
I do think there is mettle in death, which commits some loving act upon her, she hath such a celerity in dying.
I do wander everywhere  Swifter than the moon’s sphere.
I do,  This touches me in reputation.
I do, and surely It is a sleepy language, and thou speak’st Out of thy sleep.
I do, Mark Antony.
I do, truly, for thou swear’st to me thou art honest.
I do.
I do.
I doubt it is no other but the main: His father’s death and our o'erhasty marriage.
I doubt it not, sir, but you will curse your wooing.— Neighbor, this is a gift very grateful, I am sure of it.
I doubt not but his friends will turn to us.
I doubt not of his temperance.
I doubt not of your wisdom.
I doubt not that, since we are well-persuaded We carry not a heart with us from hence That grows not in a fair consent with ours, Nor leave not one behind that doth not wish Success and conquest to attend on us.
I doubt some danger does approach you nearly.
I doubt some foul play.
I dreamt a dream tonight.
I dreamt last night of the three weird sisters: To you they have showed some truth.
I dreamt there was an emperor Antony.
I dreamt tonight that I did feast with Caesar, And things unlucky charge my fantasy.
I drew to part them.
I drink to thee.
I drunk!
I durst have denied that before you were so choleric.
I durst not!
I durst, my lord, to wager she is honest, Lay down my soul at stake.
I eat the air, promise-crammed.
I embrace it.
I fear ’tis choleric.
I fear he will prove the weeping philosopher when he grows old, being so full of unmannerly sadness in his youth.
I fear he will.
I fear I wrong the honorable men Whose daggers have stabbed Caesar.
I fear it is too choleric a meat.
I fear it, I promise you.
I fear me both are false.
I fear me you’ll be in till then.
I fear my Thisbe’s promise is forgot!— And thou, O Wall, O sweet, O lovely Wall, That stand’st between her father’s ground and mine.
I fear no uncles dead.
I fear thee not.
I fear thou wilt once more come again for a ransom.
I fear you have sold your own lands to see other men’s.
I fear your disposition.
I feared he did but trifle And meant to wreck thee.
I feel this pinprick.
I fight against thee?
I find here that Don Pedro hath bestowed much honor on a young Florentine called Claudio.
I find it still, when I have leave to sleep.
I find not Myself disposed to sleep.
I find you passing gentle.
I fly, Biondello.
I follow him to serve my turn upon him.
I forget, But these sweet thoughts do even refresh my labors, Most busiest when I do it.
I forgive you the praise.
I found her trimming up the diadem On her dead mistress.
I found him here as melancholy as a lodge in a warren.
I found him under a tree like a dropped acorn.
I found it in my chamber, And he himself confessed but even now That there he dropped it for a special purpose Which wrought to his desire.
I found it thrown in at the casement of my closet.
I found not Cassio’s kisses on her lips.
I found them on a tree.
I found you as a morsel cold upon Dead Caesar’s trencher.
I frown the while, and perchance wind up watch, or play with my—some rich jewel.
I frown upon him, yet he loves me still.
I gave him no order.
I gave him the stuff.
I gave my love a ring and made him swear Never to part with it.
I gave thee mine before thou didst request it, And yet I would it were to give again.
I gave you all— And in good time you gave it.
I give away myself for you and dote upon the exchange.

I give it you.

I go, my lord.

I grant him bloody, Luxurious, avaricious, false, deceitful, Sudden, malicious, smacking of every sin That has a name.
I grant I am a woman, but withal A woman that Lord Brutus took to wife.
I grant I am a woman, but withal A woman well-reputed, Cato’s daughter.
I grant indeed it hath not appeared, and your suspicion is not without wit and judgment.
I grant you, friends, if you should fright the ladies out of their wits, they would have no more discretion but to hang us.
I grant you.
I greet thy love Not with vain thanks but with acceptance bounteous, And will upon the instant put thee to ’t.
I guess at it.
I had a pass with him, rapier, scabbard, and all, and he gives me the stuck-in with such a mortal motion, that it is inevitable.
I had a Richard too, and thou did’st kill him; I had a Rutland too; thou holp’st to kill him.
I had a son, Now outlawed from my blood.
I had a wound here that was like a “T,” But now ’tis made an “H.” They do retire.
I had as lief be a Brownist as a politician.
I had as lief be wooed of a snail.
I had as lief have a reed that will do me no service as a partisan I could not heave.
I had as lief have my mistress a jade.
I had as lief thou didst break his neck as his finger.
I had been happy if the general camp, Pioneers and all, had tasted her sweet body, So I had nothing known.
I had else been perfect, Whole as the marble, founded as the rock, As broad and general as the casing air.
I had forgot the reward.
I had forgot—three months.
I had it of him.
I had it of Leah when I was a bachelor.
I had most need of blessing, and “Amen” Stuck in my throat.
I had my father’s signet in my purse, Which was the model of that Danish seal.
I had myself notice of my brother’s purpose herein and have by underhand means labored to dissuade him from it; but he is resolute.
I had rather be a canker in a hedge than a rose in his grace, and it better fits my blood to be disdained of all than to fashion a carriage to rob love from any.
I had rather be a country servant-maid Than a great queen with this condition, To be so baited, scorned, and stormèd at.
I had rather be a dog and bay the moon Than such a Roman.
I had rather be a peddler.
I had rather be a toad And live upon the vapor of a dungeon Than keep a corner in the thing I love For others' uses.
I had rather be any kind o' thing than a fool.
I had rather be married to a death’s-head with a bone in his mouth than to either of these.
I had rather break mine own.
I had rather have a fool to make me merry than experience to make me sad— and to travel for it, too.
I had rather have a handful or two of dried peas.
I had rather have my horse to my mistress.
I had rather have this tongue cut from my mouth Than it should do offence to Michael Cassio.
I had rather hear my dog bark at a crow than a man swear he loves me.
I had rather than forty pound I were at home.
I had rather to adopt a child than get it.— Come hither, Moor.
I had thought t’ have held it poor; but since my lord Is Antony again, I will be Cleopatra.
I hate a drunken rogue.
I hate ingratitude more in a man Than lying, vainness, babbling, drunkenness, Or any taint of vice whose strong corruption Inhabits our frail blood—    O heavens themselves!
I hate it as an unfilled can.
I hate the Moor, And it is thought abroad that ’twixt my sheets He’s done my office.
I hate the word, As I hate hell, all Montagues, and thee.
I have ’t in my nose too.
I have ’t.

I have a daughter—have while she is mine— Who in her duty and obedience, mark, Hath given me this.

I have a daughter.

I have a journey, sir, shortly to go.

I have a pain upon my forehead, here.
I have a reasonable good ear in music.
I have a salt and sorry rheum offends me.
I have a ship Laden with gold.

I have an exposition of sleep come upon me.
I have an humor to knock you indifferently well.
I have an interest in your hearts' proceeding.

I have as much of this in art as you, But yet my nature could not bear it so.
I have been dear to him, lad, some two thousand strong, or so.

I have been up this hour, awake all night.

I have great comfort from this fellow.
I have had four quarrels, and like to have fought one.
I have heard her swear ’t.
I have heard him read many lectures against it, and I thank God I am not a woman, to be touched with so many giddy offenses as he hath generally taxed their whole sex withal.

I have heard my father name him.

I have known when he would have walked ten mile afoot to see a good armor, and now will he lie ten nights awake carving the fashion of a new doublet.
I have known when there was no music with him but the drum and the fife, and now had he rather hear the tabor and the pipe.
I have laid those sheets you bade me on the bed.
I have led you oft; carry me now, good friends, And have my thanks for all.
I have limed her, but it is Jove’s doing, and Jove make me thankful!
I have lived long enough.
I have locked the letter in my closet.
I have looked upon the world for four times seven years, and since I could distinguish betwixt a benefit and an injury I never found man that knew how to love himself.
I have made it for you.
I have made no fault.
I have made strong proof of my constancy, Giving myself a voluntary wound Here in the thigh.
I have many enemies in Orsino’s court, Else would I very shortly see thee there.
I have marked A thousand blushing apparitions To start into her face, a thousand innocent shames In angel whiteness beat away those blushes, And in her eye there hath appeared a fire To burn the errors that these princes hold Against her maiden truth.
I have more care to stay than will to go.
I have more cause.
I have much to do But to go hang my head all at one side And sing it like poor Barbary.
I have myself resolved upon a course Which has no need of you.
I have neither the scholar’s melancholy, which is emulation; nor the musician’s, which is fantastical; nor the courtier’s, which is proud; nor the soldier’s, which is ambitious; nor the lawyer’s, which is politic; nor the lady’s, which is nice; nor the lover’s, which is all these, but it is a melancholy of mine own, compounded of many simples, extracted from many objects, and indeed the sundry contemplation of my travels, in which my often rumination wraps me in a most humorous sadness.
I have no ambition To see a goodlier man.
I have no exquisite reason for ’t, but I have reason good enough.
I have no food for thee.
I have no great devotion to the deed And yet he hath given me satisfying reasons.

I have no long spoon.

I have no way, and therefore want no eyes.

I have none.

I have this present evening from my sister Been well informed of them—and with such cautions That if they come to sojourn at my house I’ll not be there.

I know no ways to mince it in love, but directly to say, “I love you.” Then if you urge me farther than to say, “Do you, in faith?” I wear out my suit.
I know not at whose suit he is arrested well, But he’s in a suit of buff which ’rested him; that can I tell.
I know not by what power I am made bold Nor how it may concern my modesty In such a presence here to plead my thoughts, But I beseech your grace that I may know The worst that may befall me in this case, If I refuse to wed Demetrius.
I know not how to pray your patience, Yet I must speak.
I know not if ’t be true, But I, for mere suspicion in that kind, Will do as if for surety.

I know when one is dead and when one lives.
