I know,” quoth he, “no house, no wife, no mistress.” So that my errand, due unto my tongue, I thank him, I bare home upon my shoulders, For, in conclusion, he did beat me there.
I lay with Cassio lately And, being troubled with a raging tooth, I could not sleep.
I learned it in England where indeed they are most potent in potting.
I leave an arrant knave with your Worship, which I beseech your Worship to correct yourself, for the example of others.
I leave him to your gracious acceptance, whose trial shall better publish his commendation.” You hear the learned Bellario, what he writes.
I leave my duty a little unthought of and speak out of my injury.
I led them on in this distracted fear And left sweet Pyramus translated there.
I left no ring with her.
I like him not, nor stands it safe with us To let his madness range.
I like him very well.
I like it not.
I like not that.
I like the new tire within excellently, if the hair were a thought browner; and your gown’s a most rare fashion, i' faith.
I like the work well.
I like you lads.
I little thought You would have followed.
I long that we were safe and sound aboard.
I long to hear him call the drunkard “husband,” And how my men will stay themselves from laughter When they do homage to this simple peasant.
I long To hear the story of your life, which must Take the ear strangely.
I long to know the truth hereof at large.
I long with all my heart to see the prince.
I look down towards his feet, but that’s a fable.
I looked her in the face, and saw her led Between her brother and Mark Antony.
I looked not for you yet, nor am provided For your fit welcome.
I love her ten times more than e'er I did.
I love thee not, therefore pursue me not.
I love thee not.
I love thee well in that thou lik’st it not.
I love to cope him in these sullen fits, For then he’s full of matter.
I love you the better; the hearers may cry “Amen.” God match me with a good dancer!
I love you with so much of my heart that none is left to protest.
I love your majesty According to my bond, no more nor less.
I loved him, friend— No father his son dearer.
I loved Ophelia.
I loved you ever.
I loved you not.
I made no such report.
I make all use of it, for I use it only.
I make not, but foresee.
I marry her!
I marvel Cambio comes not all this while.
I marvel our mild husband Not met us on the way.
I marvel what kin thou and thy daughters are.
I marvel why I answered not again.
I marvel your ladyship takes delight in such a barren rascal.

I may command where I adore.” Why, she may command me.
I may do that I shall be sorry for.
I may not breathe my censure What he might be.

I may not, madam.
I may say “thrusting” it, For piercing steel and darts envenomèd Shall be as welcome to the ears of Brutus As tidings of this sight.
I may sit in a corner and cry, “Heigh-ho for a husband!” Lady Beatrice, I will get you one.
I mean in singing.
I mean not cuckold mad, But sure he is stark mad.
I mean that my heart unto yours is knit So that but one heart we can make of it.
I mean, an we be in choler, we’ll draw.
I mean, in a sort.
I mean, my head upon your lap?
I mean, she is the list of my voyage.
I mean, sir, for his weapon.
I mean, the Lord Protector.
I mean, the matter that you read, my lord.
I mean, to go, sir, to enter.
I meant plain holy thistle.
I meddle with no tradesman’s matters nor women’s matters, but withal I am indeed, sir, a surgeon to old shoes.
I met her deity Cutting the clouds towards Paphos, and her son Dove-drawn with her.
I met the duke yesterday and had much question with him.
I met the youthful lord at Lawrence' cell, And gave him what becomèd love I might, Not stepping o'er the bounds of modesty.
I met this man with my glove in his cap, and I have been as good as my word.
I might ask you for your commission, but I do take thee, Orlando, for my husband.
I might call him A thing divine, for nothing natural I ever saw so noble.
I might do ’t as well i' th' dark.
I might have saved her.
I muse why she’s at liberty.
I must and will have Katherine to my wife.
I must another way To fetch a ladder, by the which your love Must climb a bird’s nest soon when it is dark.
I must attend mine office, Or would have done ’t myself.
I must attend on Caesar.
I must attend the duke at dinner.
I must away this night toward Padua, And it is meet I presently set forth.
I must be circumstanced.
I must be cruel only to be kind.
I must be gone.
I must be gone.
I must be idle.
I must be laughed at If or for nothing or a little, I Should say myself offended, and with you Chiefly i’ th’ world; more laughed at, that I should Once name you derogately, when to sound your name It not concerned me.
I must be one of these same dumb wise men, For Gratiano never lets me speak.
I must believe my master; else, I promise you, I should be arguing still upon that doubt.
I must catechise you for it, madonna.
I must confess your offer is the best, And, let your father make her the assurance, She is your own; else, you must pardon me.
I must discontinue your company.
I must eat my dinner.
I must embrace thee.
I must employ you in some business Against our nuptial and confer with you Of something nearly that concerns yourselves.
I must fetch his necessaries ashore.
I must go in.

I must go with you to Belmont.
I must have liberty Withal, as large a charter as the wind, To blow on whom I please, for so fools have.
I must hence to wait.
I must leave them and seek some better service.
I must leave you.
I must love you and sue to know you better.
I must needs after him, madam, with my letter.
I must needs report the truth.

I must not say no.
I must obey.
I must Once in a month recount what thou hast been, Which thou forget’st.

I must perforce.

I must take out the work?

I must, she’ll rail in the street else.
I myself could make A chough of as deep chat.
I myself heard the king say he would not be ransomed.
I myself.
I ne'er saw this before.
I need not to be ashamed of your Majesty, praised be God, so long as your Majesty is an honest man.
I neither know it nor can learn of him.
I never can see him but I am heartburned an hour after.
I never did deny it.
I never did her any, to my knowledge.
I never did like molestation view On the enchafèd flood.

I never got him.— Hark, the duke’s trumpets.
I never hated thee.
I never heard a passion so confused, So strange, outrageous, and so variable, As the dog Jew did utter in the streets.
I never heard So musical a discord, such sweet thunder.
I never hurt you.
I never knew woman love man so.
I never looked for better at his hands After he once fell in with Mistress Shore.
I never may believe These antique fables nor these fairy toys.
I never saw a better-fashioned gown, More quaint, more pleasing, nor more commendable.
I never saw a woman, But only Sycorax my dam and she.
I never saw an action of such shame.
I never saw her till this time.
I never saw my father in my life.
I never saw the chain, so help me heaven, And this is false you burden me withal.
I never saw you in my life till now.
I never shall endure her.
I never spake with her in all my life.
I never sued to friend, nor enemy; My tongue could never learn sweet smoothing word.
I never thought him worse.
I never was nor never will be false.
I not doubt He came alive to land.
I noted her not, but I looked on her.
I now perceive it was not altogether your brother’s evil disposition made him seek his death, but a provoking merit set awork by a reprovable badness in himself.
I now repent I told the pursuivant, As too triumphing, how mine enemies Today at Pomfret bloodily were butchered, And I myself secure in grace and favor.
I nursed her daughter that you talked withal.
I oft delivered from his forfeitures Many that have at times made moan to me.
I often came where I did hear of her, but cannot find her.
I once did lend my body for his wealth, Which but for him that had your husband’s ring Had quite miscarried.
I once more take my leave.
I once writ a sonnet in his praise and began thus: “Wonder of nature—”  I have heard a sonnet begin so to one’s mistress.
I one, my lord.
I only speak right on.
I overheard him and his practices.
I owe you much, and, like a willful youth, That which I owe is lost.

I partly feel thee.
I partly guess, for I have loved ere now.
I partly know the man.
I passed, methought, the melancholy flood, With that sour ferryman which poets write of, Unto the kingdom of perpetual night.
I pause for a reply.
I perceive these lords At this encounter do so much admire That they devour their reason and scarce think Their eyes do offices of truth, their words Are natural breath.—But howsoev'r you have Been justled from your senses, know for certain That I am Prospero and that very duke Which was thrust forth of Milan, who most strangely Upon this shore where you were wracked, was landed, To be the lord on ’t.
I peseech you heartily, scurvy, lousy knave, at my desires, and my requests, and my petitions, to eat, look you, this leek.
I pitied thee, Took pains to make thee speak, taught thee each hour One thing or other.

I pity you.
I pray God he be not, I say.

I prithee now, lead the way without any more talking.— Trinculo, the king and all our company else being drowned, we will inherit here.—Here, bear my bottle.—Fellow Trinculo, we’ll fill him by and by again.
I prithee now, ungird thy strangeness and tell me what I shall vent to my lady.

I saw him yesterday”—or “t' other day,” Or then, or then, with such or such—“and, as you say, There was he gaming, there o'ertook in’s rouse, There falling out at tennis,” or, perchance, “I saw him enter such a house of sale”—   Your bait of falsehood takes this carp of truth.
I saw Mark Antony offer him a crown (yet ’twas not a crown neither, ’twas one of these coronets) and, as I told you, he put it by once—but, for all that, to my thinking, he would fain have had it.

I speak but as I find.
I speak but brotherly of him, but should I anatomize him to thee as he is, I must blush and weep, and thou must look pale and wonder.
I speak but in the figures and comparisons of it.
I speak in understanding.
I speak no treason.
I speak not as in absolute fear of you.
I speak not like a dotard nor a fool, As under privilege of age to brag What I have done being young, or what would do Were I not old.
I speak not this that you should bear a good opinion of my knowledge, insomuch I say I know you are.
I speak not to disprove what Brutus spoke, But here I am to speak what I do know.
I speak not yet of proof.
I speak to thee plain soldier.
I speak too loud.— Where’s Malvolio?

I spoke with some of the sailors that escaped the wrack.

I therefore vouch again That with some mixtures powerful o'er the blood Or with some dram, conjured to this effect, He wrought upon her.
I think ’twas Soto that your Honor means.
I think Alexander the Great was born in Macedon.
I think he be angry indeed.
I think he be transformed into a beast, For I can nowhere find him like a man.
I think he bought his doublet in Italy, his round hose in France, his bonnet in Germany, and his behavior everywhere.
I think he brings the money.
I think he only loves the world for him.
I think he thinks upon the savage bull.
I think He told me Paris should have married Juliet.
I think he will carry this island home in his pocket and give it his son for an apple.
I think he will stand very strong with us.
I think he would not wish himself anywhere but where he is.
I think his soul is in hell, madonna.
I think I can discover him, if you please To get good guard and go along with me.
I think I did, sir.
I think I had.
I think I hear them.—Stand, ho!
I think I told your lordship a year since how much I am in the favor of Margaret, the waiting gentlewoman to Hero.
I think it be, sir.
I think it be.
I think it doth.
I think it freely, and betimes in the morning I will beseech the virtuous Desdemona to undertake for me.
I think it is in Macedon where Alexander is porn.
I think it is not meet Mark Antony, so well beloved of Caesar, Should outlive Caesar.
I think it is the weakness of mine eyes That shapes this monstrous apparition.
I think it is.
I think it lacks of twelve.
I think it was to see my mother’s wedding.
I think it well, my lord.
I think nobly of the soul, and no way approve his opinion.
I think not of them.
I think not so, my lord.
I think of as many matters as he, but I give heaven thanks and make no boast of them.
I think our country sinks beneath the yoke.
I think our father will hence tonight.
I think oxen and wainropes cannot hale them together.
I think she’ll sooner prove a soldier.
I think so too.
I think so, Charmian.
I think that one of them is hereabout, And cannot make away.
I think that thou art just and think thou art not.
I think the best grace of wit will shortly turn into silence, and discourse grow commendable in none only but parrots.
I think the duke will not be spoke withal.
I think the policy of that purpose made more in the marriage than the love of the parties.
I think the sun where he was born Drew all such humors from him.
I think the world’s asleep.
I think their inhibition comes by the means of the late innovation.
I think there’s never a man in Christendom Can lesser hide his love or hate than he, For by his face straight shall you know his heart.
I think this tale would win my daughter too.
I think thou art an ass.
I think thou art in mind, and so am I. Nay, master, both in mind and in my shape.
I think thou dost.
I think we are too bold upon your rest.
I think we do know the sweet Roman hand.
I think withal There would be hands uplifted in my right; And here from gracious England have I offer Of goodly thousands.
I think you are all mated or stark mad.
I think you set nothing by a bloody coxcomb.
I this infer: That many things, having full reference To one consent, may work contrariously, As many arrows loosèd several ways Come to one mark, as many ways meet in one town, As many fresh streams meet in one salt sea, As many lines close in the dial’s center, So may a thousand actions, once afoot, End in one purpose, and be all well borne Without defeat.
I thought all for the best.
I thought so then, I’ll kill myself for grief.
I thought that all things had been savage here, And therefore put I on the countenance Of stern commandment.
I thought the king had more affected the Duke of Albany than Cornwall.
I thought thou hadst been resolute.
I thought thy heart had been wounded with the claws of a lion.
I to the world am like a drop of water That in the ocean seeks another drop, Who, falling there to find his fellow forth, Unseen, inquisitive, confounds himself.
I told him that your father was at Venice, And that you looked for him this day in Padua.
I told him what I thought, and told no more Than what he found himself was apt and true.
I told him you were asleep.
I told him you were sick.
I told you, sir, they were red-hot with drinking, So full of valor that they smote the air For breathing in their faces, beat the ground For kissing of their feet—yet always bending Towards their project.
I took him sleeping—that is finished too— And the Athenian woman by his side, That, when he waked, of force she must be eyed.
I took no more pains for those thanks than you take pains to thank me.
I took no more pains for those thanks than you took pains to thank me.” That’s as much as to say, “Any pains that I take for you is as easy as thanks.” If I do not take pity of her, I am a villain.
I trouble thee too much, but thou art willing.

I understand thee not.
I urge this childhood proof Because what follows is pure innocence.

I was a fine fool to take it.

I was of late as petty to his ends As is the morn-dew on the myrtle leaf To his grand sea.
I was provokèd by her sland'rous tongue, That laid their guilt upon my guiltless shoulders.
I was sure your lordship did not give it me.
I was the man i' the moon when time was.
I was the more deceived.
I was the other day talking on the sea-bank with certain Venetians, and thither comes the bauble and, by this hand, she falls me thus about my neck— Crying “O dear Cassio!” as it were.
I was told that by one that knows him better than you.
I was too young that time to value her, But now I know her.
I was with Hercules and Cadmus once, When in a wood of Crete they bayed the bear With hounds of Sparta.
I was, but I do find more pain in banishment Than death can yield me here by my abode.
I wear it for a memorable honor, For I am Welsh, you know, good countryman.
I weigh it lightly, were it heavier.

I will answer you with gait and entrance.
I will ask him for my place again, he shall tell me I am a drunkard.
I will assume thy part in some disguise And tell fair Hero I am Claudio, And in her bosom I’ll unclasp my heart And take her hearing prisoner with the force And strong encounter of my amorous tale.
I will bandy with thee in faction.
I will be angry.
I will be bitter with him and passing short.
I will be brief, for my short date of breath Is not so long as is a tedious tale.
I will be correspondent to command And do my spiriting gently.
I will be deaf to pleading and excuses.
I will be faithful.
I will be flesh and blood, For there was never yet philosopher That could endure the toothache patiently, However they have writ the style of gods And made a push at chance and sufferance.
I will be free from thee.
I will be gone, sir, and not trouble you.
I will be hanged else!
I will be hanged, if some eternal villain, Some busy and insinuating rogue, Some cogging, cozening slave, to get some office, Have not devised this slander.
I will be heard.
I will be here again, even with a thought.
I will be mild and gentle in my words.
I will be more jealous of thee than a Barbary cock- pigeon over his hen, more clamorous than a parrot against rain, more newfangled than an ape, more giddy in my desires than a monkey.
I will be near to second your attempt, and he shall fall between us.
I will be proud, I will read politic authors, I will baffle Sir Toby, I will wash off gross acquaintance, I will be point- devise the very man.
I will be satisfied.
I will be strange, stout, in yellow stockings, and cross-gartered, even with the swiftness of putting on.
I will be treble-sinewed, -hearted, -breathed, And fight maliciously.

I will bite my thumb at them, which is a disgrace to them, if they bear it.

I, thus neglecting worldly ends, all dedicated To closeness and the bettering of my mind With that which, but by being so retired, O'erprized all popular rate, in my false brother Awaked an evil nature.

I’ll confine myself no finer than I am.
I’ll court his favors.
I’ll cross it though it blast me.—Stay, illusion!
I’ll devil-porter it no further.
I’ll die for ’t but some woman had the ring.
I’ll do ’t, but it dislikes me.
I’ll do ’t, my lord.
I’ll do ’t.
I’ll do my best To woo your lady— Whoe'er I woo, myself would be his wife.
I’ll do the service of a younger man In all your business and necessities.
I’ll drain him dry as hay.
I’ll drink for you.
I’ll drink to her as long as there is a passage in my throat and drink in Illyria.
I’ll end my exhortation after dinner.
I’ll entreat for thee.
I’ll fetch my sister to get her goodwill.
I’ll fetch some flax and whites of eggs To apply to his bleeding face.
I’ll fetch the general’s surgeon.— Save you your labor.—He that lies slain here, Cassio, Was my dear friend.
I’ll fetch them, sir.
I’ll fight at sea.
I’ll fight till from my bones my flesh be hacked.
I’ll find out your man, And he shall signify from time to time Every good hap to you that chances here.
I’ll find Romeo To comfort you.
I’ll fish for thee and get thee wood enough.
I’ll follow him no more with bootless prayers.
I’ll follow it.
I’ll follow thee and make a heaven of hell, To die upon the hand I love so well.
I’ll follow this good man, and go with you; And, having sworn truth, ever will be true.
I’ll follow you.
I’ll fume with them!” And with that word she struck me on the head, And through the instrument my pate made way,
I’ll get me to a place more void, and there Speak to great Caesar as he comes along.
I’ll give ’t him.
I’ll give you a verse to this note that I made yesterday in despite of my invention.
I’ll go alone.
I’ll go along, no such sight to be shown, But to rejoice in splendor of mine own.
I’ll go and chat with Paris.
I’ll go another way to work with him.
I’ll go arm myself.
I’ll go farther off.
I’ll go find a shadow and sigh till he come.
I’ll go with you.
I’ll grow a talker for this gear.
I’ll halt after.
I’ll have an action of battery against him if there be any law in Illyria.
I’ll have grounds More relative than this.
I’ll have her, but I will not keep her long.
I’ll have my bond, and therefore speak no more.
I’ll have my bond.
I’ll have no bigger.
I’ll have no halves.
I’ll have no speaking.
I’ll have no worse a name than Jove’s own page, And therefore look you call me Ganymede.
I’ll have some proof.
I’ll have the work ta'en out And give ’t Iago.
I’ll have them sleep on cushions in my tent.
I’ll have this crown of mine cut from my shoulders Before I’ll see the crown so foul misplaced.
I’ll have this knot knit up tomorrow morning.
I’ll help you to a horse.
I’ll help you, Sir Toby, because we’ll be dressed together.
I’ll hold my mind were she an Ethiope.
I’ll humbly signify what in his name, That magical word of war, we have effected: How with his banners and his well-paid ranks The ne’er-yet-beaten horse of Parthia We have jaded out o’ th’ field.
I’ll in to counsel them.
I’ll join with black despair against my soul And to myself become an enemy.

I’ll know his humor when he knows his time.

I’ll make one too.

I’ll ride your horse as well as I ride you.

I’ll tell thee, Charles: it is the stubbornest young fellow of France, full of ambition, an envious emulator of every man’s good parts, a secret and villainous contriver against me his natural brother.
I’ll tell thee, friend, I am almost mad myself.
I’ll tell you in your ear.

If a Christian do not play the knave and get thee, I am much deceived.
If a Jew wrong a Christian, what is his humility?

If a man’s brains were in ’s heels, were ’t not in danger of kibes?
If all else fail, myself have power to die.
If all the devils of hell be drawn in little, and Legion himself possessed him, yet I’ll speak to him.
If all the wine in my bottle will recover him, I will help his ague.

If any be Trinculo’s legs, these are they.
If any man doubt that, let him put me to my purgation.
If any ship put out, then straight away.
If any such there be, heaven pardon him!
If any, speak—for him have I offended.
If any, speak—for him have I offended.

If by your art, my dearest father, you have Put the wild waters in this roar, allay them.
If Caesar had stabbed their mothers they would have done no less.
If Caesar please, our master Will leap to be his friend.
If Cleopatra heard you, your reproof Were well deserved of rashness.
If consequence do but approve my dream My boat sails freely, both with wind and stream.
If die, be brief, That our swift-wingèd souls may catch the king’s, Or, like obedient subjects, follow him To his new kingdom of ne'er-changing night.
If e'er thou wast thyself and these woes thine, Thou and these woes were all for Rosaline.
If Echo were as fleet, I would esteem him worth a dozen such.
If either of you know any inward impediment why you should not be conjoined, charge you on your souls to utter it.
If ever he go alone again, I’ll never wrestle for prize more.
If ever he have wife, let her be made More miserable by the death of him Than I am made by my poor lord and thee.— Come now towards Chertsey with your holy load, Taken from Paul’s to be interrèd there.
If ever I live to see it, I will challenge it.
If ever I return to you again, I’ll bring you comfort.
If ever thou come to me and say, after tomorrow, “This is my glove,” by this hand I will take thee a box on the ear.
If ever thou wilt thrive, bury my body.
If every of your wishes had a womb, And fertile every wish, a million.
If every one knows us, and we know none, 'Tis time, I think, to trudge, pack, and be gone.
If fortune be not ours today, it is Because we brave her.
If from the field I shall return once more To kiss these lips, I will appear in blood.
If God will be avengèd for this deed, O, know you yet He doth it publicly!
If good, thou shamest the music of sweet news By playing it to me with so sour a face.
If Hamlet give the first or second hit Or quit in answer of the third exchange, Let all the battlements their ordnance fire!
If haply you my father do suspect An instrument of this your calling back, Lay not your blame on me.
If he ask for me, I am ill and gone to bed.
If he awake, From toe to crown he’ll fill our skins with pinches, Make us strange stuff.
If he be absent, bring his brother to me.
If he be leaden, icy, cold, unwilling, Be thou so too, and so break off the talk, And give us notice of his inclination; For we tomorrow hold divided councils, Wherein thyself shalt highly be employed.
If he be not in love with some woman, there is no believing old signs.

If he be sad, he wants money.
If he be so resolved, I can o'ersway him.
If he be taken, he shall never more Be feared of doing harm.
If he be, he knows how to turn his girdle.
If he break the peace, he ought to enter into a quarrel with fear and trembling.
If he cannot, let the botcher mend him.
If he come not, then the play is marred.
If he come tomorrow, I’ll give him his payment.
If he could right himself with quarreling, Some of us would lie low.
If he distaste it, let him to our sister, Whose mind and mine I know in that are one, Not to be overruled.
If he do bleed, I’ll gild the faces of the grooms withal, For it must seem their guilt.
If he do blench, I know my course.
If he do fear God, he must necessarily keep peace.
If he do resist, Subdue him at his peril!
If he do, sure he cannot weep ’t back again.
If he fail of that, He will have other means to cut you off.
If he filled His vacancy with his voluptuousness, Full surfeits and the dryness of his bones Call on him for ’t.
If he have caught the Benedick, it will cost him a thousand pound ere a be cured.
If he have never drunk wine afore, it will go near to remove his fit.
If he have the condition of a saint and the complexion of a devil, I had rather he should shrive me than wive me.
If he love Caesar, all that he can do Is to himself: take thought and die for Caesar.
If he may be conveniently delivered, I would he were, for I am now so far in offense with my niece that I cannot pursue with any safety this sport to the upshot.
If he please To give me conquered Egypt for my son, He gives me so much of mine own as I Will kneel to him with thanks.
If he say so, may his pernicious soul Rot half a grain a day!
If he were dead, what would betide on me?
If he were dead, you’d weep for him.
If he will not stand when he is bidden, he is none of the Prince’s subjects.
If he will take it, so.
If he, compact of jars, grow musical, We shall have shortly discord in the spheres.
If her breath were as terrible as her terminations, there were no living near her; she would infect to the north star.
If his cause be wrong, our obedience to the king wipes the crime of it out of us.
If his fitness speaks, mine is ready, now or whensoever, provided I be so able as now.
If I be waspish, best beware my sting.
If I can cross him any way, I bless myself every way.
If I can fasten but one cup upon him, With that which he hath drunk tonight already, He’ll be as full of quarrel and offense As my young mistress' dog.
If I can recover him and keep him tame and get to Naples with him, he’s a present for any emperor that ever trod on neat’s leather.
If I can recover him and keep him tame, I will not take too much for him.
If I could add a lie unto a fault I would deny it.
If I could bid the fifth welcome with so good a heart as I can bid the other four farewell, I should be glad of his approach.
If I could make that resemble something in me—Softly!
If I could pray to move, prayers would move me.

If I do live, I will be good to thee.

If I do not usurp myself, I am.
If I do prove her haggard, Though that her jesses were my dear heartstrings, I’d whistle her off and let her down the wind To prey at fortune.

If I dream not, thou art Emilia.

If I let him go, The debt he owes will be required of me.
If I live to see it, I will never trust his word after.
If I lose a scruple of this sport, let me be boiled to death with melancholy.
If I may trust the flattering truth of sleep, My dreams presage some joyful news at hand.
If I myself, there is no hour so fit As Caesar’s death’s hour, nor no instrument Of half that worth as those your swords, made rich With the most noble blood of all this world.
If I owe you anything, I will pay you in cudgels.

If I should be?

If it pass against us, We lose the better half of our possession, For all the temporal lands which men devout By testament have given to the Church Would they strip from us, being valued thus: “As much as would maintain, to the King’s honor, Full fifteen earls and fifteen hundred knights, Six thousand and two hundred good esquires; And, to relief of lazars and weak age Of indigent faint souls past corporal toil, A hundred almshouses right well supplied; And to the coffers of the King besides, A thousand pounds by th' year.” Thus runs the bill.

If she be a traitor, Why so am I.

If she convey Letters to Richmond, you shall answer it.
If she deny to wed, I’ll crave the day When I shall ask the banns and when be marrièd.
If she do bid me pack, I’ll give her thanks, As though she bid me stay by her a week.
If she do, he’ll smile and take ’t for a great favor.
If she find him not, To England send him or confine him where Your wisdom best shall think.
If she had been blessed, she would never have loved the Moor.
If she live long, And in the end meet the old course of death, Women will all turn monsters.
If she lives till doomsday, she’ll burn a week longer than the whole world.
If she should make tender of her love, ’tis very possible he’ll scorn it, for the man, as you know all, hath a contemptible spirit.
If she sustain him and his hundred knights When I have showed th' unfitness— Here, madam.
If she will return me my jewels I will give over my suit and repent my unlawful solicitation.
If she will stir hither, I shall seem to notify unto her.
If sight and shape be true, Why then, my love adieu.

If so, my eyes are oftener washed than hers.
If so, then be not tongue-tied.
If such a one be fit to govern, speak.

If th' other two be brained like us, the state totters.
If that be all, masters, I hear no harm.
If that be to care for nothing, sir, I would it would make you invisible.

If that may be then all is well.
If that same demon that hath gulled thee thus Should with his lion gait walk the whole world, He might return to vasty Tartar back And tell the legions “I can never win A soul so easy as that Englishman’s.” Oh, how hast thou with jealousy infected The sweetness of affiance!
If that the Turkish fleet Be not ensheltered and embayed, they are drowned.
If that this simple syllogism will serve, so.
If that thou be’st a devil, I cannot kill thee.
If that will not suffice, I will be bound to pay it ten times o'er, On forfeit of my hands, my head, my heart.
If that you were the good Sir Rowland’s son, As you have whispered faithfully you were, And as mine eye doth his effigies witness Most truly limned and living in your face, Be truly welcome hither.

If the cat will after kind, So, be sure, will Rosalind.

If the English had any apprehension, they would run away.
If the heavens had been pleased, would we had so ended!
If the ill spirit have so fair a house, Good things will strive to dwell with ’t.
If the matter of this paper be certain, you have mighty business in hand.
If the matter were good, my lord, I durst swear it were his.
If the Prince be too important, tell him there is measure in everything, and so dance out the answer.
If their purgation did consist in words, They are as innocent as grace itself.
If then that friend demand why Brutus rose against Caesar, this is my answer: not that I loved Caesar less, but that I loved Rome more.
If then they chanced to slack you, We could control them.
If then true lovers have been ever crossed, It stands as an edict in destiny.
If there be any good thing to be done That may to thee do ease and grace to me, Speak to me.
If there be any impediment, I pray you discover it.
If there be any in this assembly, any dear friend of Caesar’s, to him I say that Brutus' love to Caesar was no less than his.
If there be more, more woeful, hold it in.
If there be truth in sight, you are my daughter.
If there be truth in sight, you are my Rosalind.
If there come truth from them— As upon thee, Macbeth, their speeches shine— Why, by the verities on thee made good, May they not be my oracles as well, And set me up in hope?
If there were no more women but Fulvia, then had you indeed a cut, and the case to be lamented.
If they deny to come, Swinge me them soundly forth unto their husbands.
If they do see thee they will murder thee.
If they do this, As, if God please, they shall, my ransom then Will soon be levied.
If they have done this deed, my noble lord— If?
If they make you not then the better answer, you may say they are not the men you took them for.
If they speak but truth of her, These hands shall tear her; if they wrong her honor, The proudest of them shall well hear of it.
If they suffer our departure, death’s the word.
If they will fight with us, bid them come down, Or void the field.
If they’ll do neither, we will come to them And make them skirr away as swift as stones Enforcèd from the old Assyrian slings.
If this be known, Cassius or Caesar never shall turn back, For I will slay myself.
If this be not that you look for, I have no more to say, But bid Bianca farewell forever and a day.
If this be so, why blame you me to love you?
If this be so, why blame you me to love you?
If this fall into thy hand, revolve.
If this letter move him not, his legs cannot.
If this prove A vision of the Island, one dear son Shall I twice lose.
If this uncouth forest yield anything savage, I will either be food for it or bring it for food to thee.
If this were played upon a stage now, I could condemn it as an improbable fiction.
If this were true, then should I know this secret.
If this young gentleman Have done offence, I take the fault on me.
If thou account’st it shame, lay it on me, And therefore frolic!
If thou and nature can so gently part, The stroke of death is as a lover’s pinch, Which hurts, and is desired.
If thou art she, tell me where is that son That floated with thee on the fatal raft?
If thou ask me why, sufficeth my reasons are both good and weighty.
If thou beest as poor for a subject as he’s for a king, thou'rt poor enough.
If thou beest not immortal, look about you.
If thou beest Stephano, touch me and speak to me.
If thou beest Trinculo, come forth.
If thou canst love a fellow of this temper, Kate, whose face is not worth sunburning, that never looks in his glass for love of anything he sees there, let thine eye be thy cook.
If thou canst love me for this, take me.
If thou consider rightly of the matter, Caesar has had great wrong.
If thou darest tempt me further, draw thy sword.
If thou delight to view thy heinous deeds, Behold this pattern of thy butcheries.
If thou didst ever hold me in thy heart Absent thee from felicity a while, And in this harsh world draw thy breath in pain To tell my story.
If thou didst ever thy dear father love— O God!
If thou didst it, thou art the nonpareil.
If thou dost find him tractable to us, Encourage him and show him all our reasons.
If thou dost I shall never love thee after.
If thou dost love fair Hero, cherish it, And I will break with her and with her father, And thou shalt have her.
If thou dost love me Show me thy thought.
If thou dost play with him at any game, Thou art sure to lose, and of that natural luck He beats thee ’gainst the odds.
If thou doubt it, thou mayst slide from my shoulder to my heel with no greater a run but my head and my neck.
If thou entertainest my love, let it appear in thy smiling.
If thou follow him, thou must needs wear my coxcomb.—How now, nuncle?
If thou hadst feared to break an oath by Him, Th' imperial metal circling now thy head Had graced the tender temples of my child, And both the princes had been breathing here, Which now, two tender bedfellows for dust, Thy broken faith hath made the prey for worms.
If thou hast any sound or use of voice, Speak to me.
If thou hast her not i' the end, call me “Cut.”  If I do not, never trust me, take it how you will.
If thou hast nature in thee, bear it not.
If thou hast slain Lysander in his sleep, Being o'er shoes in blood, plunge in the deep, And kill me too.
If thou kill’st me, boy, thou shalt kill a man.
If thou more murmur’st, I will rend an oak And peg thee in his knotty entrails till Thou hast howled away twelve winters.
If thou pleasest not, I yield thee up my life.
If thou read this, O Caesar, thou mayst live.
If thou rememb’rest not the slightest folly That ever love did make thee run into, Thou hast not loved.
If thou rememberest aught ere thou camest here, How thou camest here thou mayst.
If thou say so, villain, Thou kill’st thy mistress.
If thou say so, withdraw and prove it too.
If thou speak’st false, Upon the next tree shall thou hang alive Till famine cling thee.
If thou takest more Or less than a just pound, be it but so much As makes it light or heavy in the substance Or the division of the twentieth part Of one poor scruple—nay, if the scale do turn But in the estimation of a hair, Thou diest and all thy goods are confiscate.
If thou the next night following enjoy not Desdemona, take me from this world with treachery and devise engines for my life.
If thou wert my fool, nuncle, I’d have thee beaten for being old before thy time.
If thou wilt lend this money, lend it not As to thy friends, for when did friendship take A breed for barren metal of his friend?
If thou wilt needs damn thyself, do it a more delicate way than drowning.
If thou wilt weep my fortunes, take my eyes.
If thou would have such a one, take me.
If thus thou vanishest, thou tell’st the world It is not worth leave-taking.
If thy greatness will Revenge it on him—for I know thou darest, But this thing dare not— That’s most certain.
If thy revengeful heart cannot forgive, Lo, here I lend thee this sharp-pointed sword, Which if thou please to hide in this true breast And let the soul forth that adoreth thee, I lay it naked to the deadly stroke And humbly beg the death upon my knee.
If thy speech be sooth, I care not if thou dost for me as much.
If till the expiration of your month, You will return and sojourn with my sister, Dismissing half your train, come then to me.
If to have done the thing you gave in charge Beget your happiness, be happy then, For it is done.
If trembling I inhabit then, protest me The baby of a girl.
If we are like you in the rest, we will resemble you in that.
If we are marked to die, we are enough To do our country loss; and if to live, The fewer men, the greater share of honor.
If we be not relieved within this hour, We must return to th’ court of guard.
If we do lose this battle, then is this The very last time we shall speak together.
If we do meet again, we’ll smile indeed.
If we do meet again, why, we shall smile.
If we grow all to be pork-eaters, we shall not shortly have a rasher on the coals for money.
If we know him to be a thief, shall we not lay hands on him?
If we offend, it is with our good will.
If we walk not in the trodden paths our very petticoats will catch them.
If we, with thrice such powers left at home, Cannot defend our own doors from the dog, Let us be worried, and our nation lose The name of hardiness and policy.
If what he might he is not, I would to heaven he were!
If with myself I hold intelligence Or have acquaintance with mine own desires, If that I do not dream or be not frantic— As I do trust I am not—then, dear uncle, Never so much as in a thought unborn Did I offend your Highness.
If without peril it be possible, Sweet Blunt, make some good means to speak with him, And give him from me this most needful note.
If wolves had at thy gate howled that stern time, Thou shouldst have said, “Good porter, turn the key,” All cruèls else subscribed.
If you are so fond over her iniquity, give her patent to offend, for if it touch not you it comes near nobody.
If you be gentlemen, Do me this right: hear me with patience.
If you be not mad, be gone.
If you be pleased, retire into my cell And there repose.

If you call me Jephthah, my lord, I have a daughter that I love passing well.
If you can separate yourself and your misdemeanors, you are welcome to the house.
If you can, your reason?
If you cannot, give thanks you have lived so long and make yourself ready in your cabin for the mischance of the hour, if it so hap.—Cheerly, good hearts!—Out of our way, I say.
If you choose that wherein I am contained, Straight shall our nuptial rites be solemnized.
If you choose that, then I am yours withal.
If you come slack of former services, You shall do well.
If you dare fight today, come to the field.
If you deny it, let the danger light Upon your charter and your city’s freedom.
If you deny me, fie upon your law— There is no force in the decrees of Venice.
If you deny them, all the land will rue it.
If you desire the spleen, and will laugh yourself into stitches, follow me.
If you did wear a beard upon your chin, I’d shake it on this quarrel.
If you did wed my sister for her wealth, Then for her wealth’s sake use her with more kindness.
If you do fight against your country’s foes, Your country’s fat shall pay your pains the hire.
If you do fight in safeguard of your wives, Your wives shall welcome home the conquerors.
If you do free your children from the sword, Your children’s children quits it in your age.
If you do love me you will find me out.— Nerissa and the rest, stand all aloof.
If you do love Rosalind so near the heart as your gesture cries it out, when your brother marries Aliena shall you marry her.
If you do meet Horatio and Marcellus, The rivals of my watch, bid them make haste.
If you do not, if I be left alone, Now, by mine honor—which is yet mine own— I’ll have that doctor for my bedfellow.
If you do sorrow at my grief in love, By giving love your sorrow and my grief Were both extermined.
If you do stir abroad, go armed.
If you do sweat to put a tyrant down, You sleep in peace, the tyrant being slain.
If you go on thus, you will kill yourself, And ’tis not wisdom thus to second grief Against yourself.
If you grow foul with me, Pistol, I will scour you with my rapier, as I may, in fair terms.
If you had known the virtue of the ring, Or half her worthiness that gave the ring, Or your own honor to contain the ring, You would not then have parted with the ring.
If you have any music that may not be heard, to ’t again.
If you have any pity, grace, or manners, You would not make me such an argument.
If you have lost him, Why, I have lost him too.
If you have poison for me, I will drink it.
If you have tears, prepare to shed them now.
If you knew my business, You would entreat me rather go than stay.
If you like upon report The soil, the profit, and this kind of life, I will your very faithful feeder be And buy it with your gold right suddenly.
If you love her then, tomorrow wed her.
If you mark Alexander’s life well, Harry of Monmouth’s life is come after it indifferent well, for there is figures in all things.

If you offend him, I for him defy you.

If your Majesties is remembered of it, the Welshmen did good service in a garden where leeks did grow, wearing leeks in their Monmouth caps, which, your Majesty know, to this hour is an honorable badge of the service.
If your master Would have a queen his beggar, you must tell him, That majesty, to keep decorum, must No less beg than a kingdom.
If, Duke of Burgundy, you would the peace, Whose want gives growth to th' imperfections Which you have cited, you must buy that peace With full accord to all our just demands, Whose tenors and particular effects You have, enscheduled briefly, in your hands.

In the most high and palmy state of Rome, A little ere the mightiest Julius fell, The graves stood tenantless and the sheeted dead Did squeak and gibber in the Roman streets As stars with trains of fire and dews of blood, Disasters in the sun, and the moist star Upon whose influence Neptune’s empire stands Was sick almost to doomsday with eclipse.

Invoke his warlike spirit And your great-uncle’s, Edward the Black Prince, Who on the French ground played a tragedy, Making defeat on the full power of France Whiles his most mighty father on a hill Stood smiling to behold his lion’s whelp Forage in blood of French nobility.

Let but the commons hear this testament— Which, pardon me, I do not mean to read— And they would go and kiss dead Caesar’s wounds And dip their napkins in his sacred blood, Yea, beg a hair of him for memory, And, dying, mention it within their wills, Bequeathing it as a rich legacy Unto their issue.
Let copulation thrive, for Gloucester’s bastard son Was kinder to his father than my daughters got ’tween the lawful sheets.
Let each man render me his bloody hand.
Let every eye nogetiate for itself And trust no agent, for beauty is a witch Against whose charms faith melteth into blood.
Let every man be master of his time Till seven at night.
Let every soldier hew him down a bough And bear ’t before him.
Let fall thy blade on vulnerable crests; I bear a charmèd life, which must not yield To one of woman born.
Let floods o'erswell and fiends for food howl on!
Let four captains Bear Hamlet like a soldier to the stage, For he was likely, had he been put on, To have proved most royally.

Let go!

Like one of two contending in a prize That thinks he hath done well in people’s eyes, Hearing applause and universal shout, Giddy in spirit, still gazing in a doubt Whether these pearls of praise be his or no— So, thrice fair lady, stand I even so, As doubtful whether what I see be true Until confirmed, signed, ratified by you.

Love cools, friendship falls off, brothers divide, in cities
Love give me strength, and strength shall help afford.
Love is merely a madness and, I tell you, deserves as well a dark house and a whip as madmen do, and the reason why they are not so punished and cured is that the lunacy is so ordinary that the whippers are in love, too.
Love looks not with the eyes but with the mind.
Love me or love me not, I like the cap, And it I will have, or I will have none.
Love news, in faith?
Love wrought these miracles.
Love, and be friends as two such men should be.
Love, therefore, and tongue-tied simplicity In least speak most, to my capacity.
Love?
Love’s heralds should be thoughts, Which ten times faster glide than the sun’s beams, Driving back shadows over louring hills.
Love’s not love When it is mingled with regards that stands Aloof from th' entire point.
Lovers can see to do their amorous rites By their own beauties, or, if love be blind, It best agrees with night.

Make those that do offend you suffer too.
Make thy two eyes, like stars, start from their spheres, Thy knotted and combinèd locks to part And each particular hair to stand on end, Like quills upon the fearful porpentine.

Make we our march towards Birnam.

Malcolm and Donalbain, the king’s two sons, Are stol'n away and fled, which puts upon them Suspicion of the deed.

Many a man his life hath sold But my outside to behold.
Many a man would take you at your word And go indeed, having so good a mean.
Many a morning hath he there been seen, With tears augmenting the fresh morning’s dew, Adding to clouds more clouds with his deep sighs.
Many good morrows to my noble lord.
Many hot inroads They make in Italy—the borders maritime Lack blood to think on ’t—and flush youth revolt.
Many times, madam.
Many will swoon when they do look on blood.
March gently on to meet him.
March on, march on, since we are up in arms, If not to fight with foreign enemies, Yet to beat down these rebels here at home.
March to the bridge.
Marcus Luccicos, is not he in town?
Marcus Octavius, Marcus Justeius, Publicola, and Caelius, are for sea; But we keep whole by land.
Maria once told me she did affect me, and I have heard herself come thus near, that, should she fancy, it should be one of my complexion.
Marian, I say!
Mark Antony I served, who best was worthy Best to be served.
Mark Antony In Egypt sits at dinner, and will make No wars without doors.
Mark Antony is in your tents, my lord.
Mark Antony shall say I am not well, And for thy humor I will stay at home.
Mark Antony— Pardon me, Caius Cassius.
Mark Antony, here, take you Caesar’s body.
Mark Antony, shall we give sign of battle?
Mark him.
Mark his condition and the event.
Mark how he trembles in his ecstasy.
Mark how the tyrant writes.
Mark it, nuncle.
Mark me.
Mark me.
Mark the music.
Mark well Metellus Cimber.
Mark, I say, instantly, and carry it so As I have set it down.
Mark, King of Scotland, mark: No sooner justice had, with valor armed, Compelled these skipping kerns to trust their heels, But the Norweyan lord, surveying vantage, With furbished arms and new supplies of men, Began a fresh assault.
Marked you not How that the guilty kindred of the queen Looked pale when they did hear of Clarence' death?
Marry them to your heirs!
Marry, ’tis enough.
Marry, and did.
Marry, and it shall be done tomorrow morning if I live.
Marry, as for Clarence, he is well repaid; He is franked up to fatting for his pains.
Marry, at the very next turning turn of no hand, but turn down indirectly to the Jew’s house.
Marry, before he fell down, when he perceived the common herd was glad he refused the crown, he plucked me ope his doublet and offered them his throat to cut.
Marry, before your ladyship, I grant, She puts her tongue a little in her heart And chides with thinking.
Marry, beshrew my hand If it should give your age such cause of fear.
Marry, come up, I trow.
Marry, do I, sir, and I came to acquaint you with a matter.
Marry, for my part, I think the duke hath lost never a man, but one that is like to be executed for robbing a church, one Bardolph, if your Majesty know the man.
Marry, God defend his grace should say us nay!
Marry, God forbid!
Marry, he told me so himself; and he said he cared not who knew it.
Marry, heaven forbid!
Marry, heaven forbid!
Marry, here’s grace and a codpiece—that’s a wise man and a fool.
Marry, I fare well, For here is cheer enough.
Marry, I remember it well.
Marry, I saw your niece do more favors to the Count’s servingman than ever she bestowed upon me.
Marry, I will, and this is wisely done.
Marry, I would not do such a thing for a joint-ring, nor for measures of lawn, nor for gowns, petticoats, nor caps, nor any petty exhibition.
Marry, I’ll teach you.
Marry, if he that writ it had played Pyramus and hanged himself in Thisbe’s garter, it would have been a fine tragedy.
Marry, it is your brother’s right hand.
Marry, my child, early next Thursday morn, The gallant, young, and noble gentleman, The County Paris, at Saint Peter’s Church, Shall happily make thee there a joyful bride.
Marry, my uncle Clarence' angry ghost.
Marry, now I can tell.
Marry, now I let go your hand, I am barren.
Marry, on Hero, the daughter and heir of Leonato.
Marry, once before he won it of me with false dice.
Marry, patience, Or I shall say you are all in all in spleen, And nothing of a man.
Marry, peace it bodes, and love, and quiet life, And awful rule, and right supremacy, And, to be short, what not that’s sweet and happy?
Marry, sir, be better employed, and be naught awhile.
Marry, sir, because silver hath a sweet sound.
Marry, sir, by a rule as plain as the plain bald pate of Father Time himself.
Marry, sir, for this something that you gave me for nothing.
Marry, sir, in her buttocks.
Marry, sir, lullaby to your bounty till I come again.
Marry, sir, she’s the kitchen wench, and all grease, and I know not what use to put her to but to make a lamp of her and run from her by her own light.
Marry, sir, they have committed false report; moreover, they have spoken untruths; secondarily, they are slanders; sixth and lastly, they have belied a lady; thirdly, they have verified unjust things; and, to conclude, they are lying knaves.
Marry, sir, they praise me and make an ass of me, now my foes tell me plainly I am an ass.
Marry, sir, to bid my old master the Jew to sup tonight with my new master the Christian.
Marry, sir, to get a husband for her sister.
Marry, sir, we say we are none.
Marry, sir, with needle and thread.
Marry, th' athversary was have possession of the pridge, but he is enforced to retire, and the duke of Exeter is master of the pridge.
Marry, that am I and my partner.
Marry, that can Hero!
Marry, that he had received a thousand ducats of Don John for accusing the Lady Hero wrongfully.
Marry, that should you if I were your mistress, or I should think my honesty ranker than my wit.
Marry, that, I think, be young Petruchio.
Marry, they say my uncle grew so fast That he could gnaw a crust at two hours old.
Marry, this is miching
Marry, this it is, sir.
Marry, thou dost wrong me, thou dissembler, thou.
Marry, we were sent for to the justices.
Marry, well remembered.
Marry, well said, very well said.
Marry, will I, sir.
Marry, you may partly hope that your father got you not, that you are not the Jew’s daughter.
Marry, your manhood, mew!
Mars’s hot minion is returned again.
Marvelous sweet music!
Mass, and my elbow itched, I thought there would a scab follow.
Mass, and well said.

May ’t please your highness sit.
May ’t please your Majesty to give us leave Freely to render what we have in charge, Or shall we sparingly show you far off The Dauphin’s meaning and our embassy?
May a man do it?
May be she doth but counterfeit.

May I know?

Maybe the letter moved him, For, as I think, they do command him home, Deputing Cassio in his government.
Me believe it?
Me they shall feel while I am able to stand, and ’tis known I am a pretty piece of flesh.
Me, a groat?
Me, poor man, my library Was dukedom large enough.
Me, uncle?
Mean you his majesty?
Mean you to enjoy him then?
Meantime forbear, And let mischance be slave to patience.— Bring forth the parties of suspicion.
Meantime God grants that we have need of you.
Meantime I writ to Romeo, That he should hither come as this dire night, To help to take her from her borrowed grave, Being the time the potion’s force should cease.
Meantime we thank you for your well-took labor.
Meantime, but think how I may do thee good, And be inheritor of thy desire.
Meantime, have patience.
Mechanic slaves With greasy aprons, rules, and hammers shall Uplift us to the view.
Meet me and Gratiano At Gratiano’s lodging some hour hence.
Meet me by and by at the citadel.
Meet presently at the palace.
Melt Egypt into Nile, and kindly creatures Turn all to serpents.
Men at some time are masters of their fates.
Men may sleep, and they may have their throats about them at that time, and some say knives have edges.
Men must not walk too late.
Men shall deal unadvisedly sometimes, Which after-hours give leisure to repent.
Men should be what they seem, Or those that be not, would they might seem none!
Men that hazard all Do it in hope of fair advantages.
Men, wives, and children stare, cry out, and run As it were doomsday.
Men’s eyes were made to look and let them gaze.
Menas, I’ll not on shore.
Mend the instance, shepherd.
Mend when thou canst.
Mend your speech a little, Lest you may mar your fortunes.
Mend” me, thou saucy fellow?
Merciful heaven!
Merciful powers, Restrain in me the cursèd thoughts that nature Gives way to in repose.
Mercutio, thou consort’st with Romeo.
Mercutio’s kinsman, noble County Paris.
Mercy but murders, pardoning those that kill.
Mercy, mercy!
Mere prattle without practice Is all his soldiership.
Meseemeth good that with some little train Forthwith from Ludlow the young prince be fet Hither to London, to be crowned our king.
Messala, I have here receivèd letters That young Octavius and Mark Antony Come down upon us with a mighty power, Bending their expedition toward Philippi.
Messala, This is my birthday, as this very day Was Cassius born.
Messala!
Metellus Cimber?
Methinks he looks as though he were in love.
Methinks his words do from such passion fly, That he believes himself.
Methinks I could not die anywhere so contented as in the king’s company, his cause being just and his quarrel honorable.
Methinks I do.
Methinks I have a great desire to a bottle of hay.
Methinks I hear Antony call.
Methinks I see my cousin’s ghost Seeking out Romeo, that did spit his body Upon a rapier’s point.
Methinks I see thee now, thou art so low As one dead in the bottom of a tomb.
Methinks I should know you, and know this man.
Methinks it is like a weasel.
Methinks our garments are now as fresh as when we put them on first in Afric, at the marriage of the king’s fair daughter Claribel to the King of Tunis.
Methinks she should not use a long one for such a Pyramus.
Methinks sometimes I have no more wit than a Christian or an ordinary man has.
Methinks the ground is even.
Methinks the wind hath spoke aloud at land, A fuller blast ne'er shook our battlements.
Methinks they are such a gentle nation that, but for the mountain of mad flesh
Methinks thy voice is altered, and thou speak’st In better phrase and matter than thou didst.
Methinks you are my glass, and not my brother: I see by you I am a sweet-faced youth.
Methinks you are too much of late i' th' frown.
Methinks you’re better spoken.
Methinks your maw, like mine, should be your clock, And strike you home without a messenger.
Methinks, mistress, you should have little reason for that.
Methought I had, and often did I strive To yield the ghost, but still the envious flood Stopped in my soul and would not let it forth To find the empty, vast, and wand'ring air, But smothered it within my panting bulk, Who almost burst to belch it in the sea.
Methought I heard a voice cry, “Sleep no more!
Methought I lay Worse than the mutines in the bilboes.
Methought the billows spoke and told me of it, The winds did sing it to me, and the thunder, That deep and dreadful organ pipe, pronounced The name of Prosper.
Methought their souls whose bodies Richard murdered Came to my tent and cried on victory.
Methoughts I saw a thousand fearful wracks, A thousand men that fishes gnawed upon, Wedges of gold, great anchors, heaps of pearl, Inestimable stones, unvalued jewels, All scattered in the bottom of the sea.
Methoughts that I had broken from the Tower And was embarked to cross to Burgundy, And in my company my brother Gloucester, Who from my cabin tempted me to walk Upon the hatches.
Michael Cassio, Lieutenant to the warlike Moor Othello, Is come on shore.
Michael, good night.
Milan and Naples have More widows in them of this business' making Than we bring men to comfort them.
Mine ache to think on ’t.
Mine and my father’s death come not upon thee, Nor thine on me.
Mine ear must pluck it thence.
Mine ear, I thank it, brought me to thy sound But why unkindly didst thou leave me so?
Mine eyes did sicken at the sight and could not Endure a further view.
Mine eyes do itch, Doth that bode weeping?
Mine honor was not yielded, But conquered merely.
Mine nightingale, We have beat them to their beds.
Mine shall be spent When theirs are dry, for Romeo’s banishment.
Mine speak of seventy senators that died By their proscriptions, Cicero being one.
Mine was not bridled.
Mine would, sir, were I human.
Mine, and most of our fortunes tonight, shall be—drunk to bed.
Mine’s not an idle cause.
Minion, thou liest.
Minion, your dear lies dead, And your unblest fate hies.
Miranda.—O my father, I have broke your hest to say so!
Miscreant!
Miserable England, I prophesy the fearfull’st time to thee That ever wretched age hath looked upon.— Come, lead me to the block.
Misery acquaints a man with strange bedfellows.
Mistake me not.
Mistake no more.
Mistress and master, you have oft inquired After the shepherd that complained of love, Who you saw sitting by me on the turf, Praising the proud disdainful shepherdess That was his mistress.

Mistress, both man and master is possessed.

Moon and stars!

Moonshine and Lion are left to bury the dead.
More company!
More knocking.
More light and light it grows.
More light and light, more dark and dark our woes!
More matter for a May morning.
More of this hereafter.
More of this matter cannot I report.
More pity that the eagle should be mewed While kites and buzzards prey at liberty.
More shall they speak, for now I am bent to know, By the worst means, the worst.
More than pertains to feats of broils and battle, And therefore little shall I grace my cause In speaking for myself.
More to know Did never meddle with my thoughts.
More validity, More honorable state, more courtship lives In carrion flies than Romeo.
More villain thou.—Well, push him out of doors And let my officers of such a nature Make an extent upon his house and lands.
More will I do— Though all that I can do is nothing worth, Since that my penitence comes after all, Imploring pardon.
More wonderful, when angels are so angry.
More, Domitius: My lord desires you presently.
More, I prithee, more.
More, more, I prithee, more.
Moreover that we much did long to see you, The need we have to use you did provoke Our hasty sending.
Moreover, he hath left you all his walks, His private arbors and new-planted orchards, On this side Tiber.
Moreover, urge his hateful luxury And bestial appetite in change of lust, Which stretched to their servants, daughters, wives, Even where his raging eye or savage heart, Without control, lusted to make his prey.
Morton is fled to Richmond, And Buckingham, backed with the hardy Welshmen, Is in the field, and still his power increaseth.
Most absolute lord, My mistress Cleopatra sent me to thee.
Most certain, if you are she, you do usurp yourself, for what is yours to bestow is not yours to reserve.
Most certain, sir.
Most certain.
Most certain.
Most certain.
Most constantly.
Most detestable Death, by thee beguiled, By cruel, cruel thee quite overthrown!
Most excellent accomplished lady, the heavens rain odors on you!

Most gracious majesty!
Most happy!
Most heartily I do beseech the court To give the judgment.
Most heathenish and most gross!
Most heavy day!
Most high, most mighty, and most puissant Caesar, Metellus Cimber throws before thy seat An humble heart—     I must prevent thee, Cimber.

Most learnèd judge, a sentence!
Most like a gentleman.
Most like.
Most meet That first we come to words, and therefore have we Our written purposes before us sent, Which, if thou hast considered, let us know If ’twill tie up thy discontented sword And carry back to Sicily much tall youth That else must perish here.
Most mighty Caesar, let me know some cause, Lest I be laughed at when I tell them so.
Most mighty duke, behold a man much wronged.
Most mighty duke, vouchsafe me speak a word.
Most mighty sovereign, You have no cause to hold my friendship doubtful.
Most mischievous foul sin in chiding sin, For thou thyself hast been a libertine, As sensual as the brutish sting itself, And all th' embossèd sores and headed evils That thou with license of free foot hast caught Wouldst thou disgorge into the general world.
Most miserable hour that e'er time saw In lasting labor of his pilgrimage.
Most monsterlike be shown For poor’st diminutives, for dolts, and let Patient Octavia plow thy visage up With her preparèd nails!
Most monstrous, oh!
Most noble Antony!
Most noble brother, you have done me wrong.
Most noble Caesar!

Most sure and vulgar.

My affections Are then most humble.
My arm is sore.
My babes were destined to a fairer death If grace had blessed thee with a fairer life.
My back a' t' other side.
My banquet is to close our stomachs up, After our great good cheer.
My being in Egypt, Caesar, what was ’t to you?
My best endeavours shall be done herein.
My best way is to creep under his gaberdine.
My bond to the Jew is forfeit.
My bones would rest, That have but labored to attain this hour.
My books and instruments shall be my company, On them to look and practice by myself.
My boon I make it that you know me not Till time and I think meet.
My bounty is as boundless as the sea, My love as deep.
My brave spirit!
My breath and blood!
My brother and thy uncle, called Antonio— I pray thee, mark me (that a brother should Be so perfidious!
My brother Gloucester’s voice.—Ay, I know thy errand.
My brother hath a daughter, Almost the copy of my child that’s dead, And she alone is heir to both of us.
My brother he is in Elysium.
My brother killed no man; his fault was thought, And yet his punishment was bitter death.
My brother never Did urge me in his act.
My brother’s love, the devil, and my rage.
My brother’s servants Were then my fellows.
My cake is dough, but I’ll in among the rest, Out of hope of all but my share of the feast.
My charge was but to fetch you from the mart Home to your house, the Phoenix, sir, to dinner.
My charity is outrage, life my shame, And in that shame still live my sorrows' rage.
My charms crack not, my spirits obey, and time Goes upright with his carriage.
My charms I’ll break, their senses I’ll restore, And they shall be themselves.
My child is yet a stranger in the world.
My child, my only life, Revive, look up, or I will die with thee!— Help, help!
My children too?
My clerk hath some good comforts too for you.
My comfort is that old age, that ill layer-up of beauty, can do no more spoil upon my face.
My countryman, but yet I know him not.
My countrymen—     Peace, silence!
My cousin means Signor Benedick of Padua.
My cousin tells him in his ear that he is in her heart.
My cousin Westmoreland?
My cousin’s a fool, and thou art another.
My creditors grow cruel.
My curses on her!
My dagger, little cousin?
My daughter he hath wedded.
My daughter tells us all.
My daughter!
My daughter’s mother thinks it with her soul.
My dear lord, You know the fiery quality of the duke, How unremoveable and fixed he is In his own course.
My dear master, My captain, and my emperor, let me say, Before I strike this bloody stroke, farewell.
My dear Othello!
My dear’st sister!
My dearest cousin and my dearer lord?
My dearest coz, I pray you school yourself.
My dearest love, Duncan comes here tonight.
My decayèd fair A sunny look of his would soon repair.
My deeds upon my head.
My determinate voyage is mere extravagancy.
My dismal scene I needs must act alone.
My door is lock’d.
My dukedom to a beggarly denier, I do mistake my person all this while!
My duty cannot suffer To obey in all your daughters' hard commands.
My duty hushes me.
My duty to you both, on equal love, Great kings of France and England.
My duty, madam, and most humble service.
My estate is very low.
My ever-gentle cousin, welcome hither.
My excellent good friends!
My face I’ll grime with filth, Blanket my loins, elf all my hair in knots, And with presented nakedness outface The winds and persecutions of the sky.
My fair Bianca, bid my father welcome, While I with selfsame kindness welcome thine.
My fair Rosalind, I come within an hour of my promise.
My fairy lord, this must be done with haste.
My falcon now is sharp and passing empty, And, till she stoop, she must not be full-gorged, For then she never looks upon her lure.
My fan, Peter.
My father charged you in his will to give me good education.
My father compounded with my mother under the dragon’s tail and my nativity was under Ursa Major, so that it follows I am rough and lecherous.
My father dead, my fortune lives for me.
My father had a daughter loved a man As it might be, perhaps, were I a woman, I should your lordship.
My father Is hard at study.
My father is not dead, for all your saying.
My father loved Sir Rowland as his soul, And all the world was of my father’s mind.
My father was no traitor.
My father watches.
My father—methinks I see my father.
My father, poorly led?
My father’s bears more toward the marketplace.
My father’s death—      Thy life hath it dishonored.
My father’s loss, the weakness which I feel, The wrack of all my friends, nor this man’s threats, To whom I am subdued, are but light to me, Might I but through my prison once a day Behold this maid.
My father’s love is enough to honor him.
My father’s spirit in arms.
My fault, but not my body, pardon, sovereign.
My fool usurps my body.
My friend, thy husband, honest, honest Iago.
My friends told me as much, and I thought no less.
My gentleman, Cesario?
My good friends, hark!
My good friends, I’ll leave you till night.
My good knave Eros, now thy captain is Even such a body.
My good lord.
My good lords both, with all the heed I can.
My gracious sovereign, now in Devonshire, As I by friends am well advertisèd, Sir Edward Courtney and the haughty prelate, Bishop of Exeter, his elder brother, With many more confederates are in arms.
My gracious sovereign.
My grandam told me he was murdered there.
My hair doth stand an end to hear her curses.
My heart is sorry for your daughter’s death, But, on my honor, she was charged with nothing But what was true and very full of proof.
My heart is ten times lighter than my looks.
My heart is thirsty for that noble pledge.
My heart prays for him, though my tongue do curse.
My hearty friends, You take me in too dolorous a sense, For I spake to you for your comfort, did desire you To burn this night with torches.
My honored lord!
My hour is almost come When I to sulfurous and tormenting flames Must render up myself.
My house was at the Phoenix?
My husband is on earth, my faith in heaven.
My husband lost his life to get the crown, And often up and down my sons were tossed For me to joy, and weep, their gain and loss.
My husband say that she was false!
My husband, then?
My husband!
My husband!
My husband?
My industrious servant, Ariel!
My invocation Is fair and honest.
My kind Antonio, I can no other answer make but thanks, And thanks, and ever thanks.
My lady bade me tell you, that, though she harbors you as her kinsman, she’s nothing allied to your disorders.
My lady charged my duty in this business.
My Lady Grey his wife, Clarence, ’tis she That tempers him to this extremity.
My lady has a white hand, and the Myrmidons are no bottle-ale houses.
My lady is within, sir.
My lady will hang thee for thy absence.
My lady would not lose him for more than I’ll say.
My language!
My learnèd lord, we pray you to proceed And justly and religiously unfold Why the law Salic that they have in France Or should or should not bar us in our claim.
My leg is cut in two.
My leisure serves me, pensive daughter, now.— My lord, we must entreat the time alone.
My letters say a hundred and seven galleys.
My liberty.
My liege and madam, to expostulate What majesty should be, what duty is, Why day is day, night night, and time is time, Were nothing but to waste night, day, and time.
My liege, here is a villain and a traitor, that, look your Grace, has struck the glove which your Majesty is take out of the helmet of Alençon.
My liege, I am advisèd what I say, Neither disturbed with the effect of wine, Nor heady-rash, provoked with raging ire, Albeit my wrongs might make one wiser mad.
My liege, They are not yet come back.
My liege, this was my glove; here is the fellow of it.
My liege, your highness now may do me good.
My liege.
My life is run his compass.
My life upon ’t, young though thou art, thine eye Hath stay’d upon some favor that it loves.
My life upon her faith!—Honest Iago, My Desdemona must I leave to thee.
My life were better ended by their hate Than death proroguèd, wanting of thy love.
My life will be too short, And every measure fail me.
My life, sir!
My little spirit, see, Sits in a foggy cloud and stays for me.
My lord and brother, God save you.
My lord and lady, it is now our time, That have stood by and seen our wishes prosper, To cry, “Good joy, good joy, my lord and lady!” My Lord Bassanio and my gentle lady, I wish you all the joy that you can wish, For I am sure you can wish none from me.
My lord and master loves you.
My lord and you were then at Mantua.— Nay, I do bear a brain.—But, as I said, When it did taste the wormwood on the nipple Of my dug and felt it bitter, pretty fool, To see it tetchy and fall out with the dug!
My lord approaches.
My Lord Bassanio gave his ring away Unto the judge that begged it and indeed Deserved it too.
My Lord Bassanio, let him have the ring.
My Lord Bassanio, since you have found Antonio, We two will leave you.
My Lord Constable, the armor that I saw in your tent tonight, are those stars or suns upon it?
My Lord High Constable, the English lie within fifteen hundred paces of your tents.
My lord is dead.
My lord is not my lord, nor should I know him Were he in favor as in humor altered.
My lord is often thus And hath been from his youth.
My lord it shall be done.
My lord of Burgundy.
My Lord of Cambridge, and my kind Lord of Masham, And you, my gentle knight, give me your thoughts.
My lord of Gloucester hath conveyed him hence.
My Lord of Gloucester, I have too long borne Your blunt upbraidings and your bitter scoffs.
My Lord of Norfolk— Here, most gracious liege.
My lord of Orléans, and my Lord High Constable, you talk of horse and armor?
My Lord of Oxford, you, Sir William Brandon, And you, Sir Walter Herbert, stay with me.
My Lord of Warwick and my brother Gloucester, Follow Fluellen closely at the heels.
My Lord of Warwick, here is, praised be God for it, a most contagious treason come to light, look you, as you shall desire in a summer’s day.
My lord Sebastian, The truth you speak doth lack some gentleness And time to speak it in.
My lord shall never rest, I’ll watch him tame and talk him out of patience.
My Lord— Ay, what’s o'clock?
My lord, for aught I know.
My lord, from head to foot.
My lord, good morrow.
My lord, he doth deny to come.
My lord, he is but even now gone hence.
My lord, he’s going to his mother’s closet.
My lord, his majesty bade me signify to you that he has laid a great wager on your head.
My lord, his throat is cut.
My lord, I am for you, though it cost me ten nights' watchings.
My lord, I came to see your father’s funeral.
My lord, I cannot.
My lord, I claim the gift, my due by promise, For which your honor and your faith is pawned— Th' earldom of Hereford and the movables Which you promisèd I shall possess.
My lord, I did intend it.
My lord, I did, But answer made it none.
My lord, I do not know that I did cry.
My lord, I do protest—    O, do not swear!
My lord, I have considered in my mind The late request that you did sound me in.
My lord, I have news to tell you.
My lord, I have remembrances of yours That I have longèd long to redeliver.
My lord, I have.
My lord, I hold my life as dear as you do yours, And never in my days, I do protest, Was it so precious to me as ’tis now.
My lord, I know not what the matter is, but to my judgment your highness is not entertained with that ceremonious affection as you were wont.
My lord, I shall reply amazèdly, Half sleep, half waking.
My lord, I take my leave.
My lord, I think I saw him yesternight.
My lord, I warrant you we will play our part As he shall think by our true diligence He is no less than what we say he is.
My lord, I will not.
My lord, I will use them according to their desert.
My lord, I would that Thursday were tomorrow.
My lord, I’ll tell you that self bill is urged Which in th' eleventh year of the last king’s reign Was like, and had indeed against us passed But that the scambling and unquiet time Did push it out of farther question.
My lord, in Athens.
My lord, Mark Antony, Hearing that you prepared for war, acquainted My grievèd ear withal, whereon I begged His pardon for return.

My lord, my lord— I will not hear you.
My lord, my lord, I’ll prove it on his body if he dare, Despite his nice fence and his active practice, His May of youth and bloom of lustihood.
My lord, my lord!
My lord, that would dishonor him!

My lord, the queen would speak with you, and presently.

My lord, there needs no such apology.

My lord, this would not be believed in Venice, Though I should swear I saw ’t.
My lord, upon the platform where we watch.

My lord.
My love doth so approve him That even his stubbornness, his checks, his frowns— Prithee, unpin me—have grace and favor.
My love is thine to teach.
My love thou art, my love, I think.
My love, my life, my soul, fair Helena!
My maid Nerissa and myself meantime Will live as maids and widows.
My master calls me.

My master is grown quarrelsome.
My master is the great rich Capulet, and if you be not of the house of Montagues, I pray come and crush a cup of wine.
My master stays in the street.
My master will be here ere morning.
My master, and my lord!
My master, not myself, lacks recompense.
My master’s a very Jew.
My master’s mind.
My master’s.
My masters, are you mad?
My matter hath no voice, lady, but to your own most pregnant and vouchsafed ear.
My men should call me “lord.” I am your goodman.
My mind hath been as big as one of yours, My heart as great, my reason haply more, To bandy word for word and frown for frown.
My mind is changed.
My mind was never yet more mercenary.
My mistress and her sister stays for you.
My mistress here lies murdered in her bed— Oh, heavens forfend!
My mistress showed me thee and thy dog and thy bush.
My mistress with a monster is in love.
My mistress, dearest, and I thus humble ever.
My mistress, sir,” quoth I.
My money is almost spent, I have been tonight exceedingly well cudgeled, and I think the issue will be I shall have so much experience for my pains.
My more particular, And that which most with you should safe my going, Is Fulvia’s death.

My most dear lord!

My mother.

My name’s Macbeth.
My necessaries are embarked.
My news I might have told hereafter.
My news shall be the fruit to that great feast.
My niece is already in the belief that he’s mad.
My niece Plantagenet Led in the hand of her kind aunt of Gloucester?
My niece shall take note of it, and assure thyself, there is no love-broker in the world can more prevail in man’s commendation with woman than report of valor.
My noble brother!
My noble father, I do perceive here a divided duty.
My noble girls!

My noble lords and cousins all, good morrow.
