My nyas?
My old bones ache.
My old brain is troubled.
My old friend Grumio and my good friend Petruchio?
My other self, my council’s consistory, My oracle, my prophet, my dear cousin, I, as a child, will go by thy direction Toward Ludlow then, for we’ll not stay behind.
My own flesh and blood to rebel!
My parts, my title, and my perfect soul Shall manifest me rightly.
My people do already know my mind And will acknowledge you and Jessica In place of Lord Bassanio and myself.
My powers are crescent, and my auguring hope Says it will come to th’ full.
My prayers, minx?
My precious Queen, forbear, And give true evidence to his love which stands An honorable trial.
My present business calls me from you now.
My pretty cousins, you mistake me both.
My purpose is, indeed, a horse of that color.
My purposes do draw me much about.
My quaint Ariel, Hark in thine ear.
My Queen and Eros Have by their brave instruction got upon me A nobleness in record.
My Regan counsels well.
My remedy is then to pluck it out.
My remembrance is very free and clear from any image of offense done to any man.
My reputation, Iago, my reputation!
My resolution and my hands I’ll trust, None about Caesar.
My resolution’s placed, and I have nothing Of woman in me.
My royal cousin, teach you our princess English?
My royal lord, You do not give the cheer.
My salad days, When I was green in judgment, cold in blood, To say as I said then.
My servant, sir!
My services to your lordship.
My services which I have done the signiory Shall out-tongue his complaints.
My ships come home a month before the day.
My sickness grows upon me.
My sight was ever thick.
My sister may receive it much more worse To have her gentleman abused, assaulted For following her affairs.—Put in his legs.
My son Came then into my mind, and yet my mind Was then scarce friends with him.
My soul doth tell me Hero is belied, And that shall Claudio know; so shall the Prince And all of them that thus dishonor her.
My soul is full of sorrow.
My soul is heavy, and I fain would sleep.
My soul shall thine keep company to heaven.
My soul, and not my child!
My sovereign lord, I do beseech your Highness To take our brother Clarence to your grace.
My spirits are nimble.
My spirits, as in a dream, are all bound up.
My stomach is not constant.
My strange and self-abuse Is the initiate fear that wants hard use.
My suit to her Is that she will to virtuous Desdemona Procure me some access.
My sweet Cassio!
My sweet mistress Weeps when she sees me work, and says such baseness Had never like executor.
My sword is drawn.
My sword, I say!
My tables!—Meet it is I set it down That one may smile, and smile, and be a villain.
My tale provokes that question.
My talk to thee must be how Benedick Is sick in love with Beatrice.
My thanes and kinsmen, Henceforth be earls, the first that ever Scotland In such an honor named.
My tongue and soul in this be hypocrites.
My uncle?
My very hairs do mutiny, for the white Reprove the brown for rashness, and they them For fear and doting.
My villainy they have upon record, which I had rather seal with my death than repeat over to my shame.
My villainy?
My visor is Philemon’s roof; within the house is Jove.
My voice is in my sword.
My voice is now the king’s, my looks mine own.
My voice is ragged.
My way is now to hie home to his house And tell his wife that, being lunatic, He rushed into my house and took perforce My ring away.
My wayward husband hath a hundred times
My wife is coming yonder.
My wife killed too?
My will, not all the world.
My wit’s diseased.
My wits begin to turn.—   Come on, my boy.
My wits faints.
My words are as full of peace as matter.
My words are dull.
My words would bandy her to my sweet love, And his to me.
My worthy Cawdor!
My worthy lord, Your noble friends do lack you.
My young master doth expect your reproach.
My young remembrance cannot parallel A fellow to it.
Myself am Naples, Who with mine eyes, never since at ebb, beheld The king my father wracked.
Myself and what is mine to you and yours Is now converted.
Myself have letters of the selfsame tenor.
Myself have to mine own turned enemy.
Myself myself confound, Heaven and fortune bar me happy hours, Day, yield me not thy light, nor night thy rest, Be opposite all planets of good luck To my proceedings if, with dear heart’s love, Immaculate devotion, holy thoughts, I tender not thy beauteous princely daughter.
Myself the man i' th' moon do seem to be— This is the greatest error of all the rest.
Myself, he, and my sister Today did dine together.
Myself?

Natures of such deep trust we shall much need.

Nerissa teaches me what to believe.
Never alone Did the king sigh, but with a general groan.
Never anger Made good guard for itself.
Never at quiet.
Never believe it.
Never came poison from so sweet a place.
Never come such division ’tween our souls.
Never did faithful subject more rejoice At the discovery of most dangerous treason Than I do at this hour joy o'er myself, Prevented from a damnèd enterprise.
Never did I know A creature that did bear the shape of man So keen and greedy to confound a man.
Never excuse—for when the players are all dead, there needs none to be blamed.
Never fear that.
Never hung poison on a fouler toad.
Never in your life, I think, unless you see canary put me down.
Never king of England Had nobles richer, and more loyal subjects, Whose hearts have left their bodies here in England And lie pavilioned in the fields of France.
Never make denial.
Never make known what you have seen tonight.
Never so rich a gem Was set in worse than gold.
Never talk to me.

Never to speak of this that you have seen.
Never trust me, then.
Never was monarch better feared and loved Than is your Majesty.

Never, my lord.
Never, my lord.

Now civil wounds are stopped, peace lives again.
Now comes the wanton blood up in your cheeks.
Now could I drink hot blood And do such bitter business as the bitter day Would quake to look on.

Now I begin: Imprimis, we came down a foul hill, my master riding behind my mistress— Both of one horse?
Now I change my mind, And partly credit things that do presage.
Now I feed myself With most delicious poison.
Now I must To the young man send humble treaties, dodge And palter in the shifts of lowness, who With half the bulk o’ th’ world played as I pleased, Making and marring fortunes.
Now I perceive they have conjoined all three To fashion this false sport, in spite of me.— Injurious Hermia!
Now I see, I see, In Fulvia’s death how mine received shall be.
Now I will believe That there are unicorns, that in Arabia There is one tree, the phoenix' throne, one phoenix At this hour reigning there.
Now I’ll tell you without asking.
Now in faith, Gratiano, You give your wife too unkind a cause of grief.
Now in respect it is in the fields, it pleaseth me well; but in respect it is not in the court, it is tedious.
Now is he for the numbers that Petrarch flowed in.
Now is it Rome indeed, and room enough, When there is in it but one only man.
Now is it time to arm.
Now is the day we long have lookèd for.
Now is the sun upon the highmost hill Of this day’s journey, and from nine till twelve Is three long hours, yet she is not come.
Now is the time of help.
Now is the winter of our discontent Made glorious summer by this son of York, And all the clouds that loured upon our house In the deep bosom of the ocean buried.
Now Jove, in his next commodity of hair, send thee a beard!
Now know you, Casca, I have moved already Some certain of the noblest-minded Romans To undergo with me an enterprise Of honorable-dangerous consequence.
Now let it work.
Now let me see if I can conster it.
Now let thy friendly hand Put strength enough to ’t.
Now let’s have a catch.
Now lies he there, And none so poor to do him reverence.
Now Lord be thanked for my good amends!
Now Margaret’s curse is fall'n upon our heads, When she exclaimed on Hastings, you, and I, For standing by when Richard stabbed her son.
Now Mercury endue thee with leasing, for thou speakest well of fools!
Now might I do it pat.
Now must I to the monument alone.
Now must the world point at poor Katherine And say, “Lo, there is mad Petruchio’s wife, If it would please him come and marry her!”   Upon my life, Petruchio means but well, Whatever fortune stays him from his word: Though he be blunt, I know him passing wise; Though he be merry, yet withal he’s honest.
Now must your conscience my acquaintance seal, And you must put me in your heart for friend, Sith you have heard, and with a knowing ear, That he which hath your noble father slain Pursued my life.
Now my charms are all o'erthrown, And what strength I have’s mine own, Which is most faint.
Now my spirit is going.
Now near enough.
Now quit you well.—             Torches, torches!
Now Romeo is beloved and loves again, Alike bewitchèd by the charm of looks, But to his foe supposed he must complain, And she steal love’s sweet bait from fearful hooks.
Now set the teeth and stretch the nostril wide, Hold hard the breath and bend up every spirit To his full height.
Now shall my friend Petruchio do me grace, And offer me disguised in sober robes To old Baptista as a schoolmaster Well seen in music, to instruct Bianca, That so I may, by this device at least, Have leave and leisure to make love to her And, unsuspected, court her by herself.
Now shall you see the other.
Now she holds me not.
Now she’s gone for ever.— Cordelia, Cordelia, stay a little.
Now show the wound mine eye hath made in thee.
Now sir, be judge yourself, Whether I in any just term am affined To love the Moor.
Now sir, this granted—as it is a most pregnant and unforced position—who stands so eminent in the degree of this fortune as Cassio does?
Now sit we close about this taper here And call in question our necessities.
Now sits the wind fair, and we will aboard.
Now spurs the lated traveler apace To gain the timely inn, and near approaches The subject of our watch.
Now take them up,” quoth he, “if any list.”   Trembled and shook, for why he stamped and swore As if the vicar meant to cozen him.
Now tell me how long you would have her after you have possessed her.
Now the fleeting moon No planet is of mine.
Now the witch take me if I meant it thus!
Now they are my men.
Now they believe it and withal whet me To be revenged on Rivers, Dorset, Grey; But then I sigh and, with a piece of scripture, Tell them that God bids us do good for evil; And thus I clothe my naked villainy With odd old ends stolen out of Holy Writ, And seem a saint when most I play the devil.
Now to that name my courage prove my title!
Now to you.
Now we speak upon our cue, and our voice is imperial.
Now welcome, Kate, and bear me witness all That here I kiss her as my sovereign queen.
Now will he sit under a medlar tree And wish his mistress were that kind of fruit As maids call medlars when they laugh alone.— O Romeo, that she were!
Now will I go to take some privy order To draw the brats of Clarence out of sight, And to give order that no manner of person Have any time recourse unto the princes.
Now will I question Cassio of Bianca, A huswife that by selling her desires Buys herself bread and clothes.
Now will I to the chink, To spy an I can hear my Thisbe’s face.
Now would I give a thousand furlongs of sea for an acre of barren ground: long heath, brown furze, anything.
Now you talk of a sheet of paper, I remember a pretty jest your daughter told.
Now your jest is earnest.
Now, afore God, I am so vexed that every part about me quivers.
Now, Antony, our hopes are answerèd.
Now, as I am a Christian, answer me In what safe place you have bestowed my money, Or I shall break that merry sconce of yours That stands on tricks when I am undisposed.
Now, as thou lovest me, let me see his letter.
Now, as you are a Roman, tell me true.
Now, Balthazar, As I have ever found thee honest true, So let me find thee still.
Now, banished Kent, If thou canst serve where thou dost stand condemned, So may it come thy master, whom thou lovest, Shall find thee full of labors.
Now, beshrew my father’s ambition!
Now, by Apollo— Now, by Apollo, King, Thou swear’st thy gods in vain.
Now, by heaven, My blood begins my safer guides to rule, And passion, having my best judgment collied, Assays to lead the way.
Now, by my holidam, here comes Katherina!
Now, by my hood, a gentle and no Jew.
Now, by my maidenhead at twelve year old I bade her come.
Now, by my mother’s son, and that’s myself, It shall be moon, or star, or what I list, Or e'er I journey to your father’s house.
Now, by my sword— And target.
Now, by my troth, if I had been remembered, I could have given my uncle’s grace a flout To touch his growth nearer than he touched mine.
Now, by Saint George, I am too young for you.
Now, by Saint Peter’s Church and Peter too, He shall not make me there a joyful bride.
Now, by the faith of my love, I will.
Now, by the holy mother of our Lord, The citizens are mum, say not a word.
Now, by the world—      'Tis full of thy foul wrongs.
Now, by the world, it is a lusty wench.
Now, by this hand, I swear, I scorn the term, Nor shall my Nell keep lodgers.
Now, by yon marble heaven, In the due reverence of a sacred vow I here engage my words.
Now, Catesby, what says his grace?
Now, Catesby, what says your lord to my request?
Now, Charmian!
Now, Cinna.—Now, Metellus.—What, Trebonius, I have an hour’s talk in store for you.
Now, darting Parthia, art thou struck, and now Pleased fortune does of Marcus Crassus’ death Make me revenger.
Now, ere the sun advance his burning eye, The day to cheer and night’s dank dew to dry, I must upfill this osier cage of ours With baleful weeds and precious-juicèd flowers.
Now, Eros.
Now, fair befall thee, good Petruchio!
Now, fellow, What is there?
Now, fellows, you are welcome.
Now, for I know the Breton Richmond aims At young Elizabeth, my brother’s daughter, And by that knot looks proudly on the crown, To her go I, a jolly thriving wooer.
Now, for my life, Hortensio fears his widow.
Now, for my life, she’s wandering to the Tower, On pure heart’s love, to greet the tender prince.— Daughter, well met.
Now, forward with your tale.—Prithee, stand farther off.
Now, gods, stand up for bastards!
Now, good Metellus, go along by him.
Now, good my lord, lie here and rest awhile.
Now, good sir, what are you?
Now, good sweet Nurse— O Lord, why look’st thou sad?
Now, herald, are the dead numbered?
Now, I prithee, daughter, do not make me mad.
Now, I’ll stand to it, the pancakes were naught and the mustard was good, and yet was not the knight forsworn.
Now, if these men have defeated the law and outrun native punishment, though they can outstrip men, they have no wings to fly from God.
Now, if thou wert a poet, I might have some hope thou didst feign.
Now, if you are a maid, answer to this.
Now, if you love me, stay.
Now, in good sadness, son Petruchio, I think thou hast the veriest shrew of all.
Now, infidel, I have you on the hip.
Now, Iras, what think’st thou?
Now, most noble Brutus, The gods today stand friendly that we may, Lovers in peace, lead on our days to age.
Now, music, sound, and sing your solemn hymn.
Now, my co-mates and brothers in exile, Hath not old custom made this life more sweet Than that of painted pomp?
Now, my dearest Queen— Pray you, stand farther from me.
Now, my friendly knave, I thank thee.
Now, my Lord Constable?
Now, my lord, what shall we do, if we perceive Lord Hastings will not yield to our complots?
Now, my lord.
Now, my Titania, wake you, my sweet queen.
Now, out of doubt Antipholus is mad; Else would he never so demean himself.
Now, princely Buckingham, seal thou this league With thy embracements to my wife’s allies And make me happy in your unity.
Now, Roderigo, Where didst thou see her?—Oh, unhappy girl!— With the Moor, say’st thou?—Who would be a father?— How didst thou know ’twas she?—Oh, she deceives me Past thought!—What said she to you?—Get more tapers, Raise all my kindred.
Now, Signior Petruchio, how speed you with my daughter?
Now, Signior, what news?
Now, Signior, where’s the Count?
Now, sir, what make you here?
Now, soldiers, march away, And how Thou pleasest, God, dispose the day.
Now, sweet lord, You know the goodness I intend upon you.
Now, the next day Was our sea fight, and what to this was sequent Thou know’st already.
Now, then, we’ll use His countenance for the battle, which being done, Let her who would be rid of him devise His speedy taking off.
Now, unto thy bones good night!
Now, Ursula, when Beatrice doth come, As we do trace this alley up and down, Our talk must only be of Benedick.
Now, were not I a little pot and soon hot, my very lips might freeze to my teeth, my tongue to the roof of my mouth, my heart in my belly, ere I should come by a fire to thaw me.
Now, what news on the Rialto?
Now, where’s my wife?
Now, where’s your master?
Now.
Nurse, commend me to thy lady and mistress.
Nurse, where’s my daughter?
Nurse, will you go with me into my closet To help me sort such needful ornaments As you think fit to furnish me tomorrow?
Nurse!
Nurse?
Nym, thou hast spoke the right.
O all you host of heaven!
O Antony, Antony, Antony!
O Antony, beg not your death of us.
O Antony, O thou Arabian bird!
O Antony, Thou mine of bounty, how wouldst thou have paid My better service, when my turpitude Thou dost so crown with gold!
O Antony!
O Banquo, Banquo, Our royal master’s murdered!
O bear me witness, night— What man is this?
O bitter consequence That Edward still should live “true noble prince”!
O blessèd, blessèd night!
O bloody Richard!
O bosom black as death!
O Bottom, thou art changed!
O braggart vile and damnèd furious wight, The grave doth gape, and doting death is near.
O brave monster!
O brave new world, That has such people in ’t!
O brave touch!
O brother Montague, give me thy hand.
O Brutus!
O Caesar, read mine first, for mine’s a suit That touches Caesar nearer.
O Caesar!
O calm dishonourable, vile submission!
O Cassio, Cassio, Cassio!
O Cassio, Cassio, Cassio!
O Cassio, whence came this?
O Cassius, Brutus gave the word too early, Who, having some advantage on Octavius, Took it too eagerly.
O Cassius, Far from this country Pindarus shall run, Where never Roman shall take note of him.
O Cassius, I am sick of many griefs.
O Cassius, if you could But win the noble Brutus to our party— Be you content.
O ceremony, show me but thy worth!
O Charmian, I will never go from hence.
O Cicero, I have seen tempests when the scolding winds Have rived the knotty oaks, and I have seen Th' ambitious ocean swell and rage and foam To be exalted with the threatening clouds, But never till tonight, never till now, Did I go through a tempest dropping fire.
O Cleopatra!
O Clitus!
O come, Ventidius.
O comfortable Friar!
O conspiracy, Shamest thou to show thy dangerous brow by night When evils are most free?
O Corin, that thou knew’st how I do love her!
O cousin, cousin!
O coward conscience, how dost thou afflict me!
O coz, coz, coz, my pretty little coz, that thou didst know how many fathom deep I am in love.
O cruel!
O cursed, cursed slave!
O dainty duck!
O damned Iago!
O Dardanius!
O day and night, but this is wondrous strange!
O day untowardly turned!
O deadly sin!
O dear discretion, how his words are suited!
O dear father, It is thy business that I go about.
O dear Ophelia, I am ill at these numbers.
O dear Phoebe, If ever—as that ever may be near— You meet in some fresh cheek the power of fancy, Then shall you know the wounds invisible That love’s keen arrows make.
O dear son Edgar, The food of thy abusèd father’s wrath, Might I but live to see thee in my touch, I’d say I had eyes again!
O dear!
O dolt!
O earth, which this blood drink’st revenge his death!
O earth!

O excellent device— and make a sop of him.

O excellent young man!

O fortune, fortune!
O Friar, the damnèd use that word in hell.
O gentle lady, 'Tis not for you to hear what I can speak: The repetition, in a woman’s ear, Would murder as it fell.

O hard condition, Twin-born with greatness, subject to the breath Of every fool, whose sense no more can feel But his own wringing.
O Harry’s wife, triumph not in my woes!
O hated potion, hence!
O heaven, O earth, bear witness to this sound And crown what I profess with kind event

O heavens, that they were living both in Naples, The king and queen there!
O heavens!
O heavens!

O Lord, I must laugh.

O Lord, they fight!
O Lord!

O me!

O thou public commoner!
O thou weed, Who art so lovely fair and smell’st so sweet That the sense aches at thee, would thou hadst ne'er been born!
O Thou, whose captain I account myself, Look on my forces with a gracious eye.
O time, thou must untangle this, not I.
O time’s extremity, Hast thou so crack’d and splitted my poor tongue In seven short years that here my only son Knows not my feeble key of untuned cares?

O Tranio, till I found it to be true, I never thought it possible or likely.

O true, good Catesby.
O Tybalt, Tybalt, the best friend I had!

O vassal!
O vengeance!

O woeful day!

O ye immortal gods!
O you gods!
O you mighty gods,  This world I do renounce, and in your sights Shake patiently my great affliction off.

O, full of danger is the duke of Gloucester, And the queen’s sons and brothers haught and proud, And were they to be ruled, and not to rule, This sickly land might solace as before.
O, gentlemen, see, see dead Henry’s wounds Open their congealed mouths and bleed afresh!— Blush, blush, thou lump of foul deformity, For ’tis thy presence that exhales this blood From cold and empty veins where no blood dwells.
O, give me leave.
O, good my lord, tax not so bad a voice To slander music anymore than once.
O, good sir, I do.
O, grief hath changed me since you saw me last, And careful hours with time’s deformèd hand Have written strange defeatures in my face.
O, had the gods done so, I had not now Worthily termed them merciless to us.

O, he was gentle, mild, and virtuous.

O, how this mother swells up toward my heart!

O, if I thought that, I’d beat him like a dog!

O, one too much by thee!
O, pardon me for bringing these ill news, Since you did leave it for my office, sir.
O, preposterous And frantic outrage, end thy damnèd spleen, Or let me die, to look on death no more.
O, quicken them with thine!
O, reason not the need!
O, reform it altogether!
O, rejoice Beyond a common joy, and set it down With gold on lasting pillars.
O, remember, God, To hear her prayer for them, as now for us!
O, serve me well, and teach yourselves that duty!
O, she that might have intercepted thee, By strangling thee in her accursèd womb, From all the slaughters, wretch, that thou hast done.
O, she tore the letter into a thousand halfpence, railed at herself that she should be so immodest to write to one that she knew would flout her.
O, she would laugh me Out of myself, press me to death with wit.
O, sir, I will not be so hard-hearted.
O, sir, the conceit is deeper than you think for.
O, sir, upon her nose, all o'er-embellished with rubies, carbuncles, sapphires, declining their rich aspect to the hot breath of Spain, who sent whole armadas of caracks to be ballast at her nose.
O, sixpence, that I had o' Wednesday last To pay the saddler for my mistress' crupper?
O, spare my guiltless wife and my poor children!— Keeper, I prithee sit by me awhile.
O, teach me how I should forget to think!
O, teach me how you look and with what art You sway the motion of Demetrius' heart.
O, tell me, Friar, tell me, In what vile part of this anatomy Doth my name lodge?
O, that once more you knew but what you are!
O, that thou wert not, poor distressèd soul!
O, that’s the sword to it.
O, the kindest Kate!
O, then be bold to say Bassanio’s dead!
O, then by day Where wilt thou find a cavern dark enough To mask thy monstrous visage?
O, then I see you will part but with light gifts.
O, then it moved her?
O, then, dear saint, let lips do what hands do.
O, they did urge it still unto the king.
O, thou didst prophesy the time would come That I should wish for thee to help me curse That bottled spider, that foul bunch-backed toad!
O, thou well-skilled in curses, stay awhile, And teach me how to curse mine enemies.
O, touch me not.
O, train me not, sweet mermaid, with thy note To drown me in thy sister’s flood of tears.
O, unpleasing news!
O, welcome, father!
O, well flown, bird.
O, what a fall was there, my countrymen!
O, what cause have I, Thine being but a moiety of my moan, To overgo thy woes and drown thy cries!
O, what men dare do!
O, what more favor can I do to thee, Than with that hand that cut thy youth in twain To sunder his that was thine enemy?
O, wilt thou darkling leave me?
O, wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?
O, would to God that the inclusive verge Of golden metal that must round my brow Were red-hot steel to sear me to the brains!
O, yes, my lord, but very idle words.
O, yet defend me, friends.
O, you are novices!
O, you give me ill counsel.
O!
O' Thursday be it, then.— Go you to Juliet ere you go to bed.
O’er my spirit Thy full supremacy thou knew’st, and that Thy beck might from the bidding of the gods Command me.
Obey thy parents, keep thy word’s justice, swear not, commit not with man’s sworn spouse, set not thy sweet heart on proud array.
Obey you, love you, and most honor you.
Observe her, stand close.
Observe him, for the love of mockery, for I know this letter will make a contemplative idiot of him.
Observe his construction of it.
Observe how Antony becomes his flaw, And what thou think’st his very action speaks In every power that moves.
Octavia is of a holy, cold, and still conversation.
Octavia weeps To part from Rome.
Octavius, I have seen more days than you.
Octavius, lead your battle softly on, Upon the left hand of the even field.
Octavius, then take him to follow thee, That did the latest service to my master.
Od’s lifelings, here he is!—You broke my head for nothing, and that that I did, I was set on to do ’t by Sir Toby.
Of a certain knight that swore by his honor they were good pancakes, and swore by his honor the mustard was naught.
Of a snail?
Of a strange nature is the suit you follow, Yet in such rule that the Venetian law Cannot impugn you as you do proceed.—   Ay, so he says.
Of Albany’s and Cornwall’s powers you heard not?
Of all the days i' the year, I came to ’t that day that our last King Hamlet overcame Fortinbras.
Of all the wonders that I yet have heard, It seems to me most strange that men should fear, Seeing that death, a necessary end, Will come when it will come.
Of anything the image tell me that Hath kept with thy remembrance.
Of fighting men they have full threescore thousand.
Of her society Be not afraid.
Of it own color too.
Of love?
Of lusty earls: Grandpré and Roussi, Faulconbridge and Foix, Beaumont and Marle, Vaudemont and Lestrale.
Of Mantua.
Of my kind uncle, that I know will give, And being but a toy, which is no grief to give.
Of one not easily jealous, but being wrought, Perplexed in the extreme.
Of one whose hand, Like the base Indian, threw a pearl away Richer than all his tribe.
Of princes in this number And nobles bearing banners, there lie dead One hundred twenty-six.
Of so high and plenteous wit and invention!
Of that there’s none, or little.
Of the king’s ship, The mariners, say how thou hast disposed, And all the rest o' th' fleet.

Of this discourse we more will hear anon.— Egeus, I will overbear your will.

Of us must Pompey presently be sought, Or else he seeks out us.
Of very ill manner.

Of what your reverence shall incite us to.

Oh, that woman that cannot make her fault her husband’s occasion, let her never nurse her child herself, for she will breed it like a fool.

One cried, “God bless us!” and “Amen” the other, As they had seen me with these hangman’s hands.

One doth not know How much an ill word may empoison liking.

One knocks.
One minded like the weather, most unquietly.

Only be patient till we have appeased The multitude, beside themselves with fear, And then we will deliver you the cause, Why I, that did love Caesar when I struck him, Have thus proceeded.
Only for this, I pray you, pardon me.
Only foul words, and thereupon I will kiss thee.

Only he hath not yet subscribèd this: Where your Majesty demands that the king of France, having any occasion to write for matter of grant, shall name your Highness in this form and with this addition, in French:  Nor this I have not, brother, so denied But your request shall make me let it pass.
Only I here importune death awhile, until Of many thousand kisses the poor last I lay upon thy lips.
Only I say Things have been strangely borne.
Only I yield to die.
Only in the world I fill up a place which may be better supplied when I have made it empty.
Only myself stood out; For which, if I be lapsèd in this place, I shall pay dear.
Only th’ adulterous Antony, most large In his abominations, turns you off And gives his potent regiment to a trull That noises it against us.
Only this commendation I can afford her, that were she other than she is, she were unhandsome, and being no other but as she is, I do not like her.
Only to despite them, I will endeavor anything.

Or I’ll deliver thy indignation to him by word of mouth.
Or if it did not, Your first is dead, or ’twere as good he were, As living here and you no use of him.
Or if not so, then here I hit it right: Our Romeo hath not been in bed tonight.
Or if thou follow me, do not believe But I shall do thee mischief in the wood.
Or if thou hast not broke from company Abruptly, as my passion now makes me, Thou hast not loved.

Or if thou hast uphoarded in thy life Extorted treasure in the womb of earth, For which, they say, you spirits oft walk in death, Speak of it.

Or is he on his horse?

Or is your gold and silver ewes and rams?

Or o' mine either?
Or rather bottomless, that as fast as you pour affection in, it runs out.

Or that I had any friend would be a man for my sake!

Or what are you?

Or wilt thou hunt?
Or would you have me speak after my custom, as being a professed tyrant to their sex?
Or, failing so, yet that I put the Moor At least into a jealousy so strong That judgment cannot cure.
Or, if his mind be writ, give me his letter.
Or, if sour woe delights in fellowship And needly will be ranked with other griefs, Why followed not, when she said “Tybalt’s dead,” “Thy father” or “thy mother,” nay, or both, Which modern lamentations might have moved?
Or, if thou wilt, swear by thy gracious self, Which is the god of my idolatry, And I’ll believe thee.
Or, if you borrow one another’s love for the instant, you may, when you hear no more words of Pompey, return it again.
Or, if you do not, make the bridal bed In that dim monument where Tybalt lies.
Or, if you will, Come home to me, and I will wait for you.

Othello’s occupation’s gone.
Other women cloy The appetites they feed, but she makes hungry Where most she satisfies, for vilest things Become themselves in her, that the holy priests Bless her when she is riggish.
Our arms in strength of malice and our hearts Of brothers' temper do receive you in With all kind love, good thoughts, and reverence.
Our army shall In solemn show attend this funeral, And then to Rome.
Our bodies are our gardens, to the which our wills are gardeners.
Our brother is imprisoned by your means, Myself disgraced, and the nobility Held in contempt, while great promotions Are daily given to ennoble those That scarce some two days since were worth a noble.
Our care and pity is so much upon you That we remain your friend.
Our course will seem too bloody, Caius Cassius, To cut the head off and then hack the limbs, Like wrath in death and envy afterwards, For Antony is but a limb of Caesar.
Our dinner done and he not coming thither, I went to seek him.
Our duties, and the pledge.
Our duty to your honor.
Our enemies have beat us to the pit.
Our expectation hath this day an end.
Our fears in Banquo Stick deep, and in his royalty of nature Reigns that which would be feared.
Our force by land Hath nobly held.
Our fortune lies Upon this jump.
Our fortune on the sea is out of breath And sinks most lamentably.
Our foster nurse of nature is repose, The which he lacks—that to provoke in him Are many simples operative, whose power Will close the eye of anguish.
Our fraughtage, sir, I have conveyed aboard, and I have bought The oil, the balsamum and aqua vitae.
Our friends all stay for you.
Our general cast us thus early for the love of his Desdemona—who let us not therefore blame.
Our general’s wife is now the general.
Our good old friend, Lay comforts to your bosom, and bestow Your needful counsel to our business, Which craves the instant use.
Our gracious brother, I will go with them.
Our hour Is fully out.
Our house is hell, and thou, a merry devil, Didst rob it of some taste of tediousness.
Our instruments to melancholy bells, Our wedding cheer to a sad burial feast.
Our Italy Shines o’er with civil swords.
Our knocking has awaked him.
Our masquing mates by this time for us stay.
Our master and mistress seeks you.
Our posts shall be swift and intelligent betwixt us.—Farewell, dear sister.
Our power is ready; Our lack is nothing but our leave.
Our preparation stands In expectation of them.
Our present business Is to general woe.
Our purposes God justly hath discovered, And I repent my fault more than my death, Which I beseech Your Highness to forgive, Although my body pay the price of it.
Our queen and all our elves come here anon.
Our reasons are so full of good regard That were you, Antony, the son of Caesar, You should be satisfied.
Our separated fortune Shall keep us both the safer.
Our separation so abides and flies That thou, residing here, goes yet with me, And I, hence fleeting, here remain with thee.
Our severed navy too Have knit again, and fleet, threat’ning most sealike.
Our sex, as well as I, may chide you for it, Though I alone do feel the injury.
Our size of sorrow, Proportioned to our cause, must be as great As that which makes it.
Our solemn hymns to sullen dirges change, Our bridal flowers serve for a buried corse, And all things change them to the contrary.
Our son shall win.
Our time does call upon ’s.
Our tongue is rough, coz, and my condition is not smooth, so that, having neither the voice nor the heart of flattery about me, I cannot so conjure up the spirit of love in her that he will appear in his true likeness.
Our troops set forth tomorrow.
Our wars are done, the Turks are drowned.
Our whole city is much bound to him.
Our will is Antony be took alive.
Our worser thoughts heavens mend.
Our yoke and sufferance show us womanish.
Ourself will mingle with society And play the humble host.
Ourselves we do not owe.

Parting is such sweet sorrow That I shall say good night till it be morrow.
Pass!
Pass.
Passion, I see, is catching, for mine eyes, Seeing those beads of sorrow stand in thine, Began to water.
Past all expressing.
Past question, for thou seest it will not curl by nature.

Persever, counterfeit sad looks, Make mouths upon me when I turn my back, Wink each at other, hold the sweet jest up— This sport, well carried, shall be chronicled.

Pleaseth your Majesty to give me leave, I’ll muster up my friends and meet your Grace Where and what time your Majesty shall please.
Pleasure and action make the hours seem short.
Plots have I laid, inductions dangerous, By drunken prophecies, libels and dreams, To set my brother Clarence and the king In deadly hate, the one against the other; And if King Edward be as true and just As I am subtle, false, and treacherous, This day should Clarence closely be mewed up About a prophecy which says that “G” Of Edward’s heirs the murderer shall be.
Pluck but his name out of his heart and turn him going.

Pluck up thy spirits.
Pluck up, my heart, and be sad.
Plucking the entrails of an offering forth, They could not find a heart within the beast.
Plucks off my beard and blows it in my face?
Poison, I see, hath been his timeless end.— O churl, drunk all, and left no friendly drop To help me after?
Poisoned, then.
Pompey doth this day laugh away his fortune.
Pompey is strong at sea, And it appears he is beloved of those That only have feared Caesar.
Pompey Thrives in our idleness.
Pooh, you speak like a green girl, Unsifted in such perilous circumstance.
Poor and content is rich, and rich enough, But riches fineless is as poor as winter To him that ever fears he shall be poor.

Poor bird!

Poor man!
Poor men alone?

Proof enough to misuse the Prince, to vex Claudio, to undo Hero, and kill Leonato.
Proud,” and “I thank you,” and “I thank you not,” And yet “not proud”?
Prove that ever I lose more blood with love than I will get again with drinking, pick out mine eyes with a ballad-maker’s pen and hang me up at the door of a brothel house for the sign of blind Cupid.
Prove true, imagination, oh, prove true, That I, dear brother, be now ta'en for you!

Queen Margaret saw Thy murd'rous falchion smoking in his blood, The which thou once didst bend against her breast, But that thy brothers beat aside the point.
Question enrages him.
Question it, Horatio.
Question your Grace the late ambassadors With what great state he heard their embassy, How well supplied with noble counselors, How modest in exception, and withal How terrible in constant resolution, And you shall find his vanities forespent Were but the outside of the Roman Brutus, Covering discretion with a coat of folly, As gardeners do with ordure hide those roots That shall first spring and be most delicate.
Question: why, an hour in clamor and a quarter in rheum.
Quick, quick!
Quickly let me have it.
Quickly send— Be brief in it—to th' castle, for my writ Is on the life of Lear and on Cordelia.

Revenge.
Revenges burn in them, for their dear causes Would to the bleeding and the grim alarm Excite the mortified man.
Revolving this will teach thee how to curse.
Richard except, those whom we fight against Had rather have us win than him they follow.

Saving your merry humor, here’s the note How much your chain weighs to the utmost carat, The fineness of the gold, and chargeful fashion, Which doth amount to three-odd ducats more Than I stand debted to this gentleman.

Say ’tis not so, a province I will give thee And make thy fortunes proud.
Say “a day” without the “ever.” No, no, Orlando, men are April when they woo, December when they wed. Maids are May when they are maids, but the sky changes when they are wives.
Say again, where didst thou leave these varlets?
Say boldly.
Say either, and I’ll stay the circumstance.
Say from whence You owe this strange intelligence, or why Upon this blasted heath you stop our way With such prophetic greeting.
Say I am sick.
Say I will love her everlastingly.
Say I, her sovereign, am her subject low.

Say it, Othello.

Say not so.
Say on, my loving lord.
Say our pleasure, To such whose place is under us, requires Our quick remove from hence.
Say she be mute and will not speak a word; Then I’ll commend her volubility, And say she uttereth piercing eloquence.
Say she shall be a high and mighty queen.
Say that I did all this for love of her.
Say that I lingered with you at your shop To see the making of her carcanet, And that tomorrow you will bring it home.
Say that I slew them not.
Say that I wish he never find more cause To change a master.
Say that she frown; I’ll say she looks as clear As morning roses newly washed with dew.
Say that she rail; why then I’ll tell her plain She sings as sweetly as a nightingale.
Say that some lady, as perhaps there is, Hath for your love a great a pang of heart As you have for Olivia.
Say that the last I spoke was “Antony,” And word it, prithee, piteously.
Say that they slack their duties
Say that thou overheardst us, And bid her steal into the pleachèd bower Where honeysuckles ripened by the sun Forbid the sun to enter, like favorites Made proud by princes, that advance their pride Against that power that bred it.
Say that you love me not, but say not so In bitterness.
Say then my peace is made.
Say this becomes him— As his composure must be rare indeed Whom these things cannot blemish—yet must Antony No way excuse his foils when we do bear So great weight in his lightness.
Say thou but “ay,” And that bare vowel  Than the death-darting eye of cockatrice.
Say to me whose fortunes shall rise higher, Caesar’s or mine?
Say to the king I would attend his leisure For a few words.
Say to the king the knowledge of the broil As thou didst leave it.
Say what you will, sir, but I know what I know.
Say what, is Horatio there?

Say you so?
Say you?

Say, how is that?

Say, what?

Sblood, an arrant traitor as any ’s in the universal world, or in France, or in England!
Sblood, but you’ll not hear me!
Sblood, do you think I am easier to be played on than a pipe?
Sblood, there is something in this more than natural, if philosophy could find it out.
Scant not my cups, and make as much of me As when mine empire was your fellow too, And suffered my command.
Scape being drunk for want of wine.
Sconce” call you it?
Scorn and defiance, slight regard, contempt, And anything that may not misbecome The mighty sender, doth he prize you at.
Scout me for him at the corner the orchard like a bum-baily.
Scratch my head, Peaseblossom.
Scratching could not make it worse an ’twere such a face as yours were.

Scurvy knave!
Seafaring men, sir.
Seal then, and all is done.— Eros!—I come, my Queen.—Eros!—Stay for me.
Seal up the mouth of outrage for a while, Till we can clear these ambiguities And know their spring, their head, their true descent, And then will I be general of your woes, And lead you even to death.
Search every acre in the high-grown field, And bring him to our eye.
Search, seek, and know how this foul murder comes.
Searching the window for a flint, I found This paper, thus sealed up, and I am sure It did not lie there when I went to bed.
Season your admiration for a while With an attent ear, till I may deliver, Upon the witness of these gentlemen, This marvel to you.
Sebastian are you?
Sebastian was my father; Such a Sebastian was my brother too, So went he suited to his watery tomb.
Security gives way to conspiracy.
See better, Lear, and let me still remain The true blank of thine eye.
See for the news.
See him delivered, Fabian; bring him hither.
See how beastly she doth court him!
See how she leans her cheek upon her hand.
See how they kiss and court!
See how yon justice rails upon yon simple thief.
See it done And feast the army.
See me no more, whether he be dead or no.
See not your bride in these unreverent robes.
See this dispatched with all the haste thou canst: Anon I’ll give thee more instructions.
See thou dissemble not.
See what a rent the envious Casca made.
See where he looks out of the window.
See where his Grace stands, ’tween two clergymen.
See where she comes and brings your froward wives As prisoners to her womanly persuasion.— Katherine, that cap of yours becomes you not.
See where she comes from shrift with merry look.
See where they come.
See, and then speak yourselves.
See, Caesar!
See, doth he breathe?
See, here he comes.
See, it stalks away.
See, my women, Against the blown rose may they stop their nose, That kneeled unto the buds.—Admit him, sir.
See, see, here comes the man we went to seek.
See, see, our honored hostess!
See, they encounter thee with their hearts' thanks.
See, who comes here?
See, your wife’s with him.
See” ’t shalt thou never.—Fellows, hold the chair.— Upon these eyes of thine I’ll set my foot.
Seek him, bid him come hither.
Seek him, Titinius, whilst I go to meet The noble Brutus, thrusting this report Into his ears.
Seek it out.
Seek thine own ease.
Seek to know no more.
Seek, seek for him, Lest his ungoverned rage dissolve the life That wants the means to lead it.
Seek!
Seem they religious?
Seest not?
Seest thou here, This is the mouth o' th' cell.
Seest thou this sweet sight?

She ate no meat today, nor none shall eat.
She bids you come to her.
She cannot be so much without true judgment, Having so swift and excellent a wit As she is prized to have, as to refuse So rare a gentleman as Signior Benedick.
She cannot deny it.
She cannot endure to hear tell of a husband.
She cannot love Nor take no shape nor project of affection She is so self-endeared.

She creeps.
She desires to speak with you in her closet ere you go to bed.
She did commend my yellow stockings of late, she did praise my leg being cross-gartered, and in this she manifests herself to my love, and with a kind of injunction, drives me to these habits of her liking.
She did indeed.
She did show favor to the youth in your sight only to exasperate you, to awake your dormouse valor, to put fire in your heart and brimstone in your liver.
She died, my lord, but whiles her slander lived.
She dies for ’t.—Eros, ho!
She doth stray about By holy crosses, where she kneels and prays For happy wedlock hours.
She doth well.
She false with Cassio!
She for an Edward weeps, and so do I; I for a Clarence weep; so doth not she.

She give it Cassio?
She gives it out that you shall marry her.
She had a prophesying fear Of what hath come to pass.
She had a song of “Willow,” An old thing ’twas, but it expressed her fortune And she died singing it.
She has deceived her father, and may thee.
She has light by her continually.
She has robbed me of my sword.
She has spoke what she should not, I am sure of that.
She hath betrayed me and shall die the death.
She hath good leave.
She hath not seen the change of fourteen years.
She hath prevented me.
She hath spied him already with those sweet eyes.
She hath the stones upon her, and the ducats.” Why, all the boys in Venice follow him, Crying, “His stones, his daughter, and his ducats!”
She hath, and in that sparing makes huge waste, For beauty, starved with her severity, Cuts beauty off from all posterity.
She haunts me in every place.
She In th’ habiliments of the goddess Isis That day appeared, and oft before gave audience, As ’tis reported, so.
She is a royal princess.
She is a virtuous and a reverend lady.
She is banished.
She is cunning past man’s thought.
She is damned for it.
She Is daughter to this famous Duke of Milan, Of whom so often I have heard renown But never saw before, of whom I have Received a second life.
She is dead.
She is drowned already, sir, with salt water, though I seem to drown her remembrance again with more.
She is herself a dowry.
She is indeed perfection.
She is low-voiced.
She is never sad but when she sleeps, and not ever sad then, for I have heard my daughter say she hath often dreamed of unhappiness and waked herself with laughing.
She is not well.
She is not worth thee, then.
She is not, madam.
She is of so free, so kind, so apt, so blessed a disposition, she holds it a vice in her goodness not to do more than she is requested.
She is our capital demand, comprised Within the forerank of our articles.
She is persuaded I will marry her, out of her own love and flattery, not out of my promise.
She is protectress of her honor too.
She is spherical, like a globe.
She is stirring, sir.
She is thine own.— What, Ariel!
She is too big, I hope, for me to compass.
She is too fair, too wise, wisely too fair, To merit bliss by making me despair.
She knows the heat of a luxurious bed.
She lives.
She loved me for the dangers I had passed, And I loved her that she did pity them.
She loves me, sure!
She made good view of me, indeed so much That sure methought her eyes had lost her tongue, For she did speak in starts distractedly.
She mocks all her wooers out of suit.
She must change for youth.
She now shall be my sister, not my wife.
She Phoebes me.
She rendered life, Thy name so buried in her.

She said so.

She shows a body rather than a life, A statue than a breather.

She thanked me And bade me, if I had a friend that loved her, I should but teach him how to tell my story And that would woo her.
She that doth call me husband, even my soul Doth for a wife abhor.
She that herself will sliver and disbranch From her material sap perforce must wither And come to deadly use.
She that makes dainty, She, I’ll swear, hath corns.
She that was ever fair and never proud, Had tongue at will and yet was never loud, Never lacked gold and yet went never gay, Fled from her wish and yet said “Now I may,” She that being angered, her revenge being nigh, Bade her wrong stay and her displeasure fly, She that in wisdom never was so frail To change the cod’s head for the salmon’s tail, She that could think and ne'er disclose her mind, See suitors following and not look behind, She was a wight, if ever such wights were— To do what?
She that would alter services with thee,  The Fortunate Unhappy”  Daylight and champaign discovers not more.
She that would be your wife now ran from you.
She that, so young, could give out such a seeming, To seel her father’s eyes up close as oak, He thought ’twas witchcraft.
She told her, while she kept it 'Twould make her amiable and subdue my father Entirely to her love, but if she lost it Or made gift of it, my father’s eye Should hold her loathèd and his spirits should hunt After new fancies.
She took the ring of me.

She, dying, as it must so be maintained, Upon the instant that she was accused, Shall be lamented, pitied and excused Of every hearer.

She’s a beagle, true-bred, and one that adores me.

Simple, plain Clarence, I do love thee so That I will shortly send thy soul to heaven, If heaven will take the present at our hands.
Sin from thy lips?
Since Cassius first did whet me against Caesar, I have not slept.
Since Cleopatra died I have lived in such dishonor that the gods Detest my baseness.
Since he hath got the jewel that I loved, And that which you did swear to keep for me, I will become as liberal as you.
Since he went from Egypt ’tis A space for farther travel.
Since he went into France, I have been in continual practice.
Since his majesty went into the field, I have seen her rise from her bed, throw her nightgown upon her, unlock her closet, take forth paper, fold it, write upon ’t, read it, afterwards seal it, and again return to bed; yet all this while in a most fast sleep.
Since I am crept in favor with myself, I will maintain it with some little cost.
Since I came hither, Which I can call but now, I have heard strange news.
Since I have your good leave to go away, I will make haste.
Since my dear soul was mistress of her choice And could of men distinguish, her election Hath sealed thee for herself, for thou hast been— As one in suffering all that suffers nothing— A man that Fortune’s buffets and rewards Hast ta'en with equal thanks.
Since my young lady’s going into France, sir, the fool hath much pined away.
Since no man of aught he leaves knows, what is ’t to leave betimes?
Since that my beauty cannot please his eye, I’ll weep what’s left away, and weeping die.
Since that respects and fortunes are his love, I shall not be his wife.
Since the torch is out, Lie down and stray no farther.
Since the youth of the count’s was today with thy lady, she is much out of quiet.
Since the youth will not be entreated, his own peril on his forwardness.
Since they did plot The means that dusky Dis my daughter got, Her and her blind boy’s scandaled company I have forsworn.
Since this fortune falls to you, Be content and seek no new.
Since thou dost give me pains, Let me remember thee what thou hast promised, Which is not yet performed me.

So do not I.
So do our vulgar drench their peasant limbs In blood of princes, and the wounded steeds Fret fetlock deep in gore, and with wild rage Yerk out their armèd heels at their dead masters, Killing them twice.
So do the kings of France unto this day, Howbeit they would hold up this Salic law To bar your Highness claiming from the female And rather choose to hide them in a net Than amply to imbar their crooked titles Usurped from you and your progenitors.
So do you too, where you perceive them thick.
So doth the greater glory dim the less.
So every bondman in his own hand bears The power to cancel his captivity.
So fare you well at once, for Brutus' tongue Hath almost ended his life’s history.
So fare you well till we shall meet again.
So fare you well.

So much for praising myself, who, I myself will bear witness, is praiseworthy.

So much was his pleasure should be proclaimed.
So our leader’s led, And we are women’s men.
So out went the candle and we were left darkling.
So perhaps did yours.
So please my lord the duke and all the court, To quit the fine for one half of his goods I am content, so he will let me have The other half in use to render it Upon his death unto the gentleman That lately stole his daughter.
So please you— What says the fellow there?
So please you, for I never heard it yet, Yet heard too much of Phoebe’s cruelty.
So please you, he is here at the door and importunes access to you.
So please you, something touching the Lord Hamlet.

So please you.
So please your grace, the Prologue is addressed.
So please your Lordship to accept our duty.
So please your majesty That we may wake the king?
So quick bright things come to confusion.
So rare a wondered father and a wife Makes this place paradise.
So said, so done, is well.
So say I. Methinks you are sadder.
So says the Prince and my new-trothèd lord.
So shall he waste his means, weary his soldiers, Doing himself offense, whilst we, lying still, Are full of rest, defense, and nimbleness.
So shall I clothe me in a forced content, And shut myself up in some other course, To fortune’s alms.
So shall I, love, And so, I pray, be you.
So shall you feel the loss, but not the friend Which you weep for.
So shall you quietly enjoy your hope And marry sweet Bianca with consent.
So shalt thou show me friendship.
So she may live unscarred of bleeding slaughter, I will confess she was not Edward’s daughter.
So shines a good deed in a naughty world.
So should a murderer look, so dead, so grim.
So should he look That seems to speak things strange.
So should the murdered look, and so should I, Pierced through the heart with your stern cruelty.
So should we you, if you should be our king.
So smooth he daubed his vice with show of virtue That, his apparent open guilt omitted— I mean his conversation with Shore’s wife— He lived from all attainder of suspects.
So stood the state when Henry the Sixth Was crowned in Paris but at nine months old.
So swift a pace hath thought that even now You may imagine him upon Blackheath, Where that his lords desire him to have borne His bruisèd helmet and his bended sword Before him through the city.
So take her to thee, shepherd.
So tell them, Publius.
So that by my foes, sir I profit in the knowledge of myself, and by my friends, I am abused.
So that if we will plant nettles or sow lettuce, set hyssop and weed up thyme, supply it with one gender of herbs or distract it with many—either to have it sterile with idleness, or manured with industry—why, the power and corrigible authority of this lies in our wills.
So that in these ten thousand they have lost, There are but sixteen hundred mercenaries.
So that my speed to Mantua there was stayed.
So that, as clear as is the summer’s sun, King Pepin’s title and Hugh Capet’s claim, King Lewis his satisfaction, all appear To hold in right and title of the female.
So that, conclusions to be as kisses, if your four negatives make your two affirmatives, why then the worse for my friends and the better for my foes.
So the fool follows after.
So the gods keep you And make the hearts of Romans serve your ends.
So the gods preserve thee!
So the life that died with shame Lives in death with glorious fame.
So the maid that stood in the way for my wish shall show me the way to my will.
So the poor third is up, till death enlarge his confine.
So the sins of my mother should be visited upon me.
So the spirit is eased.
So they are.
So they do nothing, ’tis a venial slip.
So thou mayst say the king lies by a beggar if a beggar dwell near him, or the church stands by thy tabor, if thy tabor stand by the church.
So thou, that hast no unkind mate to grieve thee, With urging helpless patience would relieve me; But, if thou live to see like right bereft, This fool-begged patience in thee will be left.
So thrive my soul— A thousand times good night!
So to most noble Caesar.
So to them both.
So turns she every man the wrong side out And never gives to truth and virtue that Which simpleness and merit purchaseth.

Some five or six and thirty of his knights, Hot questrists after him, met him at gate, Who with some other of the lord’s dependants Are gone with him towards Dover, where they boast To have well-armèd friends.
Some food we had and some fresh water that A noble Neapolitan, Gonzalo, Out of his charity, who being then appointed Master of this design, did give us, with Rich garments, linens, stuffs, and necessaries, Which since have steaded much.

Some tardy cripple bear the countermand, That came too lag to see him burièd.
Some tender money to me; some invite me; Some other give me thanks for kindnesses; Some offer me commodities to buy.
Some that will evermore peep through their eyes And laugh like parrots at a bagpiper, And other of such vinegar aspect That they’ll not show their teeth in way of smile Though Nestor swear the jest be laughable.
Some there be that shadows kiss.
Some to Decius' house and some to Casca’s.
Some to Ligarius'.
Some to the common pulpits, and cry out, “Liberty, freedom, and enfranchisement!” People and senators, be not affrighted.

Something from Cyprus as I may divine.
Something have you heard Of Hamlet’s “transformation”—so call it Since nor th' exterior nor the inward man Resembles that it was.
Something he left imperfect in the state which, since his coming forth, is thought of; which imports to the kingdom so much fear and danger that his personal return was most required and necessary.
Something we will determine.
Something, sure, of state, Either from Venice, or some unhatched practice Made demonstrable here in Cyprus to him, Hath puddled his clear spirit, and in such cases Men’s natures wrangle with inferior things, Though great ones are their object.
Sometime a horse I’ll be, sometime a hound, A hog, a headless bear, sometime a fire.

Tears his white hair, Which the impetuous blasts, with eyeless rage, Catch in their fury and make nothing of.

Tedious it were to tell and harsh to hear.
Tedious” and “brief”?
Tell Antony Brutus is ta'en.
Tell her I am arrested in the street, And that shall bail me.
Tell her my love, more noble than the world, Prizes not quantity of dirty lands; The parts that fortune hath bestowed upon her, Tell her, I hold as giddily as fortune; But ’tis that miracle and queen of gems That nature pranks her in attracts my soul.
Tell her the king, that may command, entreats— That, at her hands, which the king’s King forbids.
Tell him he shall not speak with me.
Tell him his fears are shallow, without instance.
Tell him I am prompt To lay my crown at ’s feet, and there to kneel.
Tell him I have moved my lord on his behalf, and hope all will be well.
Tell him I would speak with him.
Tell him I’ll knock his leek about his pate Upon Saint Davy’s day.
Tell him my fury shall abate, and I the crowns will take.
Tell him myself, the mayor, and aldermen, No less importing than our general good, In deep designs, and matters of great moment Are come to have some conference with his grace.
Tell him so yourself, And see how he will take it at your hands.
Tell him there’s a post come from my master with his horn full of good news.
Tell him we could have rebuked him at Harfleur, but that we thought not good to bruise an injury till it were full ripe.
Tell him, so please him come unto this place, He shall be satisfied and, by my honor, Depart untouched.
Tell him, when that our princely father York Blessed his three sons with his victorious arm, He little thought of this divided friendship.
Tell me at whose suit.
Tell me but this, Have you not sometimes seen a handkerchief Spotted with strawberries in your wife’s hand?
Tell me but truly—but then speak the truth— Do you not love my sister?
Tell me for more certainty, Albeit I’ll swear that I do know your tongue.
Tell me in sadness, who is that you love.

Tell me that.
Tell me that.

The juice of it on sleeping eyelids laid Will make or man or woman madly dote Upon the next live creature that it sees.

The king doth love you well.
The king enacts more wonders than a man, Daring an opposite to every danger.
The king falls from bias of nature—there’s father against child.
The king has killed his heart.
The king hath granted every article, His daughter first, and, in sequel, all, According to their firm proposed natures.

The king hath note of all that they intend, By interception which they dream not of.
The king hath strictly charged the contrary.
The king himself is rode to view their battle.
The king his master needs must take it ill, That he, so slightly valued in his messenger, Should have him thus restrained.
The king is coming.
The king is full of grace and fair regard.
The king is mad.
The king is not bound to answer the particular endings of his soldiers, the father of his son, nor the master of his servant, for they purpose not their death, when they purpose their services.
The king is not to answer it.
The king mine uncle is to blame for it.
The king my father?!
The King of Naples, being an enemy To me inveterate, hearkens my brother’s suit, Which was that he, in lieu o' th' premises Of homage and I know not how much tribute, Should presently extirpate me and mine Out of the dukedom, and confer fair Milan With all the honors on my brother.
The king rises.
The king shall drink to Hamlet’s better breath, And in the cup an union shall he throw Richer than that which four successive kings In Denmark’s crown have worn.
The King will be gone from Southampton.
The king would speak with Cornwall.
The king, His brother, and yours, abide all three distracted, And the remainder mourning over them, Brimful of sorrow and dismay.
The king, sir— Ay, sir, what of him?
The king, sir, hath laid that in a dozen passes between yourself and him, he shall not exceed you three hits.
The king, sir, hath wagered with him six Barbary horses, against the which he has impawned, as I take it, six French rapiers and poniards with their assigns—as girdle, hangers, and so.
The king, the king’s to blame.
The king?
The king’s a bawcock, and a heart of gold, A lad of life, an imp of fame, Of parents good, of fist most valiant.
The king’s a-bed.
The king’s son have I landed by himself, Whom I left cooling of the air with sighs In an odd angle of the isle, and sitting, His arms in this sad knot.
The king’s son, Ferdinand, With hair up-staring—then, like reeds, not hair— Was the first man that leaped, cried, “Hell is empty And all the devils are here.”      Why, that’s my spirit!
The knave counterfeits well.
The labor we delight in physics pain.
The ladies, her attendants of her chamber Saw her abed, and in the morning early They found the bed untreasured of their mistress.
The Lady Beatrice hath a quarrel to you.
The lady is dead upon mine and my master’s false accusation.

The lady protests too much, methinks.
The lamentable change is from the best; The worst returns to laughter.

The last was I that felt thy tyranny.
The law allows it, and the court awards it.
The law hath yet another hold on you.
The law that threatened death becomes thy friend And turns it to exile—there art thou happy.
The laws are mine, not thine.
The leisure and the fearful time Cuts off the ceremonious vows of love And ample interchange of sweet discourse, Which so-long-sundered friends should dwell upon.

The Moor himself at sea And is in full commission here for Cyprus.

The time to come.
The time was once when thou unurged wouldst vow That never words were music to thine ear, That never object pleasing in thine eye, That never touch well welcome to thy hand, That never meat sweet-savored in thy taste, Unless I spake, or looked, or touched, or carved to thee.

thee aloud “England is thine, Ireland is thine, France is thine, and Harry Plantagenet is thine,” who, though I speak it before his face, if he be not fellow with the best king, thou shalt find the best king of good fellows.

Their battles are at hand.

Their course of love, the tidings of her death.
Their defeat Does by their own insinuation grow.
Their great guilt, Like poison given to work a great time after, Now 'gins to bite the spirits.
Their hands and faces were all badged with blood.
Their lips were four red roses on a stalk, And in their summer beauty kissed each other.

Then know that from my soul I love thy daughter.
Then lead the way, good father; and heavens so shine That they may fairly note this act of mine.
Then learn this of me: to have is to have.

Then leave him out.
Then let the trumpets sound The tucket sonance and the note to mount, For our approach shall so much dare the field That England shall couch down in fear and yield.
Then let them use us well, else let them know, The ills we do, their ills instruct us so.
Then let thy love be younger than thyself, Or thy affection cannot hold the bent.
Then let us both be sudden.
Then let your servants bring my husband forth.
Then let your will attend on their accords.

Then love me, Rosalind.

Then move not, while my prayer’s effect I take.
Then murder’s out of tune, And sweet revenge grows harsh.

Then must the Jew be merciful.
Then must thou needs find out new heaven, new earth.
Then must we look from his age to receive not alone the imperfections of long-engrafted condition, but therewithal the unruly waywardness that infirm and choleric years bring with them.
Then must you speak Of one that loved not wisely, but too well.
Then never man was man true.
Then none have I offended.
Then one of you will prove a shrunk panel and, like green timber, warp, warp.
Then open not thy lips.
Then pardon him, sweet father, for my sake.
Then patiently hear my impatience.
Then plainly know my heart’s dear love is set On the fair daughter of rich Capulet.
Then plainly to her tell my loving tale.
Then pleaded I for you.
Then put up your pipes in your bag, for I’ll away.
Then saw you not his face?
Then say at once what is it thou requests.
Then say at once what thou dost know in this.
Then say they were not slain.
Then shall I bleed to death.
Then shall I swear to Kate, and you to me, And may our oaths well kept and prosp'rous be.
Then shall the sighs of Octavia blow the fire up in Caesar, and, as I said before, that which is the strength of their amity shall prove the immediate author of their variance.
Then shall we be news-crammed.
Then shall we find tomorrow they have only stomachs to eat and none to fight.
Then she bears some breadth?
Then she is well, and nothing can be ill.
Then show it me.
Then slip I from her bum, down topples she, And “Tailor!” cries, and falls into a cough, And then the whole quire hold their hips and laugh, And waxen in their mirth, and neeze, and swear A merrier hour was never wasted there.
Then so much have I heard.
Then stand with us.
Then swore he that he was a stranger here.
Then take him up and manage well the jest.
Then tell me If this might be a brother.
Then tell me, if I get your daughter’s love, What dowry shall I have with her to wife?
Then tell me, what makes he upon the seas?
Then the liars and swearers are fools, for there are liars and swearers enough to beat the honest men and hang up them.
Then the whining schoolboy with his satchel And shining morning face, creeping like snail Unwillingly to school.
Then there is no true lover in the forest, else sighing every minute and groaning every hour would detect the lazy foot of time as well as a clock.
Then there is the County Palatine.

Therefore, you clown, abandon—which is, in the vulgar, “leave”—the society—which in the boorish is “company”—of this female—which in the common is “woman”; which together is, abandon the society of this female, or, clown, thou perishest; or, to thy better understanding, diest; or, to wit, I kill thee, make thee away, translate thy life into death, thy liberty into bondage.

These are now the fashion, and so berattle the common stages—so they call them—that many wearing rapiers are afraid of goose quills and dare scarce come thither.

These be the Christian husbands.
These both put off, a poor petitioner, A care-crazed mother to a many sons, A beauty-waning and distressèd widow, Even in the afternoon of her best days, Made prize and purchase of his wanton eye, Seduced the pitch and height of his degree To base declension and loathed bigamy.
These clothes are good enough to drink in, and so be these boots too.
These couchings and these lowly courtesies Might fire the blood of ordinary men And turn preordinance and first decree Into the law of children.
These deeds must not be thought After these ways.
These ducats pawn I for my father here.
These ears of mine, thou know’st did hear thee.
These English woes will make me smile in France.
These fellows have some soul,
These fifteen years you have been in a dream Or, when you waked, so waked as if you slept.
These fifteen years!
These foolish drops do something drown my manly spirit.
These gloves the Count sent me, they are an excellent perfume.
These griefs and losses have so bated me, That I shall hardly spare a pound of flesh Tomorrow to my bloody creditor.— Well, jailer, on.—Pray God Bassanio come To see me pay his debt, and then I care not.
These growing feathers plucked from Caesar’s wing Will make him fly an ordinary pitch, Who else would soar above the view of men And keep us all in servile fearfulness.
These hands do lack nobility that they strike A meaner than myself, since I myself Have given myself the cause.
These happy masks that kiss fair ladies' brows, Being black, puts us in mind they hide the fair.
These injuries the king now bears will be revenged home.
These late eclipses in the sun and moon portend no good to us.

They could not, would not do ’t.

They did so, to th' amazement of mine eyes That looked upon ’t.
They did, Fluellen.
They do me wrong, and I will not endure it!
They do offend our sight.
They fell together all, as by consent.
They flatter me.
They follow the king’s pleasure.
They have all stomachs.
They have dispatched with Pompey; he is gone.
They have in England A coin that bears the figure of an angel Stamped in gold, but that’s insculped upon.
They have made him drink alms-drink.
They have made worms' meat of me.
They have not been commanded, mighty king.
They have said their prayers, and they stay for death.
They have their exits and their entrances, And one man in his time plays many parts, His acts being seven ages.
They have tied me to a stake.
They know By th’ height, the lowness, or the mean, if dearth Or foison follow.
They know your Grace hath cause and means and might; So hath your Highness.
They lack retention.
They mean this night in Sardis to be quartered.
They mean to warn us at Philippi here, Answering before we do demand of them.
They met so near with their lips that their breaths embraced together.
They murder Caesar!”—Who’s within?
They must be bound and laid in some dark room.
They must lie there.
They must take it in sense that feel it.
They never meet but there’s a skirmish of wit between them.
They pray; grant thou, lest faith turn to despair.
They say Edgar, his banished son, is with the Earl of Kent in Germany.
They say he cried out of sack.
They say he has been fencer to the Sophy.
They say he parted well and paid his score.
They say there’s but five upon this isle.
They say this town is full of cozenage, As nimble jugglers that deceive the eye, Dark-working sorcerers that change the mind, Soul-killing witches that deform the body, Disguised cheaters, prating mountebanks, And many suchlike liberties of sin.
They say you are a melancholy fellow.
They say, one Taurus.
They see and smell And have their palates both for sweet and sour, As husbands have.
They shall be apprehended by and by.
They shall be married tomorrow, and I will bid the duke to the nuptial.
They shall have none, I swear, but these my joints, Which, if they have, as I will leave 'em them, Shall yield them little.
They shall, Nerissa, but in such a habit That they shall think we are accomplishèd With that we lack.
They shout for joy.
They shouted thrice.
They sit conferring by the parlor fire.
They smile at me that shortly shall be dead.
They stand and would have parley.
They stared, and were distracted.
They stay upon your patience.
They steal hearts.
They stumble that run fast.
They swore that you were almost sick for me.
They swore that you were well-nigh dead for me.
They swore you did.
They that add, moreover, he’s drunk nightly in your company.
They that have done this deed are honorable.
They that reap must sheaf and bind, Then to cart with Rosalind.
They that stand high have many blasts to shake them, And if they fall, they dash themselves to pieces.
They thus directed, we will follow In the main battle, whose puissance on either side Shall be well wingèd with our chiefest horse.
They told me I was everything.
They vanished strangely.
They were suborned.
They were traitors!
They were villains, murderers.
They will scarcely believe this without trial.
They will steal anything and call it purchase.
They will surely do us no harm.
They would be better if well followed.
They would else have been troubled with a pernicious suitor.
They would have me as familiar with men’s pockets as their gloves or their handkerchers, which makes much against my manhood, if I should take from another’s pocket to put into mine, for it is plain pocketing up of wrongs.
They would not have you to stir forth today.
They, for their truth, might better wear their heads Than some that have accused them wear their hats.
They’ll be in scarlet straight at any news.
They’ll have me whipped for speaking true, thou'lt have me whipped for lying, and sometimes I am whipped for holding my peace.
They’ll kill us.
They’ll mar my counterfeiting.
They’ll tell all.
They’ll tell the clock to any business that We say befits the hour.
They’re busy within.
Thieves!
Thine eyes, sweet lady, have infected mine.
Thine, Claudio, thine, I say.
Things at the worst will cease, or else climb upward To what they were before.—My pretty cousin, Blessing upon you.
Things base and vile, holding no quantity, Love can transpose to form and dignity.
Things growing are not ripe until their season.
Things have fall'n out, sir, so unluckily, That we have had no time to move our daughter.
Things must be as they may.
Things that are past are done, with me.
Think and die.
Think it no more.
Think not I love him, though I ask for him.
Think not, thou noble Roman, That ever Brutus will go bound to Rome.
Think of it.
Think of me as you please.
Think on Lord Hastings.
Think on me, That am with Phoebus’ amorous pinches black And wrinkled deep in time.
Think on thy sins.
Think so, Iago?
Think upon these gone.
Think upon Vaughan, and with guilty fear Let fall thy lance.
Think what thou wilt, I am thy lover’s grace.
Think you but that I know our state secure, I would be so triumphant as I am?
Think you I am no stronger than my sex, Being so fathered and so husbanded?
Think you my uncle did dissemble, grandam?
Think you not that the powers we bear with us Will cut their passage through the force of France, Doing the execution and the act For which we have in head assembled them?
Think you of a worse title, and I will fit her to it.
Think you so?
Think you to walk forth?
Think yourself a baby That you have ta'en these tenders for true pay, Which are not sterling.
Think, my lord?
Think, my lord?” Alas, thou echo’st me As if there were some monster in thy thought Too hideous to be shown.
Think, when we talk of horses, that you see them Printing their proud hoofs i' th' receiving earth, For ’tis your thoughts that now must deck our kings, Carry them here and there, jumping o'er times,
Think’st thou I jest?
Think’st thou I’d make a life of jealousy, To follow still the changes of the moon With fresh suspicions?
Think’st thou that duty shall have dread to speak When power to flattery bows?
Think’st thou the fiery fever will go out With titles blown from adulation?
Think’st thou, Hortensio, though her father be very rich, any man is so very a fool to be married to hell?
This ’greed upon To part with unhacked edges and bear back Our targes undinted.

This a good block.

This approves her letter That she would soon be here.

This blows my heart.

This is the excellent foppery of the world that when we are sick in fortune—often the surfeit of our own behavior—we make guilty of our disasters the sun, the moon, and the stars, as if we were villains by necessity, fools by heavenly compulsion, knaves, thieves, and treachers by spherical predominance, drunkards, liars, and adulterers by an enforced obedience of planetary influence, and all that we are evil in by a divine thrusting-on.

This night I hold an old accustomed feast, Whereto I have invited many a guest Such as I love.
This night I’ll spend Unto a dismal and a fatal end.
This night methinks is but the daylight sick.
This night—wherein the cub-drawn bear would couch, The lion and the belly-pinchèd wolf Keep their fur dry—unbonneted he runs, And bids what will take all.

Thomas the earl of Surrey and himself, Much about cockshut time, from troop to troop Went through the army cheering up the soldiers.
Those are the raisèd father and his friends.
Those being all my study, The government I cast upon my brother And to my state grew stranger, being transported And rapt in secret studies.
Those his goodly eyes, That o’er the files and musters of the war Have glowed like plated Mars, now bend, now turn The office and devotion of their view Upon a tawny front.
Those linen cheeks of thine Are counselors to fear.
Those of his chamber, as it seemed, had done ’t.
Those that “Hobgoblin” call you, and “sweet Puck,” You do their work, and they shall have good luck.
Those that are good manners at the court are as ridiculous in the country as the behavior of the country is most mockable at the court.
Those that are in extremity of either are abominable fellows and betray themselves to every modern censure worse than drunkards.
Those that are married already, all but one, shall live.
Those that do die of it do seldom or never recover.
Those that do teach young babes Do it with gentle means and easy tasks.
Those that have known the earth so full of faults.
Those that Macbeth hath slain.
Those that were your father’s enemies Have steeped their galls in honey, and do serve you With hearts create of duty and of zeal.
Those that will follow Cassius, go with him, And public reasons shall be renderèd Of Caesar’s death.
Those that will hear me speak, let 'em stay here.
Those that with haste will make a mighty fire Begin it with weak straws.

Thou ’dst never fear the net nor lime, The pitfall nor the gin.

Thou art armed, Gloucester.
Thou art as wise as thou art beautiful.
Thou art come to answer A stony adversary, an inhuman wretch Uncapable of pity, void and empty From any dram of mercy.
